Ideal location, perfectly sized and well appointed rooms (with balconies, rare in Tokyo), fantastic staff. This hotel delighted us with attention to every detail - air quality, lighting, views, furniture, floral arrangements, food and service. Elegant without trying to impress.

I've been fortunate to stay at several 5-star hotels in Tokyo. The Palace, however, is the creme de la creme. Why do I say this? Because even when I'm at the other hotels, I recall the greatness of the Palace and compare wherever I am staying to it. The rooms are the most spacious, the bathrooms are over the top, the bathtub is opulent, the views cannot be beat. The bar near the lobby area is a special preserve of forest and lake in the otherwise concrete jungle of Tokyo. Nothing beats the Palace (although I don't remember how good the wifi is and whether you have to pay for it). If you can afford it, stay at the Palace.
user_name:
vacationsy
New York City, New York

review_body: For a change this is an established (over 50 years) but superbly renovated and upscaled example of japanese luxury hotels. The refit has maintained elegant lines and exquisite use of luxurioys material, yet not overbearing or taking away from the unique setting and perspective, being right next to the imperial palace & garden.The 6th floor lounge - great compliments to the impeccable service and attention to detail - is the perfect location to enjoy a glass of champagne while looking out on the palace garden and square/loop.

room was pricey for size and location in hotel. attentive staff; very formal Japanese style.gym was adequate; small but needed weight equipment (e.g., lat pull down, fly machine) but could still get a decent workout, although gym was very warm. great location on quiet street, particularly at night. close to many restaurants. Buffet was more geared to american breakfast than Japanese (would have liked more fish), but, again, was fine.

Everybody raves about Japan. Oh the food! Oh the polite people! Oh it's sooooo clean! Do try the toilets!!!Can one country truly be that amazing?? I had high expectations needless to say, plus I spent over a year planning and researching (that is even longer than I took planning my wedding!).We travelled as a family with two children 8 yo and 10 yo. Most places will not allow a family of 4 to share a room as the maximum is 3. I was on a mission. I wanted 5-star plus I only wanted to book ONE room!After checking out numerous websites I narrowed it down to 3. Palace Tokyo came up trumps! I rang them directly, the reservations person was lovely, very understanding of my requirements - one room with king bed and a rollaway, plus breakfast included. Despite the language and pronunciation barrier, they had my booking spot on! (Even some hotelsin Australia get it wrong)The rooms are luxuriously appointed, bedding, amenities, numerous tea & coffee selections and even a balcony! I believe that all rooms have the same view of the gorgeous lake and water fountains we had just based on the positioning of the hotel. Two swans (Romeo and Juliet or so I'm told by the general manager Ian Jordan) cruises by each morningwhilst we have breakfast at the restaurant terrace. Breakfast is a scrumptious buffet with a good western and traditional Japanese mix. We had the rice and Japanese curry six mornings in a row. I can honestly say that all staff are very personable and would gladly spend time chatting with you. They genuinely take interest in what you do and offer assistance when required. Nothing is too difficult and theyare always, I stress, always, calm and smiling.On weekends, beautifully dressed Japanese ladies and smart looking gentleman grace the venue. It's more business clientele on weekdays. At certain times of the day, kimono clad waitresses serve afternoon tea. The fact that the place is frequent by locals tells us that they also approve and enjoy both the food and ambience. They are a culture that strives perfection so we are in the right place.The Otemachi train station is conveniently located just below the hotel, the escalator takes you down where the famous Japanese 7-ELEVEN convenient store is located. There are also additional shops and restaurants around the area. The Tokyo train station which is the central station for all train lines and Shinkansen trains is just 10 minutes walk away from the hotel. Ask the concierge and he will direct you to the side door of the hotel which leads you directly to the the closest exit to reach this station.The main restaurant for daily buffet breakfast has four seperate areas plus a private room, 1. the terrace with fresh air overlooking the waters and to the right is the famous Imperial Gardens, 2. a glasshouse with hanging baskets with greenery (I'll nickname this the greenhouse), 3. the lounge with low comfortable sofas which is also near the bar and each night a smiling pianist plays beautiful melody on the Steinway and 4. the room where the numerous food stations are.Also adjoining to this is a private room which I saw was used forbreakfast meetings. I can't fault the food served. Juices arefreshly squeezed and by day 3 they have already preempted that I'd like green tea even before I had told them. Pastries are fluffy and buttery, I love the four sectioned plate (you will have to go and check it out for yourself) so that your food selection will not mix and taint its original flavour, there are many other dish selections if this doesn't suit your needs (I am amazed), the fruit bar generously overflowing with a good selection considering how expensive Japanese fruits can be plus others which I did not even try as I always head for my Japanese rice and curry. The chef serving knows me and we smile, greet each other and he sees me again the next day.Ian Jordan the general manager is warm and friendly, he takes the effort and time to check the weather when he asked our plans for the day. One morning he came by just to bid us farewell as it was his day off the next day. You can tell that he takes pride in the place. All other encounter with staff were also very positive. Once I had to ride the lift up to the room because the staff was so kind and had walked ahead of me to press the lift door open just as we came through the main hotel doors. I didn't have the heart to tell him that I was heading down to the 7-ELEVEN store as the kids were tired and hadwanted a quick bite to eat in the room. We had spent the entire day at Disney Sea.We also tried the Kaiseki (multi traditional Japanese meal - 15courses in total for us) and shabu shabu (hot pot with thinly sliced meat and veggies in hot water) dinner at the hotel. The meat had this melting quality in your mouth. Some dishes were too beautiful to eat and some we didn't know where to start as the beauty is also edible.The verdict: A centrally located hotel, top notch staff, clean andvery luxurious spacious room, good food, very zen indeed. I strongly believe that Palace Tokyo Hotel had enhanced our overall experience in Tokyo. We will definitely return.

The hotel is in the center of tokyo close to the imperial palace. The train station is about a 10 minutes walk. A little bit more for the ginza. There is about seven restaurants and a couple of bars. You can eat inside or outside at the main dining room in the lobby. There is a seven eleven on the lower floor if you need local currency. There is a lot of people looking at your every need with a very friendly attitude. Most of them speak english. The food is excellent but expensive. There is a lot of dining options in adjacent buildings. Ask the concierge for a list. Lots of choices a la carte or you can choose a fix menu. Rooms are very nice with all the gizmos. No need for electric adaptors if you are coming from north america. Take a room with a balcony looking at the imperial palace gardens, it is the best view.

Everything was basically perfect, except perhaps the price. :) For a special occasion this is a great choice.Shop around because we found this hotel priced differently through different sites, and the hotel's own web site was not the cheapest option.

This hotel is opposite the royal palace in downtown Tokyo is excellent in many aspects including, service, rooms, food, location, polite and friendly staff.The rooms are fantastic with all equipment fully operational and excellent wifi

From the moment you enter The Palace Hotel you are greeted by polite and friendly staff. The service at this hotel is second to none. The rooms are spacious and well appointed with every mod con your heart could desire. The hotel is located right in the heart of Marunouchi business district above Japan's sprawling subway system. After a long day exploring it was great to come back and relax and unwind at the pool/spa or grab a drink at one of the hotel bars.

I have just stayed here for 4 nights during a business trip, level 22 with a great balcony view of the Imperial Gardens. I have to say that my experience here was 1st class. Staff are extremely respectful and helpful, every interaction is a pleasure. The rooms are impeccable with the smallest detail considered for your convenience. You have a great variety of in house restaurants and bars, all are unique and impressive. There is also a good variety of shops underneath the hotel as well as a very handy subway station. In my opinion this is one of the best hotels in the world, certainly that I have ever stayed at.

The Palace Hotel is very high tech and pure luxury "at a price". Rooms are spacious and luxurious. Staff are very polite and can't do enough for you. The food was fantastic, lots of choice in the hotel. There were shops underneath the hotel, Tokyo station was not far away and the Imperial Palace and gardens across the road

We went to Tokyo for 8 days as a family trip with our 10 years old. The Palace Hotel was the perfect choice. It is close to Tokyo Station but the neighborhood is not crowded and there is still plenty to do. We stayed at the Chiyuda Suite with a beautiful view on the Palace and gardens.The Hotel public spaces a beautiful, you have a choice of many restaurants with spectacular food, specially the different japanese restaurants (we tryed the Tepanyaki and the Tempura restaurants).We had a full access to the Club Lounge with breakfast (western or Japanese) included and the service was just stellar.The room was spacious with views all over Tokyo with a good layout. With the jetlag, it was good to have the bedroom isolated from the living room. The beds were very comfortable. The look was modern and japanese at the same time. Beautiful room.Our daughter suffers from food allergies and the hotel was so careful to make sure that everything was safe for her.Everyone was welcoming, with a smile and ready to go above their duties to make sure that we had a great stay. They will do everything possible to make your stay the perfect one. Marc husband and I have stayed in Tokyo many times at different locations (Imperial Hotel, Excel Tokyu in Shibuya) for business but our choice from now on will always be the Palace Hotel.
user_name:
carodufresne2016
New York City, New York

review_body: Great experience. Pros: Well decorated and maintained luxury hotel in Tokyo. A Japanese hotel with Japanese feel, vs the large western chain hotels. Service was top notch. Concierge team helped daily with itineraries and general travel advice. Convenient location, given subway (Otemachi Station) in basement of hotel, and also a short (few blocks)walk to Tokyo Station. A highlight was the balcony overlooking Imperial Palace grounds, and ability to eat breakfast outdoors at the restaurant. In addition to hotel restaurants, there are also some smaller independent restaurants in the basement of the building, as well as a 7-11 with an ATM that takes international cards. Fun: They provide pajamas for you daily.Cons: Can't think of any. I'd stay here again and recommend it to friends and family.
user_name:
DC-AXA
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Prive, the lounge bar on the sixth floor of the Palace Hotel, was a great find. After wandering gardens around Tokyo's Imperial Palace we set off to this top class hotel we could see on the other side of the moat. What an oasis, what a stylish place. What a great place for afternoon tea. Escorted to our table overlooking the gardens and Imperial Palace, we ordered cocktails before tea, coffee and treats. The staff were so attentive, offering to take us outside to a balcony to photograph the family. A wonderful experience for us all. I'd recommend going here for afternoon tea or evening drinks. Worth the price.

I had a great room on the 21st floor overlooking the imperial palace and gardens. The bed was comfortable, the bathtub was perfect, the gym overlooked the gardens, and the restaurants were delicious. It was a great stay and conveniently located for walking to meetings.
user_name:
Jess_Bkln
New York City, New York

review_body: We visited during Cherry Blossom Season in April with our kids. It was truly wonderful in every way. Amazing - location, service, room size, comforts, lobby, breakfast buffet, restaurant selection. If you are looking for a hip, luxurious hotel in a central location with a true Japanese feeling, this is the place for you.

The room was graciously appointed with an expansive view. The breakfast buffet was as good as any I have had in all of my travels. Additionally, the lounge, and restaurants made this tops. The location was out of the hubbub but still centrally located, with the subway right under the hotel. The staff was very helpful and all services were excellent. I highly recommend this hotel.
user_name:
Kagrin
New York City, New York

review_body: This is a good quality, luxury hotel well located for my needs. The rooms are very well appointed (except the irons are very small) and the bed was very comfortable. The hotel facilities are suitable - there are a number of eating options, a couple of good bars and the gym is well equipped. Also with the gym, it has great views across the palace gardens and it was never busy. The staff, as you would expect in a good Tokyo hotel, are first class - extremely courteous and well trained. I will certainly stay here again when in Tokyo for business.

We travel extensively and stay frequently in high end hotels, in fact, we have stayed in too many now to be able to find a place where we can say everything is perfect. We also did not have very high expectations for this hotel, although we read many great reviews prior our booking. And when we arrived it was not a wow from first sight, but it was a pleasant and comfortable feeling, which is already a lot in the case of an experienced traveler with a keen eye for detail. But as our stay progressed the more we noticed a great attention to detail from every member of staff without exception, be it a check in lady or a luggage assistant or a concierge. Everyone was willing to go out of their way to provide the best service without any visible signs of attitude that one can not help but notice in some hotels. Another great thing about this place is the rooms; they are brand new, tastefully decorated with great and super squeaky clean bathrooms (new design there, which is a big plus). Bathroom amenities are also of high quality with a really nice smell (no disgusting lotion smells there, although the amenities brand was not familiar to me, but the lotion was pleasant to the touch and of nice consistency).We also enjoyed our breakfast on the ground level. The breakfast restaurant has a nice selection of dishes, not overwhelming, just enough. There are also tables outdoors that overlook the Palace grounds and the waterway in between.All in all it was a very peaceful and pleasant stay and we would recommend this hotel to anyone who enjoys high quality accommodation. We already stayed in Peninsular, Mandarin Oriental, Shagri la and Four Seasons Chisan-so (not 4 seasons anymore) in Tokyo, but Palace Hotel and Shangri La are still the best!

Ginza is by far our favorite place to stay in Tokyo. The Palace Hotel is perfectly located with the best view of the Imperial Palace Garden. The subway is conveniently located just downstairs with plenty of affordable restaurants as well. The rooms are well appointed with just the right amount of luxury and comfort.

My wife and I stayed here for a quick two day trip to Tokyo. We both loved the location and the room. It was an quick 5 minute walk from the Tokyo train station and across the street from the palace. We will definitely stay here next time we are in Tokyo.

Staffs were polite and friendly, location was convenient, complimentary wifi was smooth, and in-room dining was a delight. The design was classy and elegant, it's also very practical in ways. One of the best hotels I've ever stayed in.Would definitely return for another stay.

From the moment you drive up, you are greeted with the amazing staff! We had a club level floor therefore we were ushered upstairs to the club level checkin where we were offered a welcome drink along with the complimentary afternoon tea and snack. The complimentary breakfast buffet was equally as delicious. Our room was spacious , the bathroom beautiful with wonderful smelling toiletries. The hotel and rooms were perfect mix of modern Japanese. The location is superb as it sits over a subway station/mall or just a 2 block walk to Tokyo train station.We traveled with our 2 young kids and the staff always went out of their way to make them feel special. The concierge was extremely helpful in organizing tours and dinner reservations. In addition, there is plenty of shopping nearby. If I'm ever back in Tokyo I will make sure to stay at this wonderful hotel again!

We have stayed in this hotel many times- in fact every time we visit Tokyo. It is located in the most prime area in Tokyo- nearby the imperial palace and marunouchi (nice to just take a walk especially during Christmas illumination!) We stayed in rooms with balcony (very rare in Tokyo!) and it kinda reminds you of Central Park in Manhattan when you look out from your balcony and see the Tokyo skyline, palace, river and greens. The hotel is quite new and very elegant. Rooms are spacious and clean. Service was great - the concierge helped us book out all the restaurants we want to go and gave us a map with locations/reservation details labeled out! Also the restaurants inside the hotel are also worth trying. It's very convenient in terms of location as well - the subway is connected to the underground of the hotel, and Tokyo station is just nearby. Would definitely visit whenever we are in Tokyo.

My husband and I chose to stay at the Palace hotel and we are so thankful we did. We arrived late at night and they were nothing less than spectacular. They provide laundered pajamas whixh was amazing not to have to unpack before jumping into bed. The hospitality is magnificent and they are so helpful. They upgraded us for our honeymoon and we were given access to use the lounge. The gym has beautiful views out the windows.
user_name:
tchrnyc
New York City, New York

review_body: To me, going to Tokyo is all about waking up in this hotel and having my coffee in the balcony which overlooks the gardens opposite the Imperial Palace. The rooms are big and the balcony is the best part of it. The unusual Japanese coffee bag is a wonderful experience especially in the colder months.The rooms have separate showers and bathtubs which just makes it nice to relax.The breakfast buffet is wonderful with a large variety and a lovely seating position inside and out.It is around 1 kilometer from the main shopping area, but at least you get to walk in the best place in Tokyo.Tokyo to me is all about this hotel.The price is also the most competitive for such a hotel in Tokyo.People using shuttle services could get their shuttle from this hotel to the airport.It also has a nice shopping area underneath with some restaurants and also an underground link to Tokyo Main Station, which is also around 7 minutes walking.
user_name:
SAF A
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Our family stayed at the Palace hotel in early August for 8 days. It had everything we could hope for and more. Our rooms were modern and impeccably clean. The bathroom had a tv in the mirror and the toilet had a seat warmer, bidet, etc. All the lights and curtains could be remotely controlled from different areas of the room and the tv was state of the art as one would expect. Our room had a fantastic view of the city and palace grounds. We stayed on the club level and enjoyed a great breakfast everyday. The service was phenomenal!!! The concierge was very helpful. They helped arrange Disney Sea tickets, gave us detailed directions for sightseeing and even called and reserved a hairdryer at an electronic store for my wife because she wanted to buy the same one she used in the hotel room! We miss the Palace Hotel and would love to come back soon.

Reserved by one of my friends who is co-chair if the "Afternoon Tea Afficionado's Society of Tokyo," visited with three others in total. Very nicely done with a mix of sweet and savory with a large selection of teas and a few coffees to choose from. We each had multiple kinds of teas in the menu and spent the entire afternoon there as you can relax there and enjoy the view. Would visit again.

Excellent location, adjoining the Imperial Palace and gardens in central Tokyo. Close to subway. Absolutely superb rooms and the Club Floor which has views over the Palace has highly attentive staff. Concierge staff just brilliant.

Loved this hotel. First the location right next to the Imperial Palace is great. Can go out for walks or runs around the moat and it's quite beautiful. It was also very central in Tokyo and easy to get around from there. There is a subway station in the basement of the hotel with many lines. Very convenient.Room are beautiful. We were facing the gardens so had an amazing view. All the luxuries of Asian five star hotels were included. A lot of attention to detail. Only quibble was that international channels were pretty limited, especially on entertainment side. And took me a while to figure out how to hear the stations in English as you can switch between Japanese being spoken over the channels and English.Service in the hotel was exceptional. Very attentive. Staff everywhere in case you need anything.Truly a wonderful hotel.

I have a good friend who travels to Tokyo frequently and he recommended the Palace for our first trip. It's a big hotel but the usual "quality decreases as size increases" rule does not apply here. We had a splendid room on one of the Club floors overlooking the Imperial Palace. The bed was very comfortable, the room was spacious and the bathroom was brilliant: a huge bath, with separate shower and loo, twin vanities - everything you could possibly ask for. The Club floor I can highly recommend. It's a much better place for breakfast than the main cafe downstairs - very peaceful and pleasant. The Club floor also offers beautiful canapes and French champagne gratis in the evenings - something we enjoyed most days. The hotel has a variety of restaurants, both western and Asian, and we tried some of them, although most nights we dined out - Tokyo restaurants are fabulous: don't miss the opportunity.The location is brilliant - as good for business people as it is for tourists. The Imperial Palace is on your doorstep and the subway is below the hotel. It's very efficient and easy to use and will take you to all the sights. And it's slap bang in Tokyo's financial heart.The one downside? It's not cheap, but you get what you pay for!

Have stayed here a few times now and absolutely love it. The rooms are large (for Tokyo) and well appointed, and the location is brilliant. I would suggest eating elsewhere as pricing for internal dining is very expensive, but there are plenty of excellent options nearby.

Likes:1. The view - my room comes with a balcony directly overlooking a garden and the river surrounding Imperial Palace. The expansive view of greenery and the blue sky was pleasing every morning and city lights and the starry sky fascinating in the night. Something you would not expect to enjoy in a bustling city like Tokyo (attached pictures tell it all!).2. The staff - friendly, helpful and efficient. First, the young man who took our luggage to the room with us was very well mannered. He explained the functions of different devices and appliances to us in good English (a surprise in Japan). I was about to tip him for his good service but did not do so because I read somewhere that tipping is not expected in Japan (correct me if I am wrong please). Second, we asked for a few items in certain occasions and they were all sent to our room promptly. Third, we asked of directions/suggestions for visits at the concierge and the staff was patient and very helpful every time.3. The room - spacious and, as I mentioned, with a decent-sized balcony. Very clean everywhere (even my wife who is very sensitive in this aspect was satisfied). Two double beds sleep two of us with two kids quite comfortably - I couldn't find another 5-star hotel in Tokyo that allows / can accommodate 4 people in a standard room. The bathroom is of a good size with a separate shower. There is only one sink though.4. The breakfast - high quality, good variety, not too busy, and again, friendly staff members greeted us and helped with coffee and egg orders. Enjoyed the high ceiling and good distance between tables too.5. The location - very good! 3-minute walk to a subway station and 10-minute to JR Tokyo Station - if you know the direction. All underground. It can be confusing with so many walkways and platforms, so it took us 20+ minutes to find the hotel the evening we arrived by Narita Express. Here is the centre of Tokyo so travelling to anywhere around is efficient.Dislikes: Nil

Excellent location near to the Imperial Palace, in the centre of Tokyo. Easily accessible by metro (Otomachi station leads directly into hotel). Beautiful views. A modern international hotel which still feels Japanese. Good sports room and spa. Very helpful staff.

We totally lucked out with Palace Hotel Tokyo. Got it through Hotwire, where you don't know what you booked until after you pay. From the pictures, this hotel didn't say 'WOW!' Hotel ratings can be 'generous' with 5 stars. Boy...were we in for a big treat...Location: Right across the street from Imperial Palace and within easy walking distance of Tokyo station (where Narita Express drops you off from the airport). If you have lots of bags, you can catch a cab for about 8 USD. Hotel sits on top of one major subway hubs, Ōtemachi, that connects to all Tokyo lines. You just go down an escalator to reach it. On your way to the subway entrance, you will pass a 7-11. It has the best ATM to get cash....super convenient as a lot of places don't take credit. Service: Everyone is Friendly and Efficient....front desk, concierge, housekeeping (twice daily). Top notched and unparalleled.Accommodations: Beautifully decorated in a modern style. Beds were so comfortable, you fall asleep right when you touch the sheets. Terrace overlooked the Wadakura Fountain Park and parts of the Imperial palace. Missing our morning coffees on this terrace...This maybe the best hotel we've ever stayed in...USA, Europe, Asia...Anywhere...

Despite its recent renovation (it re-opened in 2012) the Palace Hotel retains that old fashioned and refined atmosphere that makes it a pleasure to stay at. From the check-in (room ready despite it being 6am in the morning) to late night cocktails in the Royal Bar the service is personal and friendly. Our room, Deluxe with Balcony, was lovely, both spacious and comfy. The windows and balcony on a corner facing in two directions provided views of the Imperial Gardens and the City. The room seemed to be serviced every time we went out with an unlimited supply of towels, dressing downs and pyjamas. It was great to get back every day after a lot of walking and sight-seeing. Neither my wife or I had been to Tokyo for over 25 years and really enjoyed rediscovering the city and its people. The transport is fantastic and you can do most of your sightseeing yourself, but hiring a local guide (from tours by locals), provides a broader perspectives and a few local surprises. We hired a guide to guide us around the Senso-Ji and the local Asakusa taverns. Food was a real highlight for us. From the taverns of Asakusa, to the local ramen, steak and tonkatsu restaurants to fabulous sushi and teppanyaki meals. The Concierge at the Palace recommended and booked Ginza Kuebye a sushi restaurant for us. This was a fantastic meal, not just eating and learning about sushi, but the restaurant is also a special event restaurant for the locals. We were seated (at the counter on 1st floor in the main building) between two Japanese couples, on one side they were celebrating their 51st wedding anniversary and on the other a couple celebrating their 11th anniversary – the younger husband (3 years at boarding school in Orange NSW) and the chef both spoke English and helped to create a fantastic experience. At the hotel we had dinner at the Wadakura GO teppenyaki restaurant. We had the Premium Matsusaka fillet beef menu – the beef and accompanying wasabi (freshly grated) was amazing – as was the whole teppenyaki experience. They also have a great wine list – we drank Japanese white wine by the glass. The Palace Hotel is ideally located for getting just about anywhere in Tokyo, there is direct access to the Otemachi metro station (just be prepared to walk a bit) where there are four metro lines going in almost every direction. Changing trains as needed is also simple with ample signage in English.

it has all the benefits of a 5 star hotel however, they go that extra mile to make sure u r comfortable and happy. smiliing and helpful staff, attention to personal details in room, panoramic view of city and imperial palace. make sure u go to the bakery to see the piano cake!!!

First time in Tokyo. Loved the hotel. Service is great, rooms are clean, spacious and top notch. Breakfast was very good and location amazing. The room view is breath taking!!!We are traveling with. 19 and 15 year old.Definitely come back!

Stayed here since 2 years ago and a must to stay if going Tokyo unless their rooms are fully booked.You feel yourself in Japan once you walk in the lobby, unlike Peninsula and Mandarin Oriental you may feel like you are in HK due to many Hong Kong guests and the decoration are similar.Must stay in the room with balcony with club floor access, balcony facing to Imperial Palace and club floor has variety of beverage with high privacy.The bar has nice cocktails & whisky, breakfast has tonnes of food which fill you up and good taste of course.Sushi Kanesaka and Amber Palace is a must to dine at so you won't really have to leave the hotel whole day, a Sake shop in B1 has premium rare sake to buy too!

Excellent location - train station is underneath which you may reach via the hotel. Walk across the road to the Imperial Palace and spend the afternoon wandering the gardens or if you love the idea of going for a run, join the many many many Japanese that run around the gardens - even at night!Facilities in the hotel are everything you ever wished for and more. The ultimate in mini bars! Dare you not to take a photo!Book an extra day just to enjoy the hotel - sit your bathtub (bubbles supplied!) and watch the T.V. that is incorporated into your bathroom mirror - the height of modernity! (we had room 932).

There are so many great things about the Palace Hotel Tokyo. Its location across the Imperial Palace East Garden is without equal. The hotel is elegant and luxurious. Our room was very large by Tokyo standards with a magnificent view fof cherry blossoms from the balcony. The service was impeccable. We were able to walk to Tokyo Station to catch the Shinkansen and the Subway stop was in the basement 2 level. First class accomodations. We will be back.

I have been aware of the Palace for many years but never stayed their on my frequent trips to Tokyo. A client booked me there and I had a wonderful experience. An excellent location near both Tokyo Station and the Imperial Palace coupled with renovated rooms with excellent technology. I had a great view of the Palace grounds from room 1338. Enjoyed a run around the Palace and had a great lunch in the Japanese restaurant.Service is prompt and friendly. This is a five star that is worth a try

The Japanese manage to do luxury in their own special way. The hotel is absolutely superb, yet quiet and in some ways understated. Service excels and nothing is too much trouble. The lobby, lounge, bar and restaurant areas are luxurious and so enjoyable, yet simple but elegant.

This is a smashing hotel - GO there!Overlooking the emperial palace and with a perfect location close to TOKYO STATION.The service is outstanding. absolutely outstanding. High end service.The have a wonderful restaurant - Grand Kitchen and a great bar In the Ground floor. GO there even you DO NOT stay at the hotel. I stat In a Delux King Room - 30.000 JYP pr. Nat. LUXERY.

Great hotel. Excellent service and first class accommodations. Have stayed here several times in the past few years and it never disappoints. Great location, and excellent restaurants. Would recommend this for business or personal travel. Will definitely be back.

Stayed here with family for a quick three night stay in Tokyo. Location near Tokyo Station is extremely convenient, both for transport to Narita as well as access to the trains. The hotel is everything you would expect in a luxury hotel. Rooms are spacious and well appointed and the staff went well out of their way to be friendly and helpful. I will definitely stay here again.

Great service and attitude from all the staff in this hotel. It was an amazing experience thanks to the people. The hotel is beautiful and with an excellent location. The rooms are very comfortable and luxurious. The spa is incredible and the pool has an amazing view. The Concierge did everything to accommodate our needs and requests. Again, this is the best service I have experienced in any hotel in my life.

Just returned from a 4 night stay. The hotel is fantastic. We had the room with the club lounge access. The lounge was great. The breakfast was as good as the one served at the main restaurant. The location of this hotel can not be beat. We had a view of the imperial palace which was just stunning. In addition, there is a subway station downstairs from the hotel which made sightseeing more convinient. The hotel is about about a 5-10 minute walk from the Tokyo station. I would recommend walking there with your luggage. Otherwise, The cab ride for a 3 minute ride is $40.

We very much enjoyed our stay at this hotel. Aside from the service and features that you would expect from a hotel in this price range, what sets this hotel apart is the magnificent views over the imperial palace, it's moots/walls and Tokyo generally, they must be the best views in Tokyo. What's more, many rooms from what it could see, including ours, have sizable balconies to allow you to take full advantage, we in fact ate in on the balcony our first night. Aside from the palace, the location is a little removed from shopping and restaurant districts, ginza is 10 taxi ride away, however it is within walking distance of Tokyo station which is convenient. All in all, I would highly recommend this hotel.

Expensive but worth it. Great service and very nice staff. Perfect, up to date and very comfortable rooms. Excellent location in center of town but still quit rooms. Nice spa and business support. It probably doesn't get any better than this.

Everything is just perfect. Large rooms, modern furnishing, great service, beatiful lobby and the best view of Tokyo. We could see the palace and Tokyo tower from our room. The pool with jacuzzi is wonderful. It was so nice that we didn't wan to leave our suite :)

I stayed here for 3 nights and had a wonderful stay. The location is great - across the street from the Imperial Palace, direct access to Otemachi station and within a 10 minute walk from Tokyo Station. The property itself is amazing - 7+ restaurants, immaculate communal areas and lovely spa. Staff members were multi-lingual and, of course, Japanese service and hospitality is the best in the world. Lastly, the room was modern and spacious. The room had high tech controls, universal adapters, great bathroom amenities, free wi-fi, nice mini bar and a large balcony overlooking the entrance to the Imperial Palace. Overall, wonderful stay - I will be back!

The hotel is luxurious. The staffs are very very polite and warm welcoming. I love my room, it's spacios, well organized and they provide us with alot of great stuffs. Great view to the city, and... they gave us yummy welcome treats..

We have been organizing stay for our VIPs at this hotel for quite some time and I must say service is superb here up to details. Hotel has been rebuilt couple of years ago and since then it become one of the top hotels in Tokyo. If you compare to luxury hotels in Tokyo then you will see why this is my choice. Great breakfast at the terrace, highly recommended.

My daughter and I rarely have the opportunity to spend quality time together, as we are both successful working professionals -- so this trip needed to provide us with a flawless experience. Choosing over The Peninsula, The Four Seasons and The Ritz Carlton was a difficult decision -- but absolutely the right one! From the ambience to the architecture to the amenities, and especially the staff, our stay could not have been more enjoyable. We were on the Club floor for 10 days and when we left, it truly felt like we were saying goodbye to family. Rest assured, we will be back.

もしあなたが日本に滞在する旅行者ならば強くお勧めいたします。日本の上質なサービスをすぐに堪能できると思います。どのレストランも、ルールサービスも価格相応でクオリティは高いと思います。部屋は皇居の庭園に面したバルコニー付きの部屋がお勧めです。If you come to Japan for travel, We strongly recommend to stay palace hotel Tokyo. it's easy to feel Japanese service quality. Each restaurant, and room service's quality are quite high. The Room with balcony is better.

Stayed there for three night. The Japanese hospitality is at the best, right from checkin to your restaurant or room service.Very well located, both business district and the tourist hub. The room was very big compared to other Japanese hotels. They have renovated the place and has come off very well. The mini-bar a delight. The buffet breakfast is a treat. can have good walk around the surrounding areas.

The Palace Hotel Tokyo is a paradise set in the heart of the world's largest city. Right next to the Imperial Palace, the hotel provides exclusive views of the palace grounds. There is ample openness around the hotel because of this location and with a park in front of the hotel as well. The rooms are very comfortable, providing comfortable luxury to rest after a day of exploring the city. We had access to the club lounge which provided additional sanctuary from crowds that may form in the more public areas of the hotel. The lounge also provided a nice outdoor patio that allowed for a great view of the palace and city in general.The breakfast buffet was excellent. A huge selection of cuisine, both Japanese and Western. Any culinary preference can easily be satisfied. We also tried the main restaurant for dinner. The menu also gave many options and the quality was excellent. Amongst us we had a fish dish, chicken, and a gourmet burger, truffle fries, etc. All very tasty. The highlight was the Japanese sushi restaurant. Please make reservations because there are only 13 seats in the place. It is a price fix menu. The sushi is made fresh right in front of you. We have not tasted better sushi anywhere. Since we could not get into Jiro's in Ginza (one month in advance reservation needed), this was a spectacular experience in ints place. Kudos to the hotel and the restaurant for providing such a exquisite culinary delight. In the lower level of the hotel, there is a shopping area. Don't miss the sweets shop. It has excellent desserts and candy. There are some restaurants, a convenience store, a some other shops as well. Very handy place. As another bonus, there is a subway station connected to the hotel as well via a tunnel. The hotel is a great option for the luxury traveler in Tokyo.

The Palace Hotel Tokyo is one of the nicest hotels that I have ever stayed in!The minute that you step into the elegant, modern lobby with soaring ceiling and gorgeous flower arrangements, you know that you're in for a treat!The staff is incredible - friendly and knowledgable with perfect English.Our room was on the 23rd floor overlooking the Imperial Palace with a spectacular view of the city. The room was spacious and bright with a balcony, modern bathroom and very comfortable bed with amazingly soft sheets.The International Breakfast Buffet was delicious and offered a wide variety of food choices. We also went to dinner at "Go" - the Palace's Teppanyaki restaurant and it was fabulous!The hotel is located above the Otemachi subway station, so it's easy and convenient to travel anywhere in the city. It's also very close to Tokyo Station if you are traveling by train.We used the expertise of the Concierge several times for advice on restaurants, train schedules, etc. She also provided us with city maps which were incredibly helpful!We didn't have a chance to use the fitness center, spa or pool but they all looked very nice.Our entire experience at the Palace Hotel Tokyo was first class, and I would highly recommend it!

Just got back from spending 4 nights here. Rooms are good size for Tokyo standards hotel is relatively large with full amenities such as multiple restaurants gym spa etc. rooms are updated and have good size bathrooms. Service is friendly and helpful. Mostly all service staff speak English. Twice daily maid service complimentary newspaper. Location is adjacent to imperial palace grounds and i believe all rooms have views of the palace with private balconies. Hotel is located above otemachi station with easily access via hotel escalators from lobby. Short walk from Tokyo station as well. What I really loved about the hotel was being in central Tokyo yet still having the feeling of openness and tranquility because of the views of the palace grounds. All of which are unobstructed. Fabulous 5 star hotel which I would stay again

I traveled with my 2 teenagers daughters to Tokyo for 6 nights at this hotel. Everything is nice here, but if I have gotten a bigger room, that will be super! Very impressed with the shower especially the rain shower! The pressure of water is very strong that other hotels cannot compare to. The shampoos, shower gels, etc are filled up for three everyday. In addition, the pajamas that the hotel provides everyday are so comfortable. The buffet lunch is also nice but if there are more varieties, that would be perfect. The Otemachi station is very near that we could walk through the hotel gate which is connected to the station All of the staff are polite and very helpful. All in all, very impressed with the Palace Hotel Tokyo.

It is aptly named Palace Hotel as the Imperial Palace moats run by it. Your morning breakfast views are of this peaceful waterway and the Palace grounds next door. The accommodations are fantastic - I loved the in-mirror TV in the bathroom which was very spacious. Centrally located to train station. We hired an English- speaking tour guide through the concierge for a day trip to the fish market and Mt Fiji, then a 2nd day for the sites of Tokyo. Well worth it as she worked with us to tailor-make our day. Great service from this hotel.

Wow. Just amazing. Service is up to the highest level of the Peninsula Tokyo (ok, there everyone new our names within a few hours, but that is not high on our list). Reasonably priced for a luxury Tokyo hotel in the area. Wonderful room with view of the Imperial Palace, large bath tub, separate shower, and balcony, and complimentary wifi. Twin rooms also have walk-in closet and tub next to the window plus Nespresso machine (but we got one at no charge after asking). Concierge service is immediately responsive and excellent. Breakfast outside in ethereal location overlooking the Palace moat is not to be missed; everything you could want for about $40 all-inclusive! That means espresso and cappuccino, brewed least tea, freshly squeezed juices including tomato and green spinach, the best soft scrambled eggs and any other egg preparation you want including omelets, all types of breakfast meats, cheeses, and fruit, lox, freshly brick oven warmed croissants and breads, fresh greens, steamed vegetables, Japanese shrimp curry and other breakfast items, and more. And then there is the 6th floor swimming pool and jacuzzi, huge well-equipped gym, and world class spa with sauna. Plus a half-dozen expensive but top flight restaurants including a branch of the famous Sushi Kanesaka, a Chinese restaurant well-.regarded for its Peking .duck, and a 6th floor Prive bar restaurant with amazing views plus the cozy dark Royal Bar downstairs. And underground way to subway stop so you don't need to worry about rain, plus shops and restaurants. We are returning at the end of the Japan trip from Kyoto for our last two nights. Also recommend Seamon sushi restaurant a short taxi ride away.

The hotel location is good and the great view of imperial palace ... The overall hotel design and ambiance is great after their renovation ... their newly renovated guest room is decent and comfortable... Look like Spacious than before ... the lobby , japanese restaurant from the design , ambiance and the food is great... Service still as good as before ... We recommend this hotel for trip advisor friends...

This hotel is beautiful. Elegant and with a peaceful ambience great for relaxing and traveling.We loved the rich breakfast and dinner in the french restaurant.Personnel polite and helpful.The only thing is that its a little far away from everything
user_name:
Ninfa L
San Pedro Garza Garcia, Mexico

review_body: This hotel was spotless and very comfortable. Our room was spacious and nicely laid out and had everything we need. We particularly liked the large balcony over looking the imperial garden. I don't remember the last time I've been to a hotel in a city that had a balcony. The weather was perfect and my husband and I enjoyed a couple of glasses of wine in the evening. The gym was also really nice, with very modern equipment and amazing service. In general I found the service to be impeccable. The hotel is located right above a small subway station (can't remember the name) and minutes from the Tokyo station. My only gripe, and this is through no fault of the hotel, is that being located in the business district, the hotel felt a little stiff. But that is entirely the product of the people who passed through there and nothing to do with the service. The other complaint, I suppose is the breakfast is very uninspiring. The selection is not that great and surprisingly the buffet had no Japanese options! The breakfast venue, over looking the lake by the palace was very nice though so we ended up eating there anyway. Would have been great if the food were good given that food pretty much anywhere in Japan is good!

This was my first stay at the Palace Hotel but due to AMEX promotion and location next to the Imperial Palace and close to Tokyo Station I decided to give it a try. Needless to say I was impressed and this will be my 1st choice next visit to Tokyo. Pros:- The service was worthy of a 5 Star property.- Club lounge staff was first class.- The views and location next to the Imperial Palace was welcomed- Breakfast on the Terrance was relaxing - For Japan the Health Club was spacious and available 24 hours- Large rooms Cons:- Maybe price but compared to other hotels not much different and the staff, location, and amenities made up for any difference.

We stayed here as a splurge trip after I recently got promoted and we were not disappointed. After arriving early morning from Sydney we were greeted by hotel staff who ran 20m to greet us and take our bags. From entering the hotel and all the way to our room, the hotel has luxury and class oozing from every wall, every artwork and more. The room is huge even for non-Tokyo standards. We weren't sure what the views from our room would be like but were delighted with the spectacular Imperial Palace gardens view (please see my uploaded pics). Service is exceptional and better than any other 5 star hotel we've stayed at. Location is great at walking distance to both Tokyo station (important if you're keen on exploring other parts of Tokyo/Japan) and upmarket Ginza. Pros - modern luxury with no expenses spared facilities and ambience- huge rooms (ask for palace garden views)- great location next to Imperial Palace with access to both Tokyo station and Ginza- excellent service- inhouse Evian spa (we only used it to use the shower facilities on our arrival but looks top class)- can't ask for anything better in Tokyo (anything else will set you back double the price)Cons- skip the buffet breakfast, choice is limited for price and there's plenty of better options in the areaMake no mistake, at $4000 for 6 nights this hotel is not for you if you're on a budget but if you afford the splurge then there's nowhere else I would stay. We will be back!!

The size of the rooms, the level of service, the atmosphere and elegance have lead me to the title of this posting. The Palace's breakfast restaurant is beautifully decorated and if you upgrade to the Club level then you get the perks of the free amenities that come with the club lounge access, including your own balcony and lounge overlooking the Imperial Palace grounds. I highly recommend a room with a balcony!

I love Tokyo - and I love the Palace Hotel in Tokyo. Seems to combine the best of Western 5* luxury with Japanese world leading service standards. The room was very well sized and we had a balcony looking south over Ginza. Pricing for room service, hotel restaurants and bars is a bit punchy, but I guess not totally unexpected. I will probably stay here again on my next trip. I drop it down to 4* for the slightly over-the-top pricing of drinks and snacks in the room and around the hotel.

Stayed at Palace for 6 days and Palace got to be the best hotel ever for me. Location is next to the Grand Palace in the CBD of Tokyo. The Tokyo train station is a 7mins walk away. Service is impeccable. Old school service. Very happy with the hotel.

One of the best hotels I have ever stayed at. The service was a fabulous. The breakfast was one of the best ever. The location was in the business district and near Ginza (great fro restaurants and shopping) which was perfect for us. It is across from the Imperial Palace which is perhaps the most frequented running jogging course in Tokyo. Exactly 3 miles around. Nightlife is in a different area but just a short taxi ride.

Somewhat mixed stay, excellent room and food quality great however let down by poor concierge service on 3 occasions. Was very hard to get a restaurant booking in hotel unless you booked well in advance. Location and view awesome were exceptional

The Palace Hotel was the first hotel that my husband and I stayed at during our 10 day trip to Tokyo and Kyoto. I had contacted the concierge via email months before our arrival to find out if they could assist us with getting sumo tickets. The concierge was extremely helpful, replied promptly to all of my emails and got us great tickets for the day that we requested which was the day before the last day of the tournament which is apparently a difficult day to get tickets for. They also helped me with booking a dinner reservation even though it was for a day when we were no longer staying at the hotel. When we checked in, the concierge gave us our sumo tickets and asked if there was anything else we were planning on doing and we said that we were planning on going to a baseball game and they offered to help us get tickets for that and explained the best seating areas at the game and again we got great tickets with their help. The concierge also helped out when the portable wi fi we rented from an outside company didn't work. The maps that they provide for the area around the hotel and the Tokyo subway system were excellent and clearer than the 4 other subway maps that I had! It was also very convenient to have the Otemachi stop in the hotel basement. The room was lovely, the bed comfortable and lots of space in the bathroom. We also had a beautiful view of the Imperial Palace grounds. Though there were many people staying at the hotel, it was very quiet at night and no noise issues in the room. The hotel hair dryer was also great which is a always a big plus for me! The design of the hotel being right next to the Imperial Palace and having the option of eating breakfast outside helped to provide a feeling of being in an oasis in the middle of a very large city. The breakfast buffet was very good and we also ate at the lounge one night and that was very good as well. All of the staff that we encountered were helpful and friendly and spoke English. The hotel made me feel very comfortable when I was nervous about being in Japan for the first time and being in a country where I didn't know the language. I was happy that we chose the Palace Hotel and that it was our first stop on the trip. I was sad to leave it!
Hotel is directly Opposite the Imperial Palace.Many choice of Restaurants within the Hotel.Ginza is nearby so lots of shopping.10 mins walk to Tokyo station.Service staff are great, and room in nice.

This hotel exceeded our expectations. It is located adjacent to the Imperial Palace. There are several beautiful gardens and pools that can be seen from the hotel balconies. While there are many office buildings around the hotel, the area was a bit of an oasis from the rest of Tokyo with none of the bright lights, shopping or entertainment. The hotel is a 10 minute easy walk from Tokyo station. We took the Narita Express train to to Tokyo station and easily found the North Mariouche (sp?) exit and easily walked to the hotel. Check in was easy and friendly and we got the type of room requested in our reservation. We were on a high floor with a balcony overlooking the two pools and gardens of the palace. Also a great nightime view of the city. The room was large and equipped with a mini bar that included lots of whiskey on the top portion and more mundane drinks and snacks in the bottom half. We were also impressed by the in-mirror TV in the bath room! There are restaurant options in the hotel although they are very expensive. I may be a bit off on this price but I think a roast beef sandwich was about $30. If you want casual food you are better off visiting one of the malls in the lower floors of the adjacent office buildings where you will find a variety of take out or eat in food that is much less pricey. The same is true for breakfast. We used this location as a jump off point to visit other areas of Tokyo. We hired a guide to help us navigate the subway but after that were able to find our own way although we did not go too far outside the main city circular route. I would definitely recommend this hotel but would caution about the price.

The Palace Hotel is conveniently located just a short walk to the Tokyo station. Tokyo is a very easy city to get around and the Otemachi subway station, just minutes away, can be reached without going outside the building. The property is also directly adjacent to the Royal Palace grounds in the heart of Tokyo. At checkin the the staff were so friendly and refreshing, but our entire trip in Japan everyone was so very nice.Our room was a good size, beautiful, well furnished and comfortable beds. The bathroom was very nice with separate shower and luxury toiletries, with fluffy towels and the awesome Japanese towel. This is a excellent hotel with excellent staff and I highly recommend this property for travelers seeking a luxury stay.
I stayed there yesterday for silver wedding with my wife.Thank you for wonderful time.Breakfast was so nice.We visited Higashi Gyoen today. The hotel location was so good.Hotel staff also excellent.

We were so sad to depart from the Palace Hotel, which was the first place we stayed at during my first ever trip to Japan. We absolutely loved our stay here! In a nutshell, the hotel is straight-up classy and the service is impeccable. Our garden view suite on the 22nd floor was spacious and sunlight filled with unbeatable views of the Imperial Palace and Tokyo skyline from every room. Access to the Club Lounge made our stay especially enjoyable. Daily breakfast, canapés + cocktails were much appreciated after full days of exploring Tokyo. The hotel is located at Otemachi train station, which connects many train lines. The stores in the hotel arcade are all quite up-scale, although thankfully there is also a 7-11 (the convenience of which can’t be overstated!) Hotel gym is open 24 hours, which is great when you are jetlagged and trying to kill time before breakfast. If you are visiting Tokyo, stay here!
user_name:
ShuliQ
New York City, New York

review_body: Room was fantastic and very spacious with an amazing view. The hotel is just 5-10 minutes walk from Tokyo station, that's why it's also perfect for taking the Shinkansen trains. Another benefit: there is a subway station directly next to the hotel and Ginza is in walking distance. I case you didn't book a room with breakfast, you can find a Dean & Deluca just around the corner, half way in direction to Tokyo station. We recommend to take at least one drink in the very nice bar because the view is really great. We also liked the opportunity to eat outside.

We spent the first 3 night of our honeymoon at the Palace Hotel in Tokyo. Everything about the hotel was top quality - the airport pickup car with free wifi, the room, the food and the service . Our room was fantastic with an amazing view of the Imperial Palace. On our first morning we were even able to see Mount Fuji. The hotel even left us small gifts to congratulate us on our honeymoon. The size of the room was very large, the bed was very comfortable, the bathroom immaculate and the location was fantastic for seeing the city across the 3 nights. Very central and close to Tokyo train station. The food both fro breakfast and room service was top quality and very enjoyable. The hotel is pricey - and I feel more expensive then what you would pay for similar quality in other countries .
user_name:
Aaron C
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: We spent 5 nights at the Palace Hotel Tokyo. We were very impressed with the exceptional level of service we received. We took a standard room that had an amazing view on the imperial garden and was impeccably maintained. The dining options in the hotel are excellent. We tried both bars, Kanesaka (sushi) and the lounge. Everything was perfect. A special shoutout to the extremely friendly French bar tender at the Royal Bar who really took good care of us.

great hotel great position surrounded by a good shopping strip with everything you could wish for .you dont have to go far tp savour great Japanese food and dont forget to visit kaisers french bakery when you need a baguet fix. the bar on the higher floor not cheap but extensive city views good atmosphere special mention Mamoru denda good sense of humour and very personable overall the service is faultless the concierge will do anything possible any research wanted .

I've had business and pleasure trips to nice hotels in the USA and overseas, most of them outstanding, but the Palace Hotel in Tokyo now has top spot in my personal list of Best Hotels. The hotel has virtually everything you'd expect in a five-star property: clean, large and comfortable rooms, fresh flowers in the lobby and an attentive staff. What sets this hotel apart from the others is -- the bathroom. There are both a tub and a large shower. The shower's water pressure is seemingly equal to a fire hydrant hose. The Western style toilet has a heated seat, different flush modes and can be used as a bidet. This full-scale luxury comes with a price, of course, but if you are seeking luxury and close proximity to the Imperial Gardens (located across the street), this hotel should not disappoint.

This remains my favorite hotel in Tokyo. It is ideally located to rail and subway lines, within easy walking distance of many central neighborhoods, and has a distinct personality.While it feels very Japanese (unlike many other 5 star global chains in Tokyo) it continues to demonstrate incredibly high service levels while making you feel welcome. It is calm, sophisticated, and restful.The rooms are quite large for Tokyo. They are bright, very comfortable, and well equipped. The views overlooking the garden are lovely.The breakfast, bar, and overall amenities are also top notch.

Picked up at Narita by car. It was worth every penny. Met at the Palace by 3 bell staff. Very efficient and polite. On check in I discovered that I left my passport in the car. No problem. We were whisked off to our Deluxe King Room. Front desk retrieved passport and delivered to room.What a room! The bathroom with a huge bath tub overlooking the city, with Tokyo Tower straight off in the distance. Beautiful view of Imperial Gardens. The room was spotless. The bed very comfortable.Downstairs directly under the hotel was a 7 - 11 with a reliable atm. Many shops and eateries. Entrance to train station.It was raining and the bell staff provided umbrellas. The staff were so helpful with directions.Tokyo is full of great hotels, but you will regret choosing this one.

Place Hotel Tokyo is one of the most beautiful hotel I have ever stayed. The room are just gorgeous with their big balconies with wonderful view of the skyline of Tokyo. Bars and Restaurants are first rate and the personal is very nice and helpful all over the hotel.

This may very well be my favorite hotel and definitely one for your bucket list. The rooms are spacious and well appointed, the lobby, bar and public spaces are gorgeous, the service is impeccable, and the location is, well, next to the Imperial Palace. Enough said. Expensive, yes. But the price for pure luxury and an unmatched sense of serenity is well worth it.

Highly recommended in every respect: Good location in the center of everything but with lots of greenery around, stylish yet homey design with only the best materials, warm and professional service, spacious rooms featuring just about anything one would ever need, excellent infrastructure of restaurants, spa, and third party facilities.

We recently stayed 4 nights at The Palace Hotel and could not find fault with our choice. We enjoyed the location next to the Imperial Gardens and above a very convenient subway station Otemachi. From here we had easy access to all parts of Tokyo. The staff were professional and personable. The concierge staff in particular were always most helpful. We dined teppanyaki style at Wadakura Restaurant which was expensive but exceptional. Would most highly recommend this hotel.

We do not often stay in 5 Star hotels, but The palace lived up to all our expectations.Large room, with full selection of facilities. Only slight criticism is that they could supply some more interesting English language movie Channels. 5 News Channels was a bit tedious after a few days.Excellent breakfasts, helpful, friendly staff, wide selection of restaurants and comfortable Bars.Ground Floor Bar was a bit dark and old fashioned. It could be made brighter and more modern, as it was very sociable and not so formal as 6/F Bar. Excellent set meal in Japanese restaurant, which saves foreigners having to choose from perhaps unfamiliar Japanese dishes. Delicious and very well explained by the two expert waitresses who looked after us. Excellent variety of wine by the glass to choose from, as well as top end bottles.

I stayed at this hotel recently. It is a beautiful stylish hotel BUT. It is very expensive and when paying extra for Club Lounge access I dont expect to have to pay to use a computer in the business centre or to visit the sauna after using the gym. I had 2 rooms, one for my son and one for my wife and I. We could not get lounge access for both rooms on booking but there were no problems to get lounge access on check-in, but they wanted an extra daily USD 155 per person. The service in the Hotel as immaculate, other than at their signature restaurant which compared poorly to other Japanese restaurants we visited. The Club Lounge offerings were meagre; French champagne but the other drinks were only fair and the canapes pretty ordinary. For a Hotel that charged USD 350 for late checkout ie USD 700/ night it needs to stop the upsell. The Langham Xintiandi, Shanghai is better.

This place is wonderful with beautiful views, facilities and restaurants. The service personnel is perfect.the booking with American Express is a must giving additional credits and accesses.the location is perfect not only because a of views to the Palace but also a short walk to the Central Station.

To qualify, we would not have stayed here for the normal nightly rate this hotel charges. BUT, we had a free night on hotels.com, and opted to use that for our one night in Tokyo and only had to pay a little less than half what the normal rate would be. With that being said, this room was HUGE for a hotel in Japan. I had traveled to Japan before maybe a decade or so with my family (four of us), and the typical hotel room sizes are tiny. We selected this hotel because of its proximity to Tokyo station, and for having a view of the Palace across the street (and moat). We were only staying in Tokyo that night as we were heading to Kyoto the following morning, and we did not get into Tokyo city from Narita airport until about 5pm. Additionally, we would have liked to visit the palace, but we were not able to as it is closed to the public at 4 or 5pm, and closed on Sunday, which was the only other time we would have been in Tokyo heading to Haneda Airport.  From Tokyo Station, the walk was a mere 10 minutes, and check-in was easy. Upon arrival at the front desk, a bell-hop took our bags while we checked in and then proceeded to lead us to our room. Once at our room, we were given a tour of all the amenities within such as the electric blinds on the window overlooking the palace, the blinds to the glass window into the bathroom, location of outlets (international standard, so no need to carry the bulky converters), and finally asked what time we would like turn-down service.  After a 12hr flight, the room was more than enough to get us back ito energetic vacation mode. The only problem was that the room was so nice, it was difficult for us to get ourselves out of the hotel to enjoy the few hours we had in Tokyo. Thus is always the dilemma of having such a wonderful room.

Extremely beautiful hotel overlooking the imperial palace. Beautiful lounge with high ceilings and antique carved furniture. Breakfast is also delicious. Room ..second time round was very good.. make sure you ask for a room facing the imperial palace plus with balcony and 28 metres ... first room we had was two small .. but this time on 10th floor and it is much nicer. First class hotel. As a tip in basement there is a company that does massages .. half the price of hotel!!

This is my first time to this hotel and after being in few hotels in the past 15 years for business trips I can say that this is the best one it was renovated and you should take the club rooms in a high floor to enjoy the view in addition to the nice location which is close to this new renovated part of Tokyo downtown

We stayed here for a week in early April. Everything is perfect , room with a view, airy lobby and the wonderful staff especially the concierge teamThe hotel is a stone throw away from the Imperial Palace and about 15 minutes to the Tokyo Station. It's in the business district therefore there is not much going on after office hour. However the hotel is connected to the Palace Building next door through the basement which have a couple of restaurants and a convenient store if you don't want to venture out too far. Ginza is 20 minutes walk away only.The restaurants in the hotel are all of high standard and with a price to match, but worth every penny. If you want luxury in Tokyo, this is it.

We stayed on the club floor and were upgraded to a balcony room with a wonderful view. I can not praise enough everything about the hotel. The concierge were particularly amazing, offering us help before, during and after our stay. I can't wait to go back there.

Went on a 4 days business trip to Tokyo, left for a day to Osaka and stayed another day before returning back home.It was the 2nd time and it was fantastic once again. Thank you so much to the entire Team for the great service provided. From the arrival experience, service at the fantaI stick Club Lounge, dinner in two of their restaurants ... it was a superb experience and I can only highly recommend the hotel for Leisure or Business Travellers.As I enjoy to wind down by exercising, the run around the Palace (around 5km) is superb. You just step out of the hotel and enjoy a run with many others.

Given its location near the Imperial Palace, Palace Hotel Tokyo imbues all the finery and finest service one would associate with a king and queen. The hotel looks unassuming from the outside but once you step into its lobby, let your senses be luxuriated with fine furnishing and beautiful touches. Service is impeccable and so is the food here. Don't forget to hit the spa, it's magic!

Our family of four stayed for three nights at the Palace Hotel Tokyo in April 2016. We had a Grand Deluxe Twin room (#1225), which was a corner suite, with two large beds, a large bathroom, lots of storage space, and spectacular views of both the Imperial Palace and the fountains from nearby Wadakura Park. Upon arrival, there were night-shirts laid out for all four of us, and slippers were also available - which was a very nice touch after a long-day travelling and hauling luggage from Tokyo Station. In the end, our eldest daughter (7 years old) decided that her slippers were too large, and that she would prefer the smaller sized pair. One quiet word to the front desk, and it was all sorted. Our youngest had Palace Hotel pyjamas, and was in her element when back in the room each evening.I have stayed here previously for business, and know the standards to be very high. However, staying with family made me appreciate this even further: the buffet breakfast was superb, with a wide range of choices for all palates, fresh fruit, made-to-order items if you wanted, and attentive (but not intrusive) service whilst everyone was seated. The Evian Spa was a fantastic little oasis - families are welcome to use the pool from 9-5, so best to make use of it before you start your day of exploring (it was essentially deserted when we used it mid-week).We dined elsewhere, but the restaurants looked to offer very good options, and there is also a small shopping arcade directly below the hotel, where you can also dine (more cheaply, of course!). That mall also has a 7-Eleven, with an ATM that will take foreign cards, so handy to know if you are burning through JPY cash.We got a discounted rate when the Palace Hotel was having a sale, and the full rack-rates will set you back quite a bit. However, in terms of value for money, the Palace Hotel cannot be beaten - the location is superb, the service is second to none, and everything is available to you.The girls didn't want to leave... until they found out that Tokyo Disneyland was our next stop!

The location is perfect. Close to many attractions.Easy access to the metro. Ginza is 2 stations away.Underground shopping arcade.7 to 11 basement floor with many facility.Easy check in.Our rooms are palace view with balcony.Our breakfast was included either to have it in the room or in Resturant.Room service is also good.I like their spa..their therapy knowledgeable.Ask for more keys to us in the elevator..

We enjoyed a delightful two nights at this excellent hotel and wished we could have stayed longer. We dined at their first rate restaurant our first night; it was delicious and the views were priceless! (I went back the next day for photos and asked the waiter for a daylight photo of the view and he obliged me!) The next day, I enjoyed Earl Grey tea on our balcony watching the water play in the ever changing fountains below. Then, before we started sight-seeing in the Ginza and Marunouchi shopping areas we enjoyed a nice luncheon in the 6th floor lounge overlooking the Imperial Palace--again, priceless!!!

The property is beautiful, very well maintained. Attentive staff takes care of your every need. There is a great breakfast buffet, fantastic spa and impecable rooms with all the high-end Japanese amenities. Free high-speed internet. In front of Imperial palace and minutes away from Ginza.

We loved everything about this hotel. Our room was large, wonderful balcony, great bathroom, superb service, excellent breakfast and luxurious sheets and towels. It is everything that a high end hotel should be.

The refurbishment of this grand old Tokyo hotel is incredible. It is now modern, with high quality Armani-like interior design, speckled with Japanese master piece artworks all around. The service is impeccable, with staff wonderfully attentive but not overbearing, reminding me of Le Crillon in Paris - but with a Japanese humble feel. Restaurant choices are possibly best in class, with a wonderful breakfast buffet. The attention to detail is fantastical, mesmorizing, with the use of modern downlights and modern wall sconces, combined. The faucets and fittings in the bathroom are modern, but not overly minimalist. The Evian Spa is breathless, with its pool view and expansive gym. There is no reason to go to the more well known Western five star hotels in Toyko; this is the best. Lastly, the bed is perfectly comfortable, not overly mushy and lush, nor overly solid and hard; it is Zen.

Wonderful breakfast area on main floor. Staff was over the top trying to be helpful and very friendly. Nice workout room. Fantastic location near Palace and great for walking. Also very close o train station. Wonderful breakfast buffet. Other restaurants in hotel were excellent but expensive.

Really nice hotel. Beautiful, big rooms and great service. We enjoyed the location that had very good public transport connections. Quiet area without a lot of "action" in form of bars and restaurants.

We visited this hotel recently and found it to be very convenient for the Palace Gardens and also for Tokyo station.Our room on the 16 th floor had excellent views of the Palace moat and gardens. The room was spacious with a study area.The dining room where we had breakfast and dinner was of a high standard with friendly staff . There was a good choice at the breakfast buffet.

Excellent service. Very clean and comfortable room. Great view from the room. Oasis in Tokyo, and still close to major attractions. A few restaurants in the hotel. Tried a few and all are above expectations. Easy walk to subway and Tokyo train station.Hotel staff friendly and helpful.Will certainly come back next time in Tokyo.

My husband and I stayed here in September 2013 for 3 nights, including our 4th wedding anniversary. We loved Japan and stayed in 5 different hotels, in different towns and cities during our trip but this one was by far the best. The room was beautiful with a gorgeous view. The concierge pointed us in the direction of some wonderful restaurants nearby and also helped us locate some art dealers as we were on the hunt for some specific woodcut prints. The whole staff were amazing - everyone seemed to know our names, even staff that we swear we had never interacted with before (we're still not sure how they did that!)Almost 3 years later and we still rate this stay as the best of any hotel that we have stayed in the world. We loved it!

We stayed in this hotel to attend a friend's wedding. This is the most impressive hotel that I have ever stayed. The service of staff members are beyond description: professional, courteous and friendly. The view from balcony to the emperor's residency is amazingly great. The room itself is the cleanest hotel room that I have ever experienced, not a single black mold could be spotted. The service staff who assisted wedding ceremony are really professional in their services. The night club downstair offers excellent jazz music and drinks. The breakfast service is excellent. Of course, be aware that the price tag is also exceptionally high but it worths.

Staying at the Palace Hotel is an indulgence worth every yen. The service, rooms, facilities, staff are all impeccable and will spoil you for anything else. From the check in, meal service, the quality/newness/cleanliness/luxury of the room furnishings, to the smallest details (like how the hallways are lit and scented) being in the hotel felt like I was constantly being attended to and thought of. We got a room with a balcony. It was very spacious and elegantly appointed, and the view was to die for (we ended up frequently having tea and snacks on the balcony.) I went with my mother (a treat for her 70th birthday) and we also had dinner at Kanesaka, their in house sushi restaurant. It was the best sushi I've had in my life (granted I'm not Japanese, but I'm from LA where the sushi scene is pretty on point.) We also had breakfast every day at their club lounge, where there's an option of a Japanese breakfast in addition to their buffet and egg service, which was well rounded and perfectly prepared - from the on point poached eggs to the freshly squeezed juices. The only less-than-competely-stellar experience I had was when I was emailing with their concierge service before the trip. Compared to the concierge service of the Peninsula where I had a previous reservation, their staff, while completely professional and helpful, was a little slow to respond and not completely fluent/effusive in their suggestions. It's not the place for anyone looking for deal, but if you're seeking a top notch luxury experience, with all the touches of traditional Japanese hospitality and attentiveness, then there really is no other option.

My husband and I stayed one night at the Palace Hotel on our way back from a trip to Korea and Japan. The hotel has been recently redone so the rooms are very up to date. We had a lovely view of the imperial grounds. The room was fine, bathroom open to the main area, but with blinds to offer some privacy and lovely smelling bath amenities. There was tea and coffee maker (nespresso machines only in the higher category rooms).There were a few negatives--- (1) pool and gym only open until 10 p.m. (last sign in at 9 or 9:30) which if you arrive and have jet lag I thought was a bit early (2) the pillows were not down and (3) by 8 p.m., we still had not been given turn down and when we approached the maid who was in the hall to see if she was going to give us turndown, she needed to call (not sure whom) to ask if it was OK, which seemed odd to us (don't all rooms get turndown?).
