All we wanted was a couple of bottle of waters before turning in....The location is great and we would definitely stay at this hotel again. Just thought there were a couple of missteps.
user_name:
MiffysPillowBook
New York City, New York

review_body: Really enjoyed our stay here. Understated elegance at this hotel-all the staff were awesome -- courteous and helpful to the max. Great breakfast and location for getting around. Our first time in Tokyo and glad this was our home base

First trip to Japan and first stop was the Palace Hotel. Having travelled extensively, the Japanese reputation for attention to detail and considered service comes well deserved.The hotel position is great, on a metro stop and a stone's throw from the Imperial Palace. Breakfast is excellent value and in a beautiful setting. Rooms are spacious and extremely well appointed with many extras, including a pair of pyjamas in addition to luxurious robes. The shoe horns are over 1m which means no creasing of pants bending down to get shoes on. Need I say more?A true hotel's test is when they have to face a challenge. And this I had by way of a DHL courier delivery which DHL managed to bungle. No stars to DHL. In the face of DHLs poor delivery, the concierge desk did all they could to correct this. I have to commend the team for their communication and proactive approach to solving my problem. When you're a long way from home and you need a safe pair of hands, it's such a pleasure to find them. My thanks go to the team and Kazushi Kawamura for the attention and care paid.Sad to have to leave and left feeling inspired by your elegant hotel.Thank You!

We had little expectations as the web doesn't do this hotel justice. Fantastic location in safe, quiet location within walking distance to downtown Maranouchi. Subway at your doorstep. Exceptional new.t renovated rooms,gorgeous food and great service. We would return and recommend.

This is a top class hotel in every way. The location is second to none and is in what I think is one of the best areas for a tourist. It sits right outside the Imperial Palace so is surrounded by nature and water. The views from the hotel are incredible. The hotel is large and my only criticism is that the staff seemed to be very impersonal. I did not feel they went out of their way to be gracious but the service was still second to none. The hotel feels very swanky when you walk in and because we had chosen club level we were taken up to club level immediately and given a warm welcome with herbal tea and cakes. This club room has amazing views over the Palace and grounds and is great for afternoon tea as well as glasses of champagne in the evening. The bedrooms are huge with massive beds and electric curtains which open on to a balcony with gorgeous views of the palace and its lovely grounds. I can imagine this being magical during Blossom Season. The lovely shopping area of Ginza is right on the doorstep with only a very short walk and a pleasant walk at that. The hotel has an array of beautiful bars and restaurants where you can also sit outside and people watch. I would definitely return to this fabulous hotel which I rate as the very best in Tokyo. It gets from me 5 star plus plus plus

We stayed here for 4 nights with a 8 years old child. Entire hotel has been renovated and room was very clean. Having a good size of balcony let you enjoy a morning coffee/evening glass of wine with nice view. We used to stay at different hotel in Tokyo but we'll be staying here every year for sure.

Not cheap but for Tokyo this Hotel is fabulous. The staff are excellent and the rooms very very nice. I had a view over the Emperor's Palace and loved it. The Club room was nice and the restaurant and bar very good. A good selection of Scotch rounded off the visit. The Hotel is also close to Tokyo Central Station so pretty handy. Will be back for sure. Just need to save up :)

If only all hotels could reach this excellent standard. Beautiful designed hotel with a fabulous position overlooking Emperors Palace. I have stayed at The Penninsula before and whilst I like the rooms there the reception area is just awful, whilst at The Palace you arrive and feel immediately like you stepped into the most fabulous hotel in the world.We arrived early after a very long flight and looked tired I suspect as the Staff immediately found us an available room which was much appreciated. Excellent beds, linens and French toiletries. Tried the Tempura restaurant which was excellent but was very disappointed with the fish and chips on the menu in the ground floor restaurant. I think the management should take it off the menu it is that bad or get one of the tempura chefs from the top floor to create a light batter. Fabulous little bar also with very nice staff. Look forward to returning in a week when we are there for longer and will try the spa/pool/gym area.

Top notch hotel with every possible amenity and fantastic service. Rooms are luxurious, modern and most with great view of city and imperial grounds. Definitely an international flavor, which may not be appealing so some looking for a more traditional Japanese hotel. Great location. Can't really say anything bad about it, maybe just a little "cold". Pretty much like any other very high end hotel.

I frankly thing this is the best hotel in Tokyo or anywhere else! Stayed on the club level and the attention from the staff in the lounge was fantastic. Breakfast selection, afternoon coffee and pre dinner champaign & cocktails were a big hit with our family. The view from my room was of the Imperial Palace grounds, it was beautiful and serene. And it's perfectly situated to get to any part of the city. They had a very well equipped fitness room, spa and a ( real) lap pool too.Tried multiple dining options in the property also... all well executed albeit pricey..

The Palace Hotel is my favorite hotel of its category in Tokyo.It competes perfectly with any international chain palace, yet feels very Japanese and traditional.I have stayed in many of Tokyo's top hotels, and its a very tough city to compete as hospitality is close to perfect in most places.Tokyo hospitality service is simply amazing, but in addition the Palace has a scenery that is just perfect Japanese elegance. The choice of fabrics, colors ans flowers in all areas renders that perfect balance of high luxury yet subtle Japanese style.The rooms are large, beyond confortable, and very quiet. Bathrooms are heaven.The view and vibe of the Imperial gardens are delightful, gazing from your window or balcony makes you feel very peaceful. Its a great way to start a stay in busy Tokyo.Do not miss the beautiful ceramics shop in the basement.With the usual spa/pool, always on spot for jet lag.And the Japanese breakfast on the terrace of the restaurant is also a must when weather permits.Can't wait to be back.

Having stayed at other other Tokyo hotels such as the Park Hyatt, I am very pleased that we chose the Palace Hotel for our recent 4-day trip to Tokyo. This is a luxury Western-style hotel with a sense of traditional Japanese aesthetics and hospitality (formal, courteous, efficient and always trying to be helpful). We stayed in a room on an executive floor with access to the lounge on Level 19, which was the highlight of the hotel for us. Beautiful and usually quiet, with a magnificent view of the palace and the surrounding gardens, we enjoyed breakfasts, afternoon teas and evening cocktails in the lounge. We returned late on a Sunday night to the hotel (many of the restaurants in Otemachi were already closed), and the staff were able to us seats at the hotel's intimate tempura restaurant, Tatsumi, at the last minute. The hotel is situated right across from the Palace, a relatively quiet spot within walking distance or a quick taxi ride to Tokyo Station and Marunouchi. Otemachi metro station (a major subway station) is directly connected to the hotel lobby via an underground pathway.

I was attending a three-day conference. Lunch was included. The meals were ordered in advance by the conference organizers. My colleague and I had indicated vegetarian meal when we registered. There had been a glitch in the system and our preference was not passed on to the Palace Hotel. The head waiter and his staff (and manager) were totally unhelpful and inflexible. There were clearly many "no shows" by others who had ordered vegetarian dishes, but the Palace Hotel staff would not give us any food. They suggested that we fill up on sweets instead. Afterwards, we told the conference organizers of our experience, and they said they would put our names on the list for the next two days, plus they called the manager and waiter over to please give us the meals that were left over from the "no shows". The same waiter and manager suddenly were polite and full of smiles. We got our meals. This is certainly NOT what you expect from a "luxury" hotel.

As we know Japanese product always been details , but as we stay at room 924 We found the dust behind the toilet door ,We are stay at 5 nights , when we check out Housekeeping was clear the room everyday but the dust having clear . Off course if I call them and point out , they must clear it , but I think I don't to to point out to them , that is that minimum requirement form the hotel management should have someone to check the room how is the staff done

Great location if you want to visit the Imperial Gardens accross the street. Make sure they are open as they do close on Fridays and have private events that close the gardens for other visitors.Hotel room was quiet and service very good. Had a light lunch on the outside terrace which was pleasant in the January sun.We had dinner in the Wadakura restaurant which was nice, only Japanese guests when we were there, however overpriced for what it was.

This was my first visit to Tokyo, and the Palace Hotel was a pleasant surprise. I was expecting cramped quarters in Tokyo, but the room was spacious and very well appointed, with a clean, lots of electrical outlets, a modern bathroom and a fantastic view of the Imperial Garden (with a nice balcony to boot). Public spaces are beautiful and serene and concierges were superb in giving good restaurant advice and securing reservations. They always walked us out to the taxi area and explained to the driver in Japanese where we wished to go. And, as a thoughtful touch, each time we went out, they handed us a pre-printed card with the hotel's name and address (in Japanese, obviously) so that we could hand it to taxi drivers when returning to the hotel. This solved a lot of communication problems.The location is excellent - an easy walk to Tokyo Station and good shopping, as well as the Imperial Garden.A little shopping area in the basement level is very convenient, with a few restaurants, food shops and other small shops carrying small items that make great gifts. All in all, the Palace is a pleasant oasis in a busy city!

Tonight is my last night of my 5 nights stay at this hotel. At USD$600/per night, I struggled a little to rate it perfect. At this price range, I expect things to be very high standard. Lots of attention to details. A few small things bothered me a little. First, the sliding door between the bathroom and the bedroom have lots of dust on the door. Enough dust that you can clearly see it. Second, I took advantage of the free shoe shine and it came back unsatisfactory. Third, the shampoo was awful!!! And lastly my room was not ready at the standard check-in time, and my bed wasn't very comfortable for whatever reason...I wish they could put me on the same floor as my family, which makes things easier since it requires key card to use the elevator. Your key card only gets you to your floor. Besides that, everything else about this place is perfect! Fantastic and friendly staff, great location (in terms of directly above a metro station), great gym and spacious room. The hotel is next to the Palace grounds and it's a little bit on he quiet side of Tokyo. If you were coming from NRT, the NRT Express goes non stop to Tokyo Station and it's a simple 8 minutes walk to the hotel. Very easy to find.Absolutely gorgeous bathroom. Spacious, bright, strong shower and my bath tub right by the window. Very thoughtful controls right by my bed.There are several levels of room and the standard King room is smaller than the twins. If you do not mind two beds, I would pick the twin room for space.Good wifi and free of charge.The concierge team was helpful and the staff is just so welcoming.I think I will stay closer to Ginza or Shinjuku next visit even though I do like this hotel very much.

Exceptional quality hotel.Nice view to the city and the imperial garden.In every corner of the hotel a staff member bowed to us gendly.Huge spaces.TV screen in the bathroom.Beautiful,extra large paintings on the walls and many vases with flowers.

The rooms are beautiful with wonderful views of the palace gardens. The balcony affords a nice perspective of the city skyline. The breakfasts were excellent. The spa was nice but not quite as luxurious as one would expect. The service was exceptional. Everyone is eager to help.
user_name:
NG1058
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: One of the grande dame which was redeveloped a few years back and the tradition is still alive and well. A grand lobby and a view of the palace to match. the rooms are generous in size and the gym is well equipped. The bar is small enough to be cozy which contrasts well with the usual big glitzy bars in other Tokyo 5 stars hotel. will revisit for sure.

The hotel was newly renovated so facility is really great. Nice pool and interior decor are immaculate. Room is quite spacious compared to normal Tokyo hotel room standard. Love the big bath tub that other five stars hotel cannot afford. After all space is really a luxury in dense city like Tokyo. A walk in the morning in the imperial palace is just refreshing. A true five star hotel I would say.

I like hotels with a sense of place, and waking up to a beautiful sunny Tokyo day overlooking the Imperial Palace was definitely a great way to start the trip.  Obviously it would not be fair to compare this to the fabulous Aman (pretty much next door and just awesome), but compared to the Pen, the Pen has bigger space ie large walk in closet, plus a living room area.  If compared to the Mandarin, the Mandarin has fantastic restaurants and just a foodie destination.   But overall I like this hotel, as location is good (5-10 minutes walk from Tokyo station), concierge is really very efficient (especially compared to the Pen where the concierge took a week to reply to pretty much any simple request), definitely the kind of place that you can come back to over and over again.

My husband booked us a club room for 3 nights as a surprise for my birthday in December and I can safely say that the other reviews are spot on. Key highlights:- A modern, extremely well kept and clean hotel which still maintains some elements of traditional Japanese influence- Staff is excellent. Knowledgeable, extremely helpful and friendly. A special mention to Wang Meng & Hani Lee in the Club Lounge who were both superb and are a credit to the hotel- Proximity to and views of the Imperial Palace Gardens which are beautiful (as is the view of Mt. Fuji from the Club Lounge Terrace)- Pianist in the hotel bar gets a big thumbs up (only wish he would have played later in to the evening)- Club Lounge. The breakfast was very good. A relatively limited choice in comparison to some other hotel breakfasts but what came out was quality and taste which is what counts. Nice afternoon tea and the drinks and canapes in the evening were great, particularly the Laurent Perrier champagne - our glasses were never empty!- MTR station under the hotel was a big plus Loved Tokyo and would definitely return to this hotel. Book the Club Lounge if you can!

We spent 4 days in Luxury at The Place Hotel Tokyo and enjoyed the city easily from this location. Odd to say, but the most fantastic bathrooms EVER! However, we had one almost major glitch at the end when we had scheduled the airport transportation with the bell captain desk, but somehow the reservation wasn't followed through. Mr. Nobutaka Harada came to the rescue and immediately resolved the problem. He was wonderful, and my compliments to his ability to cut through the red tape and get us on our way home. Many thanks!

This is a perfect hotel to combine a business and pleasure trip to Tokyo, very comfortable, great views over the city and an ideal location to explore this fascinating city. Great amenities in the bathroom, wonderful room service and very professional staff.

Wonderful staff, wonderful food. We traveled with a six month old baby and we could not fault this hotel.We booked the cheapest room (still quite pricey!!) and it had stunning views of the Imperial Palace and excellent amenities. We were also impressed with the size of the room.Perfect location for a short stopover (or longer) in central Tokyo, handy to both Narita and Haneda airports (we flew in and out of both twice). Very reasonable taxi cost from hotel to Haneda airport. Also, the airport bus (limousine bus) goes straight from the hotel to Narita and is super convenient. Alternatively, Tokyo station is very close and walkable with many transport options to/from both airports. We have a lot of luggage but found this hotel perfect for airport commuting.

Not sure why this hotel gets great ratings. It can only be the staff - all the 'workers' are wonderful. They try very hard.Outside of the staff there are just so many disappointments.Had dinner at the Grand Kitchen. Staff great. Food ordinary. The grilled scallops and shrimp were 2 scallops and barely 2 school prawns. I can bbq better at home. Squid ink risotto not properly cooked. Food and Beverage not good value. Wine by the glass selection was poor.Had breakfast at the nearby Aman Hotel to check it out - it was cheaper than breakfast at the Palace and it was infinitely superior.If you are traveling with a family look out for some odd quirks. If you are under 16 years of age you can only swim in the pool from 9am to 5pm. What international hotel does that anywhere in the world?! I'm yet to find it. We'd punished the kids shopping with the promise of a swim back at the hotel only to be told no swimming at the Evian Spa at 5.30pm. Just a stupid rule for no apparent benefit.Front desk staffer Suzuki looked after us with a translation issue at the Pokemon center. He did a great job and we were very appreciative as did the Spanish guy from Catalan in the foyer. Good people.So what does this point to? A discourse between senior management decisions and the staff perhaps? There are so many issues in room style, design and policy that let the great staff down. Food and beverage overall is disappointing. It represents poor value when compared to Aman Tokyo or Ritz Carlton in Kyoto. I feel sorry for the staff who try hard but are let down by structural issues in the direction of the hotel as a whole.

Located a short walk from Tokyo Station, enabling you to take the train from Narita Airport, is the Palace Hotel, just right next to the Imperial Palace. The train ride took us about an hour from airport to hotel. We had a lovely room with balcony view overlooking a park. The room was quite spacious, with a mini fridge, and a large washroom, with your toilet in a separate room on your left side, a rain shower and large tub to the room on your right and with a large window also overlooking the park. As per standard Japanese service, the toiletries include: shampoo, conditioner, bath gel, body lotion, and bath salts. The room includes 2 free bottles of water.The service is impeccable. Granted, you get amazing service even at a 2 star hotel in Japan. We were greeted with a small fruit plate upon our arrival (featuring those delicious Japanese grapes), and the turndown service was exceptional (they laid out slippers and a nightgown for you, along with a cloth at the side of the bed for you to take off your footwear).Free wifi is included, as well as free breakfast buffet. The buffet is not as large as I have seen at other Japanese hotels, but has enough variety to fill you up. There is a nice gym featuring various cardio (elliptical, treadmill, bike) and weight equipment, along with a small mat area. There is bottled water and towels available in the gym. The gym is available 24/7. The cardio equipment faces onto the Imperial Palace. There is also a small pool on the same floor, which closes at 10pm. I didn’t use the pool, but I took a peek, and there is a lane designated for lane swimming, which I liked. While the pool is small, there is enough room for you to do a few laps. According to the staff there, the pool is 1.5m-2m deep. I had the opportunity to go to their Evian Spa. Great ambiance, and great service. A lot of amenities in the spa, such as a marble sauna, hot bath (similar to an onsen, but not a hot spring), and a relaxation lounge where you can sit in a reclining chair with a magazine and some tea and light snacks (the dried kiwi was delightful!). If you need some spare toiletries, come to the spa: they have hair ties, brushes, combs, headbands and razors.

I spent Christmas break in Japan and spent my last night in Tokyo and stayed at the Palace Hotel. I had stayed here before in 2013, shortly after the hotel had reopened but I had failed to remember how amazing the hotel is. The decor is classic modern - open spaces, lots of natural light, not too cluttered but everything harmoniously working together. The room I had booked had a terrace and while I couldn't fully profit of it because of the January weather (although it was a very mild winter, not warm enough to sit outside) it had some beautiful views to the moat surrounding the Imperial Palace and provided tons of natural light into the room. The room was incredibly spacious for a hotel in Tokyo and again, the decor and furnishings were understated yet very chic. Also, almost everything in the room is automated - for instance the blinds and curtains as well as the privacy blinds for the bathroom. The bathroom has a bathtub, a shower room and two hand basins (including a small TV embedded in the bathroom mirror!) and comes with all the amenities - from bath salts, to hair brushes to mouth wash. I am sure if you lacked any amenities the hotel would be happy to provide them.Breakfast is served in the Grand Kitchen and is buffet style - there was tons of choice and the service was impeccable. I had tried the sushi restaurant Wadakura on a different occasion and would definitely recommend it for a special occasion - while pricey we thoroughly enjoyed our experience and worth every penny (especially since we sat at the counter).I am sad I only stayed one night this time but I will definitely book this hotel for my next trip to Tokyo!

We booked into one of the club rooms (with a balcony) and had a top floor room overlooking the palace gardens. Good views, and the rooms were spacious (for a city hotel). The staff at the hotel were very friendly and keen to help. Breakfast was good, and we ate at the downstairs restaurant which was a change from Japanese food. The hotel is on top of a metro station and a short walk to Tokyo station (either over ground or through an underground passage). My wife also tried the spa and was pleased with the service. As my wife is vegetarian we found some Italian restaurants along the passage towards Tokyo station. We took a taxi from Haneda to the hotel which was about 30 mins. We left via Narita which is a long way out of Tokyo, but the airport bus stops at the hotel, so it is easy to catch.

Great example of Japanese best in class hotel. Great location, right in front of Imperial Palace, beautiful rooms and amazing service. Special mention to the terrace for a breakfast or dinner. Every time I go to Tokyo for work this is my favourite place.

The service is great, the public spaces are wonderful, filled with art and the rooms are spacious with a window to the Imperial park. the location is also great with a straight connection to the subway with some restaurants under the hotel. the hotel's restaurants were also very good. Overall a great experience- highly recommended.

Arrived at 9am and was collected by the hotel driver who was at the hotel forr 930am, my rooom was ready even though check in was 3pm, beauttiful room, great breakfast and room service, hotel was superb and the staff second to none extremely polite and very helpful, would definetly reccomend to others, I have stayed at many 5 star hotels but the palace was a cut above. Connected to subway but be prepared for long walks to platforms as Otemachi is a huge station

Hotel provides you with nothing left and gives the feeling of home. Walking distance to the station. One can walk across the road to the Imperial Palace Gardens and take a walk along Tokyo's Champ Eysee

The rooms were spacious, well equipped and perfectly clean. The welcome, from all staff, was warm and service outstanding. The on-site restaurants were excellent. From the moment I arrived to the moment I left, the Palace was a perfect home from home, and offered a real touch of luxury and class. I would definitely choose this hotel if returning to Tokyo.

The Palace Hotel is a luxurious hotel in a great location - right across from the Imperial Palace - in central Tokyo. The rooms are large and comfortable, including walk-in closets and beautiful, well-appointed bathrooms. It's among the nicer hotels I've had the pleasure of staying at.There are several great restaurants in the hotel building, and direct access to the subway. It's also only two blocks from the Tokyo train station. Taken all together, the Palace Hotel offers a great base of operations for visiting Tokyo.

Spent 2 nights here and just as expected as room was big with luxurious settings and modern. Room service, bell, front staff as well as concierge was great and well trained in English. On top of otemachi station is good for train travels. Two thumbs up!

Service is impeccable. Turn around and you will be helped. Room is beautiful and apparently every room has a view--and the view is wonderful of the Imperial Gardens, and of Marunouchi. Very convenient. A short walk to Tokyo Station, and an entry into Otemachi Station directly from the hotel.I will say that The Park Hyatt feels a bit more serene, but then again the Park Hyatt is a fairly long walk from Shinjuku Station. The location of the Palace means that there seem to be a lot more business people--We are torn. The Palace may be closer to the correct translation. Is that better?The Palace is superb, and the location can't be beat. Will we return here, or to the Park Hyatt?
user_name:
R Victor B
New York City, New York

review_body: We were back in Tokyo for another visit and were stumped for a hotel to stay. I suggested Palace Hotel as I had used this hotel last year for work, and was quite happy with it.We arrived via the Shinkansen at Tokyo Station, and after getting our bearings, we took the surface route out from Marunouchi North Gate. The walk is about three blocks down towards the Tokyo Imperial Palace. We could have walked underground too as this area is well connected, but I found navigation easier on the surface.The entered the rear of the hotel via the side walk that separates the moat from the buildings. Once in the hotel lobby, bell hops offered to take care of our roll-on luggage. Check-in was quick and efficient. English is spoken and the front office staff confirmed that our two luggage had arrived via Ta-Q-bin, and had been deposited in our room.The bell hop then took us up and showed us the functions in our room. The blinds and lights are remotely controlled via a console beside the bed. An extra bed was placed for our young man, and we moved this further up closer to our bed head so that I could place one of the luggage on the table. The room is good sized by western standards and is trimmed in luxury. The carpet still looks new and the cupboards, table tops and seats are well kept. The large cupboard near the main door could fit out large suitcase in it. It also housed the safe, bedroom slippers for three occupants, shoe horn and suit brush. Next to it was a cushioned bench for us to put on our shoes.The bathroom is an open concept. However, sliding doors and mechanically operated blinds ensure privacy for the shy ones. The bathroom has a luxurious feel to it. Lots of mirrors around the single sink with in-built lighting. Polished sand-coloured granite to walk on. A separate bath tub and walk-in rain shower cubicle. The toilet has its own cubicle and is fully automatic, save for the auto seat. Lots of bathroom amenities, soaps, bath gels, shampoo and conditioner are placed around the toilet. A hairdryer is also within reach. Fluffy towels and bathrobes are under the sink. We had a King bed and it was just right. Charging stations can be found beside the bed and on the long table under the TV. A large flat screen TV is hung on the wall. I was disappointed to find that they only had Fox channel for entertainment. Would have expected one or two movie channels for a five-star hotel. There are a couple more English news channels, though.Next to the TV, and in a standalone white cupboard is the liquor cabinet, the assortment of cups, glasses, kettle, snacks and fridge filled with soft drinks and beer, on top of the small bottles of hard liquor. Only the bottled water, tea and coffee is FOC [Free Of Charge], while the rest is chargeable.Free Wifi can be received in the room; it is a one-time connection for the duration of the stay.We had breakfast downstairs in the Grand Kitchen. My wife was impressed with the home-made jams and fresh breads. She was equally impressed by the wet and tasty scrambled eggs; just the way she does it. My son and I loved the ham carving station, smoked salmon, sliced smoked meats, fruits and sausages.We also did some shopping in the basement of the hotel. There is a bath towel shop that sells really soft and luxuriant towels, and a museum-like ceramics shop with a fresh and simple way of displaying its plates, bowls, vases and other ceramics. There is also a 'fish shop' here that specialises in serving fish dishes, but also has some chicken and beef. We had two meals here and quite enjoyed it.I like that the hotel's public toilets also have warm toilet seats, full bidet and flush functionalities and warm water to wash your hands. This hotel knows how to win potential guests over. The concierge team is excellent, particularly Ms Hashitani. She called ahead to the shops {Issey, Super Potato} that we wanted to go to, to make sure they had stocks; then printed the directions for us and/or the cabbie. The hotel also made reservations with Sukiyabashi Jiro on our behalf.The hotel has a perpetual line of taxis waiting for customers, and is also well-served by 5 train lines. There are ample shopping opportunities between the hotel and Tokyo Station.If you are sporty, the hotel's Evian spa has an indoor pool and a well-equipped gym, besides the spa menu. The gym instructors speak English. The hotel was kind enough to let us take a quick shower here before our late night flight. If you are inclined to go for a run, the Imperial Palace run route is quite doable. It is about 5km. Lots of runners run the route in packs or individually. The route is right outside the hotel's front door.We had a very easy-going stay here, which made it very enjoyable. The staff are all well-trained and have lots of initiative. The hotel environment is also very conducive to just chilling and taking it easy; which made it great for our vacation-base.

This is probably our 6th visit in as many years and the experience has always been great. The location with its proximity to the Imperial Palace, Tokyo station, Marunouchi shopping district and Otemachi metro station with 6 different subway lines can't be beat. We also like that it's in an area that feels serene and calm - this is not for you if you are looking to be immersed in the energy and buzz of an area like Shibuya. The hotel has an elegant feel and the rooms are comfortable and warm. The deluxe rooms have a view of the Imperial palace gardens while the larger ones have a balcony that overlook the palace grounds and Marunouchi.There we a good number of high end restaurants in the hotel though we haven't tried most of them given the number of excellent offerings in the city. We can though recommend breakfast at the Grand Kitchen - when weather permits it's lovely to sit out on the outdoor terrace. The indoor seating is also lovely especially if you get a seat next to the fireplace in the winter. You get all the usual items in the buffet spread and the coffee is pretty good. Service is enthusiastic and efficient. The Grand Kitchen is also a cosy spot for evening drinks. For an old fashioned Mad Men type experience, the Royal Bar is highly recommended. It's a small and elegant wood panelled bar on the ground floor where you can still smoke if so inclined. The bartenders are smartly and formally attired as are most of the patrons.For running enthusiasts, the track that around the Imperial Palace is a very popular exercise spot. We have used the hotel gym a couple of times - the equipment is well maintained and of sufficient variety. You also get a view of the palace gardens. And if you have a few hours to spare before your flight, we would recommend a visit to the spa for a tune up.Extra points for remembering we read the FT and having that delivered without us asking.

The hotel hosted a large convention during my 5 day stay and the wait for elevators was interminable. I stayed on the club floor where the food served was a disappointment, stale pastry and a boring selection. The room was comfortable as a 5 star hotel should be, and the hotel is in a good location so it wasn't all negative. In addition, Tokyo 5 star hotels are a bargain compared to the rest of the world

Ask for high floor room overlooking the Imperial Palace grounds to make your stay even more worthwhile. This hotel, among the top in Tokyo, will leave you wanting for more. The upscale Maranauchi District is within walking distance and several blocks away and so is the Ginza District. Travel tip: If you'd rather not pay tons of yens to catch your flight from Narita or Haneda, don't be shy about booking a seat on a bus service for some US$16. Enjoy the Japanese people, their culture and hospitality. There's nothing like it anywhere else.

We stayed here for several nights. Check-in/out was very fast & they escorted us to our room and explained all the features on our arrival. Almost all of their staff speaks English very well. We just loved their staffs for being very polite, gentle & respectful whenever we were dealing with them.The room considers big in size for Tokyo standard, have LCD TV screen & mechanical scale inside the bathroom, very very very comfy bed/pillow and the view from our room is soooooo beautiful. The view that this hotel has to offer is one of the top reason we chose this hotel.There are underground connections to Tokyo subways (Otemachi Station) and the central Tokyo Station is within walking distance. Getting a cab is quite easy too. There are restaurants, florist & grocery shops underneath the hotel. And most importantly, the Imperial Palace and gardens right in front of the door steps literally speaking.Overall, we love their staff, the location & its ambience. They offer one of the best personal experience.

If you are looking for a five star hotel in Tokyo, this is the place! We stayed at a different five star hotel in Tokyo later in our trip and I have to say that the Palace Hotel was hands down a much better experience!Amazing hotel - service was top notch. There was nothing that the staff couldn't handle. We reserved a deluxe room, which was totally worth the price. I never thought I'd write a review raving about a hotel's toilet, but the toilet seat (heated!) was awesome! We also LOVED the Panasonic hairdryer in the room. We felt pampered without having to leave the room. The location is terrific; it's an easy walk to the metro. There is a 7-11 on the same block for anyone looking for an ATM. If you are spending a ton of time like we did to research 5 star hotels in Tokyo, save yourself some time and book the Palace Hotel. We are so glad we stayed at this property!
user_name:
Emma B
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We recently stayed two nights during a four night trip to Tokyo. The check in was warm and friendly. One of the bellmen showed us to our room and explained all the features which was very helpful. The room, as well as the hotel interior, is well designed in a classic style which made it feel a little older but not aged. You'll enjoy taking pictures of the interior. The gym is a good size and was empty when I visited at 6:30 am as was the pool. The changing room by the pool is small and has only one shower so it could get crowded if more than 3 people show up at the same time. The gym and pool attendants were very helpful. The hotel location is perfect if you are interested in visiting the Imperial Palace or grounds. It's also very close to Tokyo station and many train connections including the express train to/from Narita. There are a plethora of restaurants in the office buildings just a 10-15 minute walk nearby. Kitte mall is a good place to shop and has several nice cafes on the first floor and restaurants on the top floor. We had a very nice stay at the Place - worth a splurge for a special occasion but there are better values out there.

This elegant, large hotel has your every need covered. The breakfast buffet is splendid. The location is convenient to the train station and handy for visiting many local sights. Rooms are serene, elegant and quiet. You will probably feel under-dressed.

Even for an Asian born American, Japan is a culture shock. The Palace Hotel Tokyo is a blend of Western Eastern that eases anyone into the intricacies of Japanese culture especially if one arrives at 5 am. The hotel staff apologized for not having a room available at 6 am because it was the morning of a national holiday and after a busy weekend. They also apologized that the spa would not open for another 45 minutes but we were welcomed to shower there when it did open. We decided to start our morning with a walk around the Emperor's palace across the street, with the bellhop providing us with a jogging map. When we returned they apologized that we were few minutes too early to visit the club lounge for a snack. We visited the spa first and decided to go for a morning swim and soak. They rent swimsuits for about five dollars but the bellhop brought our suitcases up to the spa. The spa provides slippers, a shoe bag, lockers and many other amenities. At the expansive indoor pool you are greeted by another staff who asks what you would like to do and are graciously directed to a large rainfall shower to the side. The pool is slightly shorter than the standard American 25 yard lap with wall to wall and ceiling to floor glass views of the park. There is no chemical like chlorine in the water, it is electronically filtered and the pool water tastes like tap water.The gym is well equipped and also has great views. There are cultural differences in tapping control panels so you may need the assistance of staff to learn to operate the treadmill. If you need something do not hesitate to ask, it is likely they have what ever you desire.All these amenities were free of charge because we took advantage of the American Express Fine Hotel program. Given how expensive food is in Japan, you may want to consider this if you are traveling with a growing adolescent boy. The club lounge provides a light multicultural breakfast, afternoon tea and evening drinks and canapés.The rooms are generously sized even by American standards but unfortunately the hotel does not allow more than 3 to a room if your children are above age six. The website gives a good detailed accounting of room amenities but somethings worth mentioning include Japanese pajamas in addition to robes and slippers. The most luxurious rainfall shower head will make you feel a tad bit guilty. Powered curtains are floor to ceiling and wall to wall so you may never realize it is morning. Sensors detect when you enter the room for temperature control and the lights: room may feel warm when you enter but the air conditioning will start to cool the room down quickly. Most of the hotel runs warm for American tastes especially during Cool season.The interiors were renovated in 2012 with dark, modern Asian tones and dark wood. Areas are sectioned by automatic glass partitions which create an incredibly quiet ambiance even in the expansive spaces. The balcony rooms overlooking the moat and garden are definitely worth the extra cost because of the views, since there is little greenery in Tokyo. Our room on the south side had a view of Mt Fuji on a clear morning. This was a free upgrade with Amex program. The club lounge situated on the 19th floor may have views of Mt Fuji on a clear morning if the fog abated. Traveling in Japan remains daunting and making pre travel arrangements to popular destinations like Studio Ghibli was difficult and "sold out" per web but the concierge service was extremely helpful via email obtaining tickets, arranging private tour guides, and recommending signing up on the web for the tour of the Emperor's palace. Our all inclusive package included daily buffet breakfast in the main restaurant. The service was top notch and food selection multicultural. I would definitely try all the different meat offerings since meat in Japan tends to be expensive but also quite different from American meat. The eggs and chicken tasted like free range raised on natural feed. Our son noticed that the yolks were much more orange which is the signature of chickens fed a natural diet. Since our rooms also include a $100 food credit, we mistakenly decide to try "Go" for lunch. Let's just say that one 40 gram mushroom costs $20. We could have done the $90 prix fix seven course lunch for less than what we spent but it was good to choose what we wanted especially if you are trying to stick to a low carb diet. Watching them make the fried garlic rice was entertaining but the extra calories are better saved for dessert. Despite the cost, it was worth the unique cultural experience of having an almost private room with your own personal chef, making art from small pieces of mushrooms, vegetables, beef and prawns. If you like shrimp with the head on, I highly recommend the prawn. The chef carefully carved a single large prawn and sautéed the head to crisp perfection, served with a small side of greens, mushroom and rich butter anchovy sauce. Afterwards you can head to the club lounge and finish feeding your adolescent boy.The hotel offers an all around spa resort experience with impressive Japanese attention to details and service. The English fluency of most of the staff insures a stress free vacation. The Concierge staff's knowledge of accessing events and special tours is well worth the 10 percent surcharge especially since credit cards are still not widely accepted for certain transactions.

This is my favourite hotel in Tokyo. Wonderfully situated for business, shopping (GInza is close by) and for views of the Imperial Palace. Welcoming and helpful staff, large rooms and a cosy lounge for breakfast and snacks

Beautiful hotel from the foyer to the rooms. Everything is spotless and the design & decor are luxurious. Service was great and all the hotel staff were friendly and accommodating. Location is great as its walking distance to Tokyo station.

Really enjoyed our stay. Nice club lounge with helpful staff (although not great on vegetarian food at any time of day, including breakfast) Club rooms are lovely. Beautiful gym. Enjoyed the piano bar downstairs.

The hotel is right next to the Royal garden and the room with a balcony facing the garden also has a view of Tokyo tower (only top). The location is right in the middle of CBD and super convenient to biz travelers. The service is impeccable with a subtle but sophisticated Japanese cultural touch. The lobby, lounge and room are all beautifully designed with a mix of modern and traditional Japanese style. The food quality is also on the top notch. The only thing that I found a bit inconvenient is the power switch in the room. No master key near the bed that allows guests to turn off all the lights immediately. You have to either use the master key near the entrance and then walk through the darkness back to bed or turn off lights one by one. Very rare design default for a hotel at this level. This is the only reason for it to be marked as 'very good' but not 'excellent'. Hope the hotel will be able to find a way to fix it.

This hotel has everything you need for a great city centre hotel. It's utterly professional in every way while maintaining great warmth from all the staff. The room was great, plenty of space and with a lovely view towards the park by the Imperial Palace. There is so little to say except that after a fascinating couple of weeks in Japan, we felt that the standards that had been set throughout our stay were consistent right through to the end with The Palace adding bells and whistles. The only question is - when are we going back?

This hotel is just fantastic! Yes, it's expensive but if you can afford it you'll get a great experience. Customer service is superb! The rooms are big and modern, the bathroom is huge and the whole place is spotless. Great location - less than 10 min walk from Tokyo train station, metro station is accessible from the underground of the hotel and you're located right next to the Imperial Palace.

Fantastic hotel, great rooms, great attention to details, very helpful. This was a great place to start our holiday in Japan, The rooms were big the beds comfortable, brilliant bathroom even has a TV set in the mirror. The hotel is set near to the metro the food is not bad and reasonable priced. We had breakfast and dinner there everyday and the food was very good. It has free wi-fi and fresh bottled water in your room each day Our room was 1635 which had a very nice view over the old palace The gym and pool were very good We would certainly use this hotel again, the staff were friendly and helpful

Large rooms for Tokyo standards, seemingly very newly renovated and spanking clean, including a nice spacious balcony with seriously nice views. Location is excellent with two subway stations nearby, the Royal Palace across the road and walking distance to Ginza (if you like to walk...) and Tokyo Station. Oh the indoor heated 20m lap pool is great. What's not to like. Phenomenal.

I stayed there for two nights. Hotel is located centrally with the imperial palace across the road while numerous shopping and restaurants around. The rooms absolutely fantastic with attention to the smallest details including the pajamas they provided nightly (really unexpected). The room is really nicely furnished and the bathroom is a heaven to relax at. I have nothing to say but fantastic.
user_name:
kghanem
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: It is not only a big and conveniently placed but also a very beautiful hotel with a nice view. It is also one of the hotels which doesn't need refurbishment. It is between the still used imperial palace and financial district named as Marunouchi.

Second time here. Large rooms, well laid out. Excellent air conditioning and black out curtains. Good soundproofing, though not perfect. If you're on a low floor facing the main road and a police car goes by with sirens on, you'll hear it, but that's a rare occurrence in Tokyo. One excellent amenity - wooden shoe trees! However, the Four Seasons close by is almost the same price, and I'd choose that over the Palace Hotel. You get all this plus a seriously luxuriously soft bed and duvet, plus own nespresso machine in the room win.

The hotel is located conveniently near Tokyo station and the Tokyo metro (with a subway station accessible right from the hotel). The room was spacious, trendy, well appointed and comfortable and had everything one could expect, apart from an ironing board and iron in the room. My room had a nice view of the Imperial Palace gardens, and was quiet enough to afford uninterrupted sleep. I loved a few of the little quirks about the room - a traditional tea-pot in the room and Japanese green tea, the glass wall bathroom area, and the high-tech health faucets. The bed was just the right level of firmness for me. I dined at two of the restaurants on-site - the Grand Kitchen restaurant overlooks the Imperial Palace moat, and does a very competent breakfast with both Japanese and western dishes, and their Japanese restaurant, where I had some outstanding sushi, tempura and some excellent sake. Being located across from the Imperial Palace gardens, one is easily able to access it for a walk in the mornings. I found the staff to be warm, helpful and eager to provide information on shopping and transportation. This is definitely worth a repeat stay.

My husband and i recently spend a week at the Palace Hotel ( me for work and him for fun). The staff was extremely helpful and wonderfully pleasant. The facilities are beautiful, and top rate. The pool in the spa was delightful. The top rate restaurants are pricy but there are plenty of restaurants within short walk, infact like of shopping mall of restaurants. A 7/11 and some some restaurants in the bottom floor offer a quick option. Location is in the financial district but close to Train station and subway stop access right in hotel. It was our first time to Tokyo so not much to compare with in the city but excellent experience.

We recently spent 6 nights at the Palace Hotel and had an excellent stay. The hotel is conveniently located in Marunouchi, next to Otemachi station, which has multiples lines running through. It is also close to Tokyo station and overlooks the Imperial Palace. The ambiance is very zen like, Low key, peaceful, but very elegant. Rooms are well appointed and housekeeping was excellent. We stopped by the concierge extensively to help us plan our days, and they were extremely friendly and helpful. Minor suggestion would be that the room service menu should include more Japanese items, which are currently extremely limited.

My wife and I have just returned from a wonderful two week visit to Japan. We had the great pleasure of staying at The Palace for four nights at the beginning of our trip and again at the end of our trip. Simply said, The Palace is outstanding in every way -- comfort, service, quality and location. The hotel is beautiful with modern Japanese design touches that soothe the senses. It is adjacent to large green spaces, just across the grounds of the Imperial Palace. The subway can be accessed without even having to go outside. All of the staff were extremely friendly, helpful and reliable. The concierge staff are incredibly thoughtful and professional. All of their restaurant recommendations were superb. The hotel has a wonderful bar. We were lucky to have a balcony on a high floor with a beautiful view both times, which we enjoyed very much. I could say much more. This was the nicest hotel stay we ever had and we are fortunate to have stayed in many wonderful places. We would not hesitate to return to The Palace or strongly recommend this hotel to friends and family.

My companion and I stayed for 3 nights on the 10th October 2015 at this SPECTACULAR gem of a property. We considered the Imperial Palace Hotel but in the end decided to go for the Palace Hotel as it's much newer and based on all the reviews we have read so far, they have nothing but praise for this noteworthy property.Our first impression upon arrival was that it has "WOW" factor in terms of the location which is very green and the grand lobby entrance. We booked the Club Deluxe Twin room with balcony overlooking the spectacular park. All the amenities were spotlessly clean and located in the right spots, especially electrical sockets.The furnishing in the room is very 'ZEN' without feeling spartan. The balcony is the pièce de ré·sis·tance as it is very spacious and could easily sit 6 people or more; rarity in Tokyo hotels. The concierge and front desk were extremely efficient when a request was made. It was not just the efficiency that impressed us but the level of courtesy extended to us. Apart from explaining some directions we were inquiring about, one of the nice ladies from concierge even escorted us to the hotel's taxi stand and explained to the driver where we were headed. That was service well and beyond our expectations. Our summation is that this property have invested heavily in training their staff.The Club Lounge located high in the building is well presented and maintained. The art decor furniture is new and comfortable and the views from the lounge overlooking the park are to die for. It also afforded an outside garden area but nobody used it on this occasion as it was rather windy and the weather was not so conducive. The staff were extremely helpful and nothing was too much to ask for. On a more critical note, we found the breakfast selection in the Club Lounge to be quite disappointing and without any variations everyday in terms of variety. One can also order cooked meals but there was no menu to show what is available. It would be great if they can introduce a little menu on the table so that the guests know what options are available apart from the buffet spread. Generally we found the selection of food to be small even for the cocktail hour and afternoon tea.I was surprised that Club Floors guests were charged 300 Yen for 15 minutes of internet usage on their PC and 150 yen to print a sheet of paper in color. That is a highly unusual practice. I have never come across this anomaly with all the hotels I have stayed in. Whenever one chooses the club floor, one automatically assumes all these facilities are complimentary. Perhaps they need to consider changing it. Most people use the free wifi anyway, so I see no point in making the guests feel awkward in this area.We ate twice at the Grand Kitchen for dinner. The ambiance is reminiscent of a French/Italian eatery. The great height of the ceiling made it feel very opulent and grand with several different and nice seating areas to choose from. We particularly love the huge and long fireplace. The only disappointment was that the food was quite bland and tasteless. We had the set menu which cost around 7600 plus yen per person. My Cesare Salad, Mushroom Soup and Fish main course were terribly disappointing in terms of taste and presentation. My companion also made the same observation with his food selection. On the second evening we ordered from the ala carte menu and the duck confit was a huge improvement over the previous evening. However the staff were extremely well trained and helpful to us on both evenings.Having said that, these are only 3 very small 'improvements' I would suggest. This hotel is as perfect as a hotel can be. I would definitely not hesitate to stay there on my next visit and highly recommend it to anyone.

Just stay in a Club Deluxe King with Balcony for 3 nights. Actually I just check out this morning. This is my first time staying at Palace Hotel Tokyo. The room interior is exactly what you see on their website. The view from the balcony is just amazing. There is no other places in Tokyo that could offer such an unobstructed view of the Imperial Palace. But what I enjoy most is the Club Lounge. It was great relief to have a nice cool drink after a long drive from Narita Airport to Central Tokyo. My wife love the afternoon tea and the evening cocktail very much. The staff were wonderful. One more benefit for staying at the Club floor is that parking is complimentary. Yes its free to park your car in the centre of Tokyo!The location can be a disadvantage if JR is your main mode of transportation. I tried to walk to Tokyo station through the underground tunnels. This is not something enjoyable. However if you use the Metro then that will be another story because the hotel is directly connected to Otemachi station which is served by 6 Metro lines. I usually stay at another hotel in Yurakucho. But now I have changed my mind and will stay at Palace Hotel Tokyo in my coming trips.

This was our first time to stay at Palace Hotel Tokyo. We spent 2 nights there. The location is superb. Close proximity to Tokyo Station and Ginza, yet away from the crowds. The lobby is excellently appointed. Staffs were friendly and helpful. Communication by email prior to our arrival was smooth and informative. We had asked for the hotel to assist with tour bookings and were given good suggestions on how to avoid holiday traffic and tour operator recommendations. We had a room with balcony so it felt even more spacious. Waking up to the view of the Imperial garden was an excellent way to start the morning. Abundance of restaurant choices within the hotel. Could have easily just stayed in and enjoy the restaurants and amenities offered by the hotel and call it a vacation.

Spent 5 days at the Palace Hotel Tokyo and am satisfied with every aspect of the hotel. The location is superb (few minutes away from Otemachi station, walkable distance to the Tokyo station where the JR Line and Narita Express are and close enough to Ginza where many good restaurants are), the room is spacious and well-decorated (a little plus for me is the Anne Semonin toiletries they use!) and the view is just one-of-a-kind.  A notable mention must also be given to the Concierge Team, which helpfully and efficiently dealt with my (many) restaurant reservation requests, some of which were pretty last minute. I would also recommend the Royal Bar at the lobby which serves very good cocktails. Will definitely stay at the Palace Hotel Tokyo again the next time I am in Tokyo!

What can I say that has not already been said, but I will go ahead anyway. We stayed here at the beginning and end of our trip to Japan. Our balcony room was comfortable with a great bathroom. The service was exemplary. I would be hard put to name a hotel in the United States where the service even approaches the care and concern we received here. We ate at the sushi restaurant-very fresh and at the Chinese restaurant at the end-a lovely setting and unusually delicious food. We would highly recommend this hotel.

One of us has been traveling around the world for over 50 years and stayed in many world class properties . This hotel is definitely one of them! Beautiful architecture overlooking the Emperor's Palace walls. Superior service, delicious food, outstanding bar. If you're staying in Tokyo this is the hotel to stay at. You will be treated royally. Try the hotel's sushi restaurant for lunch. An outstanding meal at a very fair price.
user_name:
Lauren L
Los Angeles, California, United States

review_body: I spent 4 nights at Palace Hotel Tokyo on a business trip in a Deluxe King with Balcony. The rooms were spacious, functional and well decorated, with twice daily service. The bathroom was as big as some hotel rooms, stocked with every amenity possible and had THE best shower. The balcony had beautiful views of the skyline and surrounding parks. I stayed on a club lounge rate one night and recommend if you can book. The breakfast and evening service were both excellent.Service was top notch across the board - club, front desk, valet, bell desk, restaurant, bars. Not one interaction that wasn't pleasant and helpful.Location was ideal for my needs. Its certainly a business area with lots of corporate towers, but I was able to find good bars/restaurants in immediate area. Easy walk to Tokyo Station which is helpful for Narita Express train and exploration. Plus, there was a nice trail/path around the Imperial Palace grounds for early morning runs to combat jet lag. I highly recommend this property.

We stayed at the hotel Sep 20-23. It was a long weekend in Japan and almost every hotel was sold out in Tokyo and the rooms were crazily expensive. We were really glad that we were able to reserve a room thru booking.com at a great rate. When we travel, we usually book our room through the hotel directly because we've heard horror stories about when you book through a third party website, mostly likely you will get the worst room and service. However this was not the case at the Palace Hotel Tokyo. From the moment we checked in, everyone that we encountered was extremely friendly and helpful. The room is a really good size with a gorgeous bathroom. I usually prefer double sinks as I don't like sharing with my husband but I didn't have any problem with the one sink in the bathroom as there are plenty counter space. The water pressure in shower is AWESOME!!! Everything in the room is highly functional and well thought out and nothing beats having a view of the Imperial Palace right outside of your window.We also love the location of the hotel. The surroundings is beautiful. It is VERY close to Tokyo station and Marunouchi area is great for shopping and has good restaurants. The hotel has direct access to the subway downstairs (Ometachi Line and Tokyo Station) but if you arrive by NEX and it's not raining or snowing outside, a better option will be to exit Tokyo Station and then walk 2 minutes on the street rather than taking the stairs up and down in the station.We really enjoyed our stay at the Palace Hotel Tokyo and we will definitely be back!

The moment you step out of your taxi at this hotel you are greeted with smiles and bows wherever you go. Staff are incredibly kind and helpful and really go the extra mile . The hotel has amazing art and a lovely view of The Imperial Palace gardens . These gardens are also lovely to walk through or run around .The rooms are modern and well equipped with slippers, gowns , pajamas and toiletries galore . They are cleaned and kept immaculately . The hotel has many restaurants yo choose from; a shopping arcade and is right near the metro and the main station.You will not be disappointed .
user_name:
Amber D
Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: I stayed in club room with balcony in palace hotel Tokyo from 16-20 Sep. Staffs service are excellent; especially the hotel car driver is very friendly and this morning he told me that my flight will be departed half an hour later. What a warm & personal tips!About food, buffet breakfast with a variety of choices that is fit. The chef showed his wonderful skill for my Teppanyaki dinner that I enjoyed it very much.I highly recommended this hotel & will definitely stayed in this hotel again.

You should stay a few days at the Palace Hotel. The most fundamental requirement if a hotel room is the bed. Here they are sublime. The best cotton sheets on the softest mattresses support the lightest duvets ensuring a deep and dreamless repose. The staff are unobtrusively helpful and combine Japanese manners with Western knowledge. Note the outstanding contemporary art that graces the public areas of the hotel. Any room above the second floor overlooks the Emperor's garden ensuring wide panoramic views of downtown Tokyo. It is close to the main Tokyo Railway station and the outstandingly restored original Mitsubishi building. A must stay hotel.

If Waking up each day overlooking the Imperial Palace Gardens is not enough, having breakfast next to a moat surrounding the Imperial Palace (with Swans and Carp for company) you sometimes forget you're only a few blocks from Tokyo Train Station. This hotel and its location are serene, so chilled yet has impeccable standards of service and the highest levels of hospitality. This place is great. Ichiban.

The Palace is a wonderful hotel, I cannot fault it. An oasis of calm in a crazy city. The staff are first class and nothing is too much trouble. We had a balcony room on the 21st floor which had a terrific view of the Imperial Palace Gardens.The Club Lounge is worth paying extra for, breakfast was excellent and we found ourselves there for afternoon tea and sometimes for drinks in the evening.We now wouldn't stay anywhere else in Tokyo we enjoyed our stay so much.

As to be expected, service from the check-in to breakfast and queries for the concierge were excellently met - for what I could experience during a stay for work meetings. Breakfast at the Grand Kitchen was a treat with the lovely view of the moat surrounding the gardens so try to get a table from which you can enjoy it. Besides the view, having your selected breads toasted in their wood-burning oven was another treat. I couldn't get enough of their raisin bread! Weather permitting, a walk around the hotel makes for a nice way to get acquainted with the area.

The Palace was a perfect hotel for our stay in Tokyo. Great location on the grounds of the imperial palace and within walking distance of Maranouchi station. Service was impeccable, efficient and non-intrusive. The room was beautiful, comfortable and had a lovely view of the palace grounds. The common areas were stylish with fabulous floral arrangements and artwork. There is nothing that is not exceptional at this hotel, including value for the price. You will be pleased with you stay at the palace.

I was going to go to the Peninsula but the Palace concierge was much more helpful with restaurant reservations and so I opted to stay here. The rooms overlook the palace grounds and it's convenient for visiting the palace grounds early in the morning before the heat and crowds take over. However you cannot get into the courtyard until 9am. There is a jogging route around the palace grounds if you're a runner. The rooms are typical for 5 star hotel with automated curtains/shades. There is separate shower and tub. The gym is small but empty the few times I visited. The breakfast buffet is extensive with a good selection of western and japanese items. There is seating available outside. I really loved this hotel from the artwork in the lobby to the rooms. While not as opulent as the Mandarin Oriental, the price is better.

While sightseeing in downtown Tokyo we walked into this hotel & took the elevator to the top floor restaurant. The food was delicious as was the presentation & service. The dividers between tables consisted of strings of mini twinkling lights. As the sun set we were afforded spectacular views of the city at night. Eating delicious Japanese cuisine, drinking wine & gazing out at the Tokyo skyline was very romantic. Definitely one of the highlights of our visit to Tokyo!

We stayed in Tokyo some years ago, but it was in a suburb, so this time we decided we wanted to be in the centre. The Palace Hotel is not cheap, but it is well worthwhile. It is in front of the Imperial Palace, a few minutes walk from the main Tokyo railway station and close to some good shopping in Marunouchi and not far from Ginza. The hotel is modern and very stylish. The rooms are spacious and have large bathrooms, with both a bath and a shower. The service was extremely attentive and the breakfast was great. On top of that it has a good pool, which in the evening we had to ourselves.

The friendliest and most helpful staff. Congierge Mr. Hoshino Yuichi found and arranged an appointment at the art gallery where we could purchase some the art we admired in the hotel. Delicious food, beautiful decor, plus the superb staff made for a wonderful 3 days.

This hotel was amazing, we stayed 4 nights at the beginning of our Japan adventure at The Palace. The location was perfect, 5 mins walk from Tokyo station and our room overlooked the Imperial Palace and surrounding gardens. The breakfast and service of the staff was exceptional. Can't wait to return to this amazing hotel.

At the end of two weeks in Japan travelling through a big heat wave - we were desperate for some western indulgence. My two criteria were to have an amazing buffet breakfast and a pool. This place ticked both my wishes. Firstly the buffet breakfast is amazing and especially for its western style offerings which included a egg station ; omelettes, poached, fried whatever you like, smoothie/juice bar, pastry and breads, waffles etc and inclusive coffee from the coffee machines. The only thing I had wished for was a pancake or crepe station and possibly having chai lattes (Melbourne style) but you can't have everything.Secondly the pool was slightly disappointing especially as I was dreamed of splashing in cool waters and instead it was 35 degrees, so no swim for me unfortunately, but my husband did use it once and said the view from the indoor pool was special.The rest of the hotel is pretty lovely, the lobby smells divine all the time, and there are comfy couch areas to sit if you need a break. There are water bottles on leaving which was handy in 35 degree heat and of course 2 free bottles each day in your room. There are always 5-10 people greeting or farewelling you as you walk through the lobby which can be a little annoying and I wonder what these people are meant to do. As tourists we did feel a little out of place when dressed casually and heading out to see tokyo as it is largely a business orientated hotel. But our money is as good as anyone else's so we didn't let it bother us. The room we had was pretty special with a balcony with spectacular views by day and night, two large single beds and a bathroom that could be closed off or open with bath, separate rain shower.The concierge and reception speak impeccable english and helped us with a few recommendations. Even booking a Sumo training training tour on our last day - which by the way was unreal.Room service was good and one day not feeling like heading back out for dinner we got a burger and pasta which were a good as any mid-range restaurant back home.Handy location to metro and a 7-eleven in the base of the building and various shopping malls - mostly underground. A good find was Serafino the pizza and pasta place - handy after several crazings for western food.

This hotel is simply amazing. It is a beautifully decorated spotless property. The service form the staff is some of the best in the world. I stayed with access to the club lounge. This is worth the upgrade as the personal service there is exceptional. It also offers a very nice waiter service cocktail hour.

Stayed here with the extended family. A stone's throw away from Ginza, and our room had a glimpse of the Palace grounds. Perfect balance of urban and garden landscape. Perfect for those who jogs too, since it is located right next to the Palace grounds, a great jogging route in the heart of the city. Staff are great and very helpful with everything you might need. Rooms are on the larger scale comparing to other hotels in Japan, and great amenities too. Breakfast spread is limited, but everything they serve is delicious.

I stayed here during a business trip and would say that this really exemplifies the elegant and classy hotel, with almost perfect service. The staff who I dealt with were very professional and highly efficient. My room was a decent size, well-furnished and very clean and was very tastefully furnished - no excess and pointless "luxury", just very tasteful and elegant. The views over the Imperial palace were excellent and the location really convenient for the central business district. The ambience was international, but with a distinctively Japanese flavour, this was certainly not one of those hotels where "you could be anywhere in the world". This certainly isn't a cheap place to stay, and my favourable impression was doubtless supported by the fact that I wasn't paying my own bill, but it was a hotel that I would very highly recommend.

We stayed here for 4 nights in the height of a very hot summer and had a great stay. The rooms are very comfortable and the views over the Imperial Palace spectacular. The service was some of the best I have experienced - really attentive and polite, and the location was also very convenient as the hotel has a direct connection to Otemachi subway station which has connections to several subway lines. It was a pleasure to stay here and we will definitely be coming back next time we are in Tokyo.

My wife and I stayed at the palace hotel for 4 nights in a balcony room.We booked through booking.com as directed from here. I always double check the hotel directly and they said there was no availability. When I checked the following day there was availability and it was cheaper than through booking.com. When I contacted booking.com for their price match guarantee the direct website was displaying it as full again. My point is to check with the hotel a few times and you may be rewarded with a cheaper rate.The hotel was very nice, the staff were very friendly. We used the concierge for a few things (including them setting up a sumo training viewing) and they were very good. The tour they sent us on was very enjoyable.The room was clean and the bathroom / bedroom were very spacious. The TV also had some English stations which most hotels seem to have none.The Buffett breakfast was full with a variety of options. They had good coffee, nice hot and cold selections which meet western and Japanese cuisines, nice bread/pastry section. The staff are constantly floating around and offering help.The location is great, the subway station at the basement of the hotel connects to three train lines and therefore you can easily get to all locations. It's also very close to Tokyo station.I highly recommend this hotel.

The hotel was reached from Haneda airport within 30min by Taxi. The hall is huge and the receptionist very friendly. Improvement could be done if the people would speak proper english at the front desk.. The rooms were ok, but quite pricy for the size I got. Well as Tokyo is very expensive I will have to take it

This hotel is fantastic. It comes with a 24 hours gym and beautiful and new interiors.Only 2 drawback, the nearest food outlet is about 15mins walk away, and the internet is not stable in my room.Other than that, I would rate it as excellent.

Second stay here and to me it's the best hotel in Tokyo with fantastic rooms (love the balconies), perfect location, great restaurant options, delicious breakfast and really nice service. Shops in basement are excellent for gifts. The only thing I don't like is the bar although the drinks are very good.
user_name:
intrepidgirlLondon
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel is located literally across the imperial palace and it is surrounded by a lake. The hotel has a direct access to the subway, so it is very convenient if you are using that method of transportation (taxis are expensive: $15 for a 5-7 minutes drive)The property is great, beautifully decorated, excellent food options and it has 2 very comfortable bars. One of them is located in the 6th floor with beautiful views.The rooms are very nice, spacious bathrooms and very comfortable bed and pillows. No coffee machine though.The swimming pool is ok, but it is not really a nice nor inviting area. It's ok if you want to get wet i guess.The concierge service is great. The spend a while helping me with directions and restaurant reservations.

You only need a word to describe this hotel : perfect. It is a great place to stay I Tokyo. The location is great with a lot of shops and restaurants at walking distance. Rooms are spacious and clean. Chose one with balcony for the amzazing view. A good breakfast with buffet. A very nice gym and pool. What else can you ask for?

I have been coming regularly to Tokyo on business for 20 years thus a long time guest at the Palace Hotel. I started coming at the "Old" PH and returned after the rebuilding was finished in 2012. . . the service level is 2nd to none, the hospitality of the staff is amazing and its like coming home whenever I check-in. I have never had a request that was not accommodated without any concern or worry. . . even a lost heel of a shoe 45 minutes before my next meeting was rush handled by the staff at cost only. . . .cost wise its on the high end of prices, but its worth the visit.

Very nice hotel. Good location, large nicely-designed rooms, spotlessly clean. An excellent hotel for business but would also be a very nice play to stay if you are visiting for pleasure.I would particularly like to thank the staff at reception, who really went out of their way to help make my stay a pleasant and memorable one.One small suggestion would be to give guests the options to not have their towels changed automatically (mine were changed several times a day), and to provide different slippers (the ones provided were a strange synthetic material)

This is a new hotel that was open 3 years ago and located just in front of the Imperial Gardens and Emperor's Palace. Rooms are big and very clean with all the amenities of a 5* hotel. There are several excellent restaurants within the property. The Business Lounge is situated on the 19th floor and offers all the services necessary.

I guess this place is pricey for a reason. You're paying for its worth. The room was of pretty reasonable size, bathroom was big with a nice bathtub. The water pressure is one of the BEST I've had in any hotels (I still miss it lol). The staff service was excellent, they're forever smiling, attentive and make sure you feel welcomed. Truly 5 star service. It's about 5-8 mins walk to the Otemachi metro station via an under passage or maybe 10-12 mins walk to the JR Tokyo station. I would say however if you are arriving into Tokyo JR station with luggage then the walk to the hotel might be a bit demanding for some. I would recommend taking a taxi which would probably only cost you the basic meter fare of 730yen. Trust the other reviews when they said breakfast is not that good. I had room service for breakfast one morning and was quite disappointed at the quality. I stayed in the room that doesn't have a balcony, even though they say you get the 'palace view' you're really facing it at such a strange angle that there's barely any 'view'. I read other reviews highly recommending paying extra for a room with balcony or ask for a room on higher floor, I completely agree with both. Due to flight reasons I was delayed for a day and end up having to stay one more night after I've already checked out of my old room. I was given a room 38 on a slightly higher floor but was a bit disappointed that this room is actually quite a bit smaller than the rest of the rooms of the same type (all under the same price tag of course). I guess for others who's there for the first time they may not realize the difference but I've just stayed in another room for the past 5 nights so it was a rather big difference to me. I just think if the hotel is charging every one of these rooms at the same price there shouldn't be one that's probably 10-20% smaller than the rest.. But having said that, the 'smaller room' is already above your average hotel room size in Japan and I would still highly recommend this hotel to anyone.

I have been blown away with this hotel. In the very impressive Japanese way, every single detail has been thought out in the design and service at this beautiful hotel. Be sure to read up on the artwork in the hotel in the coffee table book in your room and take the time to walk around and appreciate the art. Some gorgeous work.
