I came to Tokyo for a business trip and for the business leg stayed in a super efficient little inn in Yokohama. Being my first time to Japan I thought I would indulge myself for the weekend I added to my trip to see a little of Tokyo. Selecting this hotel was ideal as you are located right next to the Imperial Palace and you feel like you are in a Palace. Overlooking the Imperial Palace Gardens, you can walk out the door and stroll or take the jogging trail right around the Palace admiring it's beauty. The jogging trail is 5.3kms (3.3 miles) round trip. Be sure to jog anti-clockwise to go with the flow. Alternatively there is a shorter course and walking tours of the Palace itself you can take. It really is a green oasis in a big city. There is a Tokyo metro station accessible from an escalator in the Palace Hotel, making it easy to get around. Tokyo jr Station to catch the bullet train to and from the hotel to the airport or further out is only an 8 minute walk. I had a big suitcase and the hotel said it is fine to catch a taxi that short distance too. Just have cash though as it really is a short distance. Maps provided by the concierge and their advice on where to go and what to do is really valuable. If you want to do the fish market tour and sushi making lesson though, book in advance and note that the market is closed on Sunday. Was bummed I missed out on this experience. Staying in a Club Room I had access to the Club Lounge and the benefits are extensive. The breakfast, afternoon tea, cocktail hours - food and beverages and service are exceptional. Being a wine lover it can be a little difficult to get a really nice glass of wine at a lot of the casual restaurants around town, so to come back to the hotel after a day out and about and be offered up a really beautiful, bottomless glass of wine in the Club Lounge, alongside delicious canapés, was heavenly. If you are a light eater you really wouldn't need dinner after cocktail hour which runs from 5.30pm to 8pm. Booking a Club Room is worth every cent. The amenities in the room are top notch. you feel like you are in a luxury spa in your bathroom. The language barrier can be a challenge in many places so to have a hotel team that speak English really well is invaluable in helping you prepare and navigate the rest of your activities. As a female travelling on my own I felt so comfortable and well looked after here. Could not praise The Palace Hotel enough.

It's a near perfect hotel situated a bit far from the main shopping area (about 15 USD in taxi). It offers great service, food is also good in each of its many restaurants and bars. Stuff is very friendly. We will return
user_name:
ab2030
Sant Andreu de Llavaneres, Spain

review_body: The three of us stayed at Palace Hotel for 3 days and had no complaints. Rooms are comfortable and clean. The concierge service is impeccable with the greatest amount of attention to detail, we made numerous changes to our itinerary but they were ever helpful and accommodating.

Second stay at this hotel. I was in a deluxe room #1421 last September. I loved that room mainly because of the 3 tv's. I was upgraded because I booked thru visa signature and also got a balcony. This past June, I booked a club room #1833. I requested a room on the same floor as the lounge, but that request could not be granted.This stay was just as good , but my only disappointment is breakfast can only be taken in the lounge. I was told there is an additional charge for the buffet at the Grand Kitchen. I have stayed at several 5-star hotel club rooms and there is usually a choice of lounge or main restaurant for breakfast. I was really looking forward to the food selections of the lounge, but it seemed to be lacking compared to the Conrad Tokyo. The lounge at the Conrad is much smaller,but has hot food during the cocktail hour and surprisingly ice cream during tea time.. I do not drink, so the value of alcohol is wasted on me. I enjoy club lounges mainly for the food and a nice quiet place to return for a juice or soda after a day out in the city.I also feel it would be nice if they could recognize past guests. They must keep records of past guests and a warm welcome back at check in or a note from the hotel manager would be a nice touch. I booked another stay for September because of a good discount thru Travelocity. The location is ideal for me. If the little things could be improved, it would be perfect.

Tokyo has the best service in the world and this hotel is great even within that context. The breakfast buffet is excellent. And the sushi restaurant and adjacent bar are to die for. This hotel makes even a long tiring business trip tolerable. And the smell...Amazing!

I cannot imagine a better stay anywhere in Tokyo than at this hotel. It's a perfectly wonderful environment that somehow manages to make you feel that you're in a small hotel where the large, friendly and most competent staff has known you for years and takes pleasure in catering to your every move.From the rooms, to the breakfasts, to the views from our oh so comfortable room, it's as good as it gets in hotel land!

My room No. was 821 with comfortable bed, cozy living, spacious bath tab with TV and large balcony, besides the view of green and Tokyo tower. I enjoyed the elegant staying! The beautiful breakfast buffet at the summer breezing terrace of the Grand Kitchen. I enjoyed having a generous breakfast until 10:30am after swimming at Evian Spa. I used the convenient store, Seven Eleven to buy necessities under the hotel. The hotel has 6 restaurants, one is the Michelin French restaurant. If you come to the hotel by subway, C13b exit will be convenient. I would like to recommend tourists and business men to stay at Palace Hotel Tokyo like your home.

Perhaps the best service of any hotel I have ever visited. Very attentive and helpful staff. Impeccable, large rooms. The location is perfect. It's hard to imagine wanting to be anywhere else in Tokyo.
user_name:
rej5175
New York City, New York

review_body: I must admitt after traveling 15 hours, I would have been happy to be anyway but a plane. However, this is jewel of a hotel. It is rather pricey but the showers are to die for. This modern day hotel has all the amenities but a staff that is very knowledgable and willing to help. I would tell anyone to stay regardless of the price.

This is an impressive newly refurbished hotel, with nicely designed and spacious common areas and wonderful comfortable rooms. Staff is very attentive and polite. There are several restaurants and a couple of bars inside the hotel and - having tried 2 restaurants and two bars, they are all recommended. Free wifi a plus. The two areas for improvement are 1) the breakfast: nice location by the Imperial Garden moat, but a desperately small choice of food and not comparable to similar quality hotels (3-4 types of fruit, very limited Asian selection, etc), for the price of the breakfast I would recommend to go and get breakfast somewhere outside 2) might be a small but annoying point: towels and bathrobes would be changed at every use, even twice a day...while obviously that is nice, it is also completely uneccessary and not Eco-friendly, is there was not even an option to not have them changed...

We stayed at the Palace Hotel with our 3 year old. As with can be expected of Japanese hospitality, the service is impeccable with each aspect of our stay looked after with the greatest amount of attention to detail.During check-in we requested a larger room if available - and were pleased to be given this without questions or any extra cost! The room had the most exquisite view of the palace gardens, impeccable in-room bar with compartments containing coffee, tea, crockery, glasses etc of all sorts. A balcony wrapped around the full length of the room, with chairs and a table plus a japanese lantern as a light. We found a stepping stool, kids amenities pack and appropriately sized kids slippers! How thoughtful! We had room service for dinner, and was presented with the most amazing multi-layered bento box with little opening doors each hiding away a special dish. Imagine kaiseki presented in a cabinet! The hotel is located adjacent the palace gardens with little stepping stones and a fountain that we visited every day. The basement of the hotel also has a great bakery where we got our breakfast each morning. The hotel is linked to Otemachi Metro station via an underground tunnel which makes it very convenient to get around. Walk a little further and the tunnel will take you to Tokyo main Station. The hotel may be a bit pricey, but the size of the room and location more than makes up for this. If you can spare the dosh, highly recommend staying here!

Kitchen: very good and very good breakfastStaff: very nice receptionistRooms: I expected a newer room with modern equipment.Hotel restaurant: very good food with interesting views while restaurant rotates so you can look back seating all arounddesign hotel very nice garden, interesting devices mostly entrance to the hotel

Everything is excellent: the location (facing the imperial palace), the staff, the service, the room and its equipment, the breakfast, the view on the gardens and Tokyo station ... Expensive but beautiful.

We travelled in Japan for 9 days staying in 4 different locations.the Palace hotel was by far the highlight. The service is impeccable, nothing is too much trouble and the rooms are spectacular!We had a club room booked so we had access to the Club Lounge which is one of the best ever! Laurent Perrier champagne, quality snacks, breakfast and a lovely view.We will definitely return here if we visit Japan again.

If you want to chill after a busy day in Tokyo : nice quit drinks with a lovely overview on park (with a lot of joggers) on the 6th floor : lounge bar prive. The view is amazing. A large choice of drinks.

I've been coming to Tokyo twice a year for the past 20 years or so and this is definitely my favourite - the only trouble being that it is often full. Accepting that it is now well known and busy, it retains a personal charm and some of the best views in Tokyo, right next to the Palace gardens. Great for business if that's your purpose and you need to be near Marunouchi, but also just 10 minutes or so from Tokyo Station for travel. Breakfast outside by the Palace moat must be one of the more restful and unusual venues in Tokyo.

2 nights in a corner room.Positives: Tokyo hotel with large balcony.?.....YES! And the room is pretty big too. Its not cheap but it was a good experience. The balcony overlooked parts of the imperial gardens which was nice.Negatives: Be prepared for the steep price. Not that near to any convenient store.

I absolutely love this hotel! Everything in this hotel is top quality and the service is immaculate! The staff are forever very helpful. I could not fault this hotel at all. Its great location, literally near the Palace ground, train station, dining and shopping are just a doorstep away. Stayed in their Deluxe room with balcony over looking the Palace ground and towards Ginza for a far. The room is very spacious and the shower pressure is fantastic! Everything is quite convenient as they have shops below the hotel i.e. a 7 eleven, restaurants and bar, massage, laundry, Tully's coffee and souvenir shops etc. There is also a limousine bus from Narita that stops directly at the hotel's doorstep. Of course all these perfection comes with a price! The room rates are on the high side.

I stayed in this hotel for business purposes end April 2015. First of all, I have to say that this a top luxury hotel which, and this is not by causality, belongs to the Leading Hotels of the World group.Location: it is very well located, 3-4 minutes by taxi or 10 minutes walking from Tokyo central station which makes your transfer from Haneda or Narita's airports very easy and confortable if you do it by train. There is an underground station just below the hotel (exit 13B, be aware of that number!) and the Imperial Palace gardens are just across the street.Room: amazing views over the Imperial Palace. Big enough, very well furnished, big open bathroom with both bath and shower. Nice affinities from a well-known French brand. Wifi (included in the business rate of my room) worked well. I missed some more Spanish and French TV stations.Breakfast: just OK. Someone could expect, i.e., fresh orange juice and a bit more of variety both in terms of food and beverages. Moreover, the dining room in the Club Lounge is rather small as well as the tables, some of them can hardly host two guests.Gym and pool: the Gym is big enough and is open 24/24. The in-door swimming pool (Evian Spa) also has amazing views over the Imperial Palace. There is also a small hot-tub. Access to both gym and pool is included in the business' rate.All in all, this 5 stars hotel is outstanding, even if a bit overpriced.

It was the first stay at Palace and I had a high expectation from the previous good reviews. The location is not bad...they have several subway lines nearby. (Distance to Marunouchi line is little over 400m though.) From Tokyo station to the hotel by walking with several luggages was not fun. The room layout is good and the balcony is certainly a good option to enjoy the outside view.After four nights of stay, unpleasant experience at check out left a sour feeling and disappointment due to one staff(Mr. K)'s unprofessional manner. I asked Mai who was helping the check-out if I can accumulate the JMB mileage for the stay. Mr. K abruptly interrupted and ask me if I have my JMB membership card on me. I said I only have the number not the actual card. He insisted the actual JMB card and seemed very reluctant to help and accommodate the guest. (I contacted JAL and the agent said, hotel should have the necessary form for the guest to fill out when they have only the number.) However Mr. K never offered this form nor try to help out the guest. He was rather rude. When I asked his name, he pushed his chest toward me and gestured me to see his name rather than offer his business card. His inappropriate manner destroyed the image of the Palace hotel and I certainly would not go back to this hotel with this kind of check out experience.

The hotel is as good as should be expected from a top luxury hotel. However, having experienced a 7.8 magnitude earthquake today whilst in our room on the 22nd floor and attempting to use the fire exits on the floor, we were disconcerted to find that they were both locked. After 20 minutes of attempts to call reception, we were told that it is Management Policy to control the electric door release mechanism only by the reception desk! One could of course burne or die without any possibility of escape if that is the only form of escape from that height! Several guests complained strongly about this policy which would be illegal in most countries but the concierge maintained that this is the policy of the hotel. Obitor dicta, as they say!

One of the best hotels I have ever stayed in. Wonderful in every way.The hotel is beautiful. Its swimming pool has an amazing view. The breakfast is fantastic, staff very helpful and polite. A truly five star experience!

Beautifully appointed rooms. Immaculate and comfortable. Across from Imperial Palace; close toGinza and rail station. Staff very helpful and friendly. Restaurant needs improvement. Very slow service, average food and expensive.

Opposite the Imperial Gardens, with incredibly attentive service at every step. Excellent ground floor restaurant (busy at breakfast), and French restaurant upstairs. This could be very expensive unless you choose carefully, but not more than top class facilities at home. Plenty of much cheaper eateries nearby, especially if you are happy to "eat local."Rooms great. But be careful which button you push while sitting on the toilet!!!

By far the best big city hotel we have ever stayed in. Arrival, check-in, room, breakfast, concierge -- the service was professional and absolutely flawless. Difficult to see how it could be improved. (We ended up eating out every day/night but if there was one criticism it is the steep prices in the hotel's restaurants, especially compared to other restaurants with visited in Tokyo, which were excellent and cheaper than London/NYC). The design and aesthetic throughout the hotel is beautiful and serene. There is even this really cool scent everywhere, which is so good that they actually sell it. How many hotels smell so good that you want to bottle it and take it home with you? Each morning, we spent 15 minutes with the terrific concierge (whose name I have forgotten, unfortunately) to map out our day -- subway, museums, neighbourhoods, walking tours, shopping, restaurant reservations -- and then were able to email her during the day if our plans changed. Location is terrific -- walk to Imperial Gardens (across the road), Maranouchi, and Ginza. Metro stop below the hotel that takes you pretty much everywhere (although make sure you take the right exit (13b, I think) or you could find yourself miles away from the hotel).

The Palace Hotel in Tokyo is one of the loveliest big city hotels we have ever stayed in. The rooms and bathrooms are large with gorgeous views of the Imperial gardens. Deluxe view rooms have spacious balconies, a rarity in a city hotel. The restaurant in the lobby was outstanding and service throughout was perfect. I would definitely stay here again.
Located just in front of the palace and has beautiful view. A full of kind and gentle staff members.

Located in a corner of the public grounds surrounding the Imperial Palace the hotel offers stunning views of the grounds and the palace itself and Tokyo's skyline. Lobby: subtle, tasteful luxury without the overbearing trappings and scale of other new hotels in Asia. The lobby divides the potentially noisy check-in and concierge areas from the other public areas to enhance the overall guest experience. Rooms: loved it: quality throughout and very nicely decorated with hints of Japanese style in a luxuriously contemporary design. Staff: So many which could have been a little overbearing had it not have been for their politeness, smiles and discrete service. Room was spotless. Bed was huge, possibly a little hard, but good for your back. Location: Generally, great especially for tourists and business guests. There are not too many shops and street side restaurants nearby but a 5 min taxi ride takes your to the heart of Ginza.

I just loved this hotel. We stayed in low season and it was good value for money. The room was big, especially for Japanese standards. Staff very helpful. The restaurants in the hotel were awesome, we ended up doing quite a few meals there, but a good idea to book in advance. Close to imperial gardens, the room had a view facing the gardens. Convenient location close to Tokyo station, you can get to any part of Tokyo and Narita easily from here. Wifi worked superbly throughout our stay.

I can only say we were completely delighted with the hotel. Every aspect was perfect from the moment of arrival. Reception staff are quite amazing in their aptitude to remember guests names - even the bell boy who showed us to our room remembered our names throughout our stay.

First day of our stay, my 3-year old son fell down in the hotel shower place while taking a shower. There was no non-slippery pad provided by the hotel and he slipped down right in front of his dad watching him! He was seriously hit in the back head and bleeding. Hotel staff called ambulance which took us to a nearly hospital for emergency care. Fortunately with God bless, my boy was stable after doctor check up and several stitches on head. After we returned to hotel from hospital, I asked the hotel to bring in the non-slippery pad for the rest of our stay. And that's all the hotel did after this incident. There was no consolation and further checking in on my son's situation. there was certainly no apology. The next day, per our request, we set up a meeting with the housekeeping manager, and gave them the hospital bill (which btw was only a bit more than 1-night cost in this hotel). I thought it's fair that the hotel should take some responsibility for failing to keep guests safe and having flaws in its facility supply. To our greatest surprise, the first response from the hotel after 8 hours consideration was that they refused to take any responsibility and they agreed only to take out 10% service charge as a courtesy. I must say, this was beyond my imagination to have such a cold and arrogant feedback from a Japanese 5-star hotel well-known for its service!!! The next day, as I filed a complaint via my hotel booking agent, the hotel vice general manage met me again and raised his offer a little bit more than 10% service charge. I was very disappointed and angry that they treat this with such an annoying attitude. They made it look like we were exchanging our son's pain for just a little penny money! It's their cold attitude and lack of sympathy hurts us the most. The vice GM did not even bother to give us his name card during our two conversations, which to our knowledge, is extremely disrespectful in Japanese culture. We checked out on the 3rd day and paid our full bill. During the checking out, no staff came up and said any apology words to us. We just left with a heavy heart full of disappointment. This was certainly not the way we want to start our first trip into Tokyo.... Just wonder whether they would care to do the same to non-foreign local visitors.

We stayed here for 5 nights for the cheery blossom season. We were extremely happy with the hotel - felt it was 5* in all aspects but cannot compare it to other hotels as this is the only Tokyo hotel we have stayed in.Room was large and modern with wonderful bathroom - separate extra large shower. Service was top notch - the concierges are worth a special mention - full of helpful information and so friendly. It is worth noting that the hotel was fully booked during our stay however overall service was still at the highest level - also there was never any waiting (to speak to a concierge, at the restaurant, etc). Breakfast was excellent - we had a continental breakfast included but they offered us the full buffet anyway.We had dinner in the main dining room twice and found it to be excellent value for money - great food and reasonably priced (for Tokyo).The location suited us perfectly - right across the road from the Imperial Palace and gardens. The hotel has direct access to about 7 subway lines and is one-stop from Tokyo station but it is in fact faster and easier to walk to Tokyo station.WiFi was included in our rate so I am not sure if it is for all guests - something I consider very important when selected a hotel.

Located in the Marunouchi business area directly across the road from the Imperial Palace grounds. A short walk to Tokyo Central train station and the subway network as well as the hop on hop off bus terminal. There are a number of good cafes and eateries in the vicinity. Much quieter than say the Shibuya or Ginza areas. The hotel and its facilities are first class - not a thing to complain about. Staff were extremely polite and helpful. Definitely a great upmarket Tokyo hotel to stay at whether on business or for pleasure.

We stayed for 5 nights in a very spacious corner room with a spectacular view overseeing the Imperial Garden. The room was impeccably clean and attended by housekeeping with incredible attention to any detail.Front-desk staff and concierge are friendly, knowledgeable and very helpful as expected in a Tokyo 5 star hotel.The location is excellent for walking but also to explore other parts of the city by subway. One of the major subway stations is just a few minutes away from the hotel.We had massages in the hotel spa which were excellent due to the therapist being very knowledgeable. Facilities are beautiful and the atmosphere is very relaxing.

Spending time in Tokyo is always surprising, especially for the size of the rooms. Nothing compared in Palace Hotel Tokyo. The rooms have the international size. The bedroom is amazing and has the best products. The situation is at the top and the staff is totally dedicated to making your stay the best.

The bedrooms are well appointed, comfortable but not to the standard of the ground floor refurb. It doesn't have the X factor of the Mandarin although the location is hard to beat. Service is excellent. Good gym. The views of the Palace are special. It is a great hotel but Tokyo is a Mecca for top hotels and the Palace, while good, doesn't compare with others like the Mandarin.

We spent five nights at this excellent hotel during a recent three week visit to Japan. We splurged on a Club-level room and were more than happy with our choice--it was large, exquisitely clean, very quiet and had a killer view. The hotel's staffers were exceptionally pleasant and efficient. Highly recommended!

We've stayed at many great hotels but I think the Palace Hotel in Tokyo might well beat them all. When we arrived we were greeted at the door, and from our names they linked us to our reservations and simply swept us to the club floor lounge to check in there while our bags were delivered. The staff was incredibly courteous, well versed in English, and everything about our room (Jr suite facing south) was unsurpassed. The restaurant food is also great, both in presentation and in flavor.

The location was probably the most enjoyable feature for our first trip to Tokyo. It allowed us easy access to all the major neighborhoods. Hotel facilities were fitting for a high-end hotel while our room was grand and included a balcony seating area.
user_name:
Amy L
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed on the club floor and found the room spacious,,spectacularly clean with wonderful tea and coffee for the morning. The bed was wonderful. The only thing missing was the view of the Imperial gardens. I had a rather ordinary view of some non descript buildings, but the view from the club room was spectacular. The deep bathtub was appreciated and the amenities are high quality. Club breakfast was quite good, but evening cocktails and canapés a little sparse and the wine selection mediocre.The hotel staff was wonderful and very helpful. I had several requests before I arrived and the concierge answered quickly to my requests and everything was accomplished speedily. The gym is all that you need with good machines and a pool. And location....perfect with major train lines either across the street or very nearby.

We stayed three times in this Hotel in March April 2015. It is situated just opposite the Imperial Palace and its public gardens. The location is superb .The rooms are very pleasant and have very good views . A room with a balcony adds a lot to the experience. The staff and the management are very helpful , the food and beverages are good as are the bars and restaurants. The Hotel was very accommodating about an early check in .A roof top or upper floor restaurant and bar accessible to all Hotel guests would add a lot

I have stayed at the palace Hotel probably 25 times in the past 15 years. As a women traveling alone for business I have lots of safety and work requirements 1) feel safe in building and room 2) decent hair dryer and bathroom extras (like swabs, cotton balls and shower caps) 3) great wifi 4) easy work space in room and easy to charge devices 5) great gym and safe places to run outside 6) great food for eating healthy 7)great service 8) easy place to buy a few souvenirs for the kids while I'm away. The palace hotel serves all of these up with 5 stars. I love my home away from home in Tokyo!

Palace Hotel Tokyo is a hotel that relaxes you after a whole year of work when you need a break and spend family time with friends and family or your beloved ones. The Palace Hotel is a relaxation paradise and it is also convenient because the Tokyo metro system is underneath the hotel so, if you want to go to any tourist spots, you can go to there quickly and easily. During spring, there is a orchard across the road and the orchard has beautiful cherry blossoms that you could look at and have a picnic in there and enjoy the breeze of spring. Finally, the hotel offers a 6 star service and it was totally magnificent.

My family and I enjoyed our stay immensely and will return. The rooms are peaceful, spotlessly clean and luxurious. The view from our balcony of the Palace Gardens provided a calm respite in the midst of a crowded, chaotic Tokyo. The breakfast buffet is excellent with a huge variety of Western and Japanese items. The 24 hour gym is large with up to date equipment and overlooks the Palace Gardens.Service is outstanding and we felt very safe. We appreciated the security of keyed elevators. On a quirky note, the lobby of the hotel has a calming, subtle cedar, anise, citrus scent that welcomes you. The large glass windows and artwork in the lobby also contribute to a grand and luxurious welcome. On a practical note, there is a subway stop in the basement of the hotel plus a half dozen lower cost, clean local restaurants in the subway entrance area. This was an easy option for a quick, light, jet lagged family meal at the end of the day. Overall this was one of the finest hotels we have ever had the pleasure of visiting. We stayed there for four nights.

My wife and I recently stayed at the Palace Hotel for 7 nights at the beginning of a 4 week tour of Japan.We deliberately chose this hotel to experience a Japanese high class hotel, rather than the usual Four Seasons, Ritz Carlton etc that we would usually use. We selected a Club Deluxe Room with balcony as we find the facilities in the 'Club' rooms in hotels to be very useful when we are touring. The room itself was pretty spacious, with an excellent range of amenities and a wide view from the 22nd floor over the Palace Gardens towards the city and Mt.Fuji (we were lucky enough to see it on most days).The location for us was excellent - a few minutes walk to Tokyo JR Station, a direct subway connection to Otemachi station, which is one of the best connected subway stations, and within walking distance of Ginza. We really enjoyed our 7 night stay, in fact we are back there for another short stay in a couple of weeks time.All of the staff were absolutely charming, though on the Club floor perhaps not as sharp as one finds in the hotels named above, but I put some of this down to language difficulties. One young lady from the 6th Floor Restaurants - Christine I think - spent some considerable time with us, adapting the menus in the Teppanyaki and Tempura for two meals we had there, to cater for our dietary needs. She was absolutely superb, as was the lady who served us on both occasions - thank you.The one element that we thought was lacking both in quality & range was the food & beverages at the Club floor, particularly when compared to the western chains mentioned previously. The breakfast was pretty basic,and often not particularly well cooked, and the drinks offered during the cocktail period were mostly of a quite low quality, particularly the wine. (Mr Manager - a trip to the Ritz Carlton in Singapore may give an appropriate benchmark !).Notwithstanding the few negatives, we enjoyed our time at the Palace Hotel and think that on the whole it is a very good hotel indeed - there are just some parts that could do with improving to make it great. The owners and management has done well in creating a beautiful hotel and recruiting some very nice people - there are just certain aspects that are not really world class and need some improvement.We very much look forward to our return.

We stayed 3 nights at this fantastic hotel for the start of our 17 day trip in Japan. The location of the hotel overlooking the beautiful gardens was only a 3km walk from the Ginza shopping area was fabulous. The service in all areas of this hotel was outstanding from the turn down service at night to the restaurants and reception. The staff were so polite and welcoming we loved it. What a great way to start a Japan tour.

We spent 4 luxurious nights on the concierge level of this fantastic hotel. The service was flawless and the staff in the lounge took very good care of us. The room was beautifully appointed, the super comfortable bed was the perfect panacea to our jet lag.Location is a short walk to Tokyo station as is quite central.

I think that this is what every hotel wants to be. Awesome service, location and facilities. Incredibly friendly staff. My only reservation is the charge for the gym, which is quite high. Otherwise, this is " Four Seasons" calibre.

Overlooking the Marunouchi distract, the stunning Palace Gardens and a stroll from Tokyo's exciting Ginza, The Palace Hotel is a subtle blend of Japanese luxury and modern convenience, the staff are überattentive without ever being under-foot. The porters read our names from our baggage tags so quickly that we were greeted by name before we had exited our cab. We were swiftly direct to the executive lounge on the 19th floor while front desk staff checked us in remotely.Our 21st floor room was superlatively appointed, fittings of the highest quality, a solid slatted king-size bed and a view overlooking the Royal Palace and gardens.The GREATEST disappointment was that we only had two nights at The Palace, it was my first stay at the hotel - my travel companions second - we were both wowed.HINT: the arcade beneath the hotel is well worth a visit, the artisan shops will help peel away the contents of your purse, such beautiful items on offer.My only complaint was that both times we ordered room service, the fare arrived less than steaming hot.

Having stopped in many hotels during our stay in Tokyo, I was disappointed that I had only booked one night here! The hotel views and the room was amazing. And the minibar was exceptional and good value. We were extremely lucky to get into the tepinyaki restaurant during our stay and had our own personal chef for the evening. The food was exceptional and the chef encouraged us to try new foods and flavours that blew us away! Advances booking us recommended for this!

Enjoyable for a bit more mature crowd.Old school bar , great service conviniently close to the Tokyo station. not a place with tour groups, great views.recommend to get a balcony room, its is well worth it
user_name:
emily w
Egg Harbor Township, New Jersey

review_body: I used to stay at the Palace years ago before the recent refurbishment. It was good then. Now it is quite exceptional. The service standards are of the very highest international class and the room I had with a palace view had every amenity and was extremely comfortable. The tempura restaurant was a delight as was the bar. I can't wait to go back
user_location: Walton on the Hill, United Kingdom
user_name:
Sonearsofar
Walton on the Hill, United Kingdom

review_body: We are at the Palace Hotel for 2 nights and, so far, the service, the food, the attention and the cleaness is outstanding. However, tonight after trying to have dinner at the Grand Kitchen Restaurant and not being able because it was full, we were invited to stay at the Palace Lounge and have a light meal . When the bill came, to our surprise, we noticed they charged us the equivalent of US$8 for 3 pieces of bread which in our previous meals at the Hotel we were never charged. We complained with the waiter about that charge but he justified that it was a SF order, special food order... It's very wierd to us that a hotel of this category, without never mentioning the price of the bread in the menu, charged us for that, mainly because in previous meals they have never done that.

I stayed at the hotel for three nights. I'm a frequent traveler to Japan however it was my first stay at The Palace Hotel. Everything was perfect: from the quality of the room, the facilities, club lounge and in-room dining to the hospitality of the staff, it was such a luxurious experience. I would have no hesitation in booking my next visit there again. The care and professionalism of the staff made my trip so comfortable and memorable.

=> It was very nice clean and high-tech facility. I were interested by the way they set up welcome cookie and fruit on table, look tasty, luxury and different=> Evian Spa service is so nice but treatment was not excellent and diversify=> I was quite disappointed with breakfast. We didnt include breakfast in room rate but because I have flight early morning then I get up around 6 and come down for breakfast but the number amount of food is poor, only some salad, rice, fruit n yogurt. Quality not high.=> Staff was nice and guide us very detaily

In summary, everything about this hotel is near perfection. The front door staff read my name on my luggage tags so quickly that I was greeted by name when exiting the taxi upon arrival. I was then led to the front desk where the staff balanced a perfect mix of professionalism and friendliness.I was lead to a (standard) room that was large by US standards. The room was spotlessly clean - you know when more than a cursory cleaning takes place. The bathroom had the necessary things: Phone, TV, great lighting and size (heated toilets seats are great but standard in Japan). Too bad other hotels don't get this simple thing right.Hotel staff was friendly and warm - until now the best service I ever received was at the Mandarin Oriental in Singapore - the service here is even better (something I thought would be impossible). I didn't meet the person, but the manager of this hotel deserves every award out there.I ate at one of the restaurants (Golden Palace) and had drinks at the lobby bar - both were great..Location is superb - a few blocks from Tokyo station.

I cannot recommend this hotel highly enough... It was amazingly professional from start to finish but at the same time there is something exceptionally caring about the palace. In the bar Mr Matsumoto was so thoughtful, life is not always as easy as others may think when you are a female on your own. If you are going to Tokyo... Simply ... You have not been there if you do not go here for at least a drink. It may seem expensive.. Ordinary girl in an ordinary job...but considering how central it is you save in the long run!! You get the picture... Didn't like it.. Loved it thank you Palace

Luxurious room with a great view to Tokyo Palace and gardens.Great restaurants, great service, great rooms.We stayed for total 4 days and i was impressed with the kindness and the service in every single request.

In Palace Hotel Tokyo everything worked perfectly. Service staff was really attentive and over all the hotel was exactly what you expect from a 5 star hotel.We stayed three nights in Grande Deluxe -room. The balcony was huge and the view to Imperial Palace garden was beautiful. You could also see the skyline from the bathtub. The walk-in closet definitely makes is nicer to stay in a hotel room.Room service worked perfectly and the food was great. Bed, linen, and pyjamas were good quality and the room big and comfortable. Location is very good when wanting to do sightseeing in the east side of the town or if wanting to take the Shinkansen or Narita Express from Tokyo Station. Area around the hotel is very calm. Also the gym was really nice for some morning work out.

This is the first time I have stayed at the palace hotel in TokyoThe rooms were very well appointed and had all the amenities a business traveler would want The bathrooms were luxurious and linen and towels were very niceThe ingredients in the bathroom were of a high quality The location is excellent to see the palace and also central to travel conveniently to various business meetingsThe bars were very good and had the right views and atmosphere The Chinese restaurant had high quality food and very good service The only thing which did not impress me was their all day dining restaurant ..the service and food were average Overall ..a good experience

This hotel has a superb location overlooking the Imperial Palace and its gardens. Not only that but it is close to both Tokyo Central Station and the Metro Otemachi station is almost underneath. Rooms are a delight, especially the suite that we had which fell into the Club category with access to a dedicated lounge. There was a balcony with chairs where one was able to partake of drinks or meals all the time overlooking the Imperal Gardens. Everything one wanted seemed to have been anticipated. Room service was efficient as was housekeeping. Of course the room was kept immaculately clean. WiFi was free and fast. Complimentary mineral water, tea, coffee and a Nespresso machine was available. Food was superb. We ate in the Club Lounge for breakfast which offered all we wanted. As for dinner we ate outside in a relaxed manner at the Grand Kitchen having had cocktails in the Club Lounge. It was our wedding anniversary and so we pushed the boat out with a dinner at the in-house tempura restaurant. It was spectacular with the chef taking great care of us. It was a very special meal.This is also a place where wedding parties come both for photographs and their celebrations. One day the hotel hosted 10 wedding parties without any disruption to the guests. The hotel staff were excellent and very helpful. No request was too small and all was handled cheerfullyOverall a truly enjoyable experience

My husband and I recently stayed at The Palace Hotel for our 25th wedding anniversary and we were totally in awe of the thoughtfulness and kindness the staff showed to us. We had never before stayed at a hotel where the staff, who spoke English well, went to an incredibly wonderful effort to make our stay such a very happy one-from being greeted with a bed covered with rose petals and cut out origami paper spelling 'Happy 25th anniversary' to a laminated card signed by many of the staff with their best wishes and a photo of us in the middle. The views from the rooms are beautiful looking out over the Palace gardens and each day we would check Mt Fuji from our balcony. Our room was very spacious and contained every luxury we could think of and more. It was fabulously situated only a 5 minute walk from Tokyo station and 20 minute walk to Ginza Street. Beautifully memories and a beautiful Hotel! Arigato gozaimasu.

The stay in the Palace Hotel Tokyo was one of the best hotels in terms of hospitality and service.The rooms are perfect, the interior designers thought of every need and gadget you might have. Floor to ceiling windows with view of the palace compound are also not soething that you get every day.The food selection is widely ranged, the service staff very attentive and sitting outside during breakfast makes for a perfect start of the day.Quite pricy - but that's Tokyo, right?I'll be back !

This is by far the best hotel for us in Tokyo. I've stayed in the other high end hotels in the area and this is "the one" for me and my family so far. Not the biggest room in the city but very decent size and well appointed interiors. Love it that the rooms have balcony (very safe height of the railings) overlooking th Imperial Palace. Great staff-all of them. The subway line in the basement is a plus. Imabari towels are used in the hotel. The Evian Spa is a must. Nothing beats the Grandeur of this hotels lobby.

The hotel was overall very impressive. Walking distance to Tokyo station, less than 10 minutes. For those who preferred to get right to Metro, hotel was right at Otemachi station. Hotel never disapppointed me at all during my 8-day stay. Ranging from check-in counter, the staffs were very polite and with good command of English. Room were relatively spacious from Japanese hotel perspective, and enjoying the view of Imperial Palace. My wife and I kept guessing which building the Emperor was staying. Room service were quick and never refused our requests. Room were clean. Bathroom was spacious and with TV screen on the mirror.

Stayed at the Palace for two nights in December and it proved a wonderful choice. It is one of the most Japanese of Tokyo's luxury hotels (compared to some of the more "internationalised" brands like Shangri La, Peninsula, Mandarin Oriental, or Park Hyatt) and in my view has some of the most prettily decorated rooms of all in a sober and classy modern ("Westernised") Japanese style.The location is excellent, overlooking the Imperial Palace gardens and by the lovely shopping of Marunouchi, and about 10 minutes walk from Tokyo Station (Marunouchi North exit is best) and 15 from Ginza. A walk or jog in the palace gardens is a wonderful attraction in its own right!I was staying in a balcony room, and while it was a bit cold in the winter it must be a fabulous treat when the weather is milder. The bathrooms are wonderful with the wet area (bathtub and rainshower) overlooking the bay windows and the beautiful view to the Palace gardens. The rooms are large (about 45 sq m).Breakfast in the lobby lounge was good with excellent pastries, amazing wood-fired toasts and freshly squeezed fruit and vegetable juices. The hot selection was a bit less convincing. Had lunch and dinner at both the Japanese (both general area and the rather famous sushi) and the Chinese restaurants and both were of outstanding quality. Service extremely kind and efficient, outstanding room equipment including pyjamas and enough bathroom amenities that you could probably forget your toiletry bag, etc. An excellent choice in Central Tokyo.

If you can afford to stay at this hotel then you will not be disappointed. The executive room I stayed in was of the very highest standard and the service was second to none. However at over £900 per night B&B it is slightly more than I would want to pay if I was staying as a private guest.The furnishings are excellent (as you would expect) and the executive welcome with drink and nibbles whilst being registered is a nice touch (but probably not necessary).The Palace is very well placed for the railway station and for a walk in the Imperial gardens just across the road from the hotel. It is an ideal hotel to ease the strain of a hectic business trip.

Indeed a Palace !!! Probably among one of the best hotels.Next to the Palace, conveniently located at walking distance to Tokyo station. Good breakfast spread - with options to side indoors or outdoors.Rooms are very good and spacious. As we say nothing comes for free - you pay for what you get; Expensive.

a great hotel with wonderful service. Could use more restaurants near by but location next to the palace gardens was a treat. Hope next time to visit the gardens. Balcony views were marvelous. Easy check in and check out. 20 minutes to Haneda airport

I have stayed here a couple of times how and been very happy both times. The setting is excellent very close to the Palace Gardens that are very relaxing to walk round if you have the time and ideal if you want to go for a run.Service is first class in all bars. The lounge area serves good light meals and seems reasonably priced for Tokyo. Breakfast is what you would expect from a top hotel and offers a choice so you don't have to have the full buffet if you want a light breakfast.The rooms are a reasonable size but not large.The gym is ok and looks out over the palace gardens so it's a good view from the treadmill. There is also a very pleasant spa area in the gym.I will happily continue to stay here when in Tokyo.

The hotel staff are perfectly trained and polite to a fault -- greeting you by name as you first approach reception (having been alerted by the porter who escorts you in). Rooms are comfortable and well-appointed and kitted out with every amenity. The gym was a little small but equipped with quality equipment (of course!). Did some laps in the equally small lap pool, luckily I had it all to myself. The hotel was overheated and they could save some energy by dealing down the thermostat. But a treat to stay here all the same.

The views of the Imperial palace grounds (it was cherry blossom season!) were spectacular. The gym was 24 hours and has some of the best equipment you have ever seen. Not cheap but a very good central location to see all of Toyko. Felt very pampered with amazing customer service and interesting visitors from all over the world.

The standard rooms were better than any standard room I have stayed in- we felt upgraded although we weren't! They were quite large (and we had a spectacular view of the palace). The breakfast was superb, the service the same. The pool was breathtaking and we had a 'private' pool every morning since we were the only ones there. The views of the palace and gardens were beautiful and while we were centrally located in Tokyo and next to a subway station, the location was quiet and tranquil. We have stayed in many Leading Hotels of the World and this was by far one of the best. Best of all, very good value (recommend getting LHW membership and then breakfast and wifi free, and the latter should not be missed.

No efforts spared to make this THE hotel to stay in Tokyo! Service was immaculate and rooms were designed with travellers' comfort level in mind. Food quality is excellent in restaurants and room service, if time permits, a teppanyaki dinner is now my "must-have".Truly hospitality at its finest.

This is a quiet hotel with big rooms for Japanese standard especially in Tokyo. The architect did a wonderful job to renovate this hotel, the space is utilised perfectly, they have electric curtain, lights switches are user friendly. We have a veranda facing the Imperial palace, the view is spectacular. We are so happy we can stay in this hotel for the weekend, and the price is reasonable.

The service is excellent, and the room are spacious and user friendly. We stayed in a room with veranda so my husband can smoke and drink while I stated inside our hotel room, which is perfect for us.The subway station is right underneath the hotel, taking a taxi from Ginza to hotel is 910yen.

A wonderful hotel. The facilities, staff, restaurants where the food on offer was excellent, location [right next to the Imperial Palace gardens, & the subway] made it perfect for us. Access to all forms of transport for embarking on a "selfie" tour of the city made it so easy.It is not often that my wife says 'we should have made a reservation for the last two nights" - of our3 week trip to Japan. If you have the opportunity to stay in Tokyo do stay at the Palace hotel, you won't regret it.

I was very positively surprised when I entered the room first: much more spacious than I'd expect in Tokyo. This hotel has been recently rebuilt and all the facilities are great. The rooms are well equipped and spotless. Hotel staff is very helpful and knowledgeable - received some great recommendations.In room dining experience was very good, food arrived quickly and the quality was excellent.The only downside was that they wanted to charge me an extra third of the daily room rate for a late check out (2pm), which I kindly rejected and visited the royal palace imperial garden across the road.It also has great transport connections with both the main train lines and metro just few minutes walking away.Sleep quality was excellent - rooms are not noise at all.

Straight off a flight from NYC, the Palace Hotel greeted me with excellence. My room wasn't ready yet, so they held on to our luggage while we stepped out to get lunch.Upon our return we were escorted to our room (our luggage had a slight delay in following us), which was spacious and luxurious. The bed was comfy and the bathroom was full of amenities. The best part is that we discovered they replenished our towels and toiletries during turndown service.Breakfast was plentiful, with both Japanese and Western items. The pastry chef on site was a real bonus.This was the most expensive hotel we stayed at in Japan, but we definitely got value and service for the expense.

After many years of decline, this hotel was torn down and completely rebuilt from the ground up. While here are probably some structures around the globe that don't warrant such an invest, I don't think that qualifies for post 1950's construction. This hotel is beautiful. It is centrally located and very close to the Tokyo train. From there you can go anywhere in Japan. As with most Asian hotels, the service is impeccable. It is clean and modern. Highly recommended.

This hotel has much going for it. Nice style and design, quite new. Grand entrance and best location and outlook. The fittings are average quality but not of high standard. The bed hard and quite uncomfortable. The breakfast buffet quite appalling actually - everything was quite mauled actually. Many foods not restocked and buffet badly set out makes it feel very uncivilised and uncomfortable. I won't go back.

The new Palace Hotel opened a couple of years ago (I have been to the old one back in 2003) and finally I had a chance to visit it: This is a typical japanese 5* hotel with highest standards in regards of service. Rooms are spacious with large bath area and of classic, yet modern design. The unique feature is the private balcony, where you can enjoy the view over the Imperial Palace. As for facilities, there are two bars, one smoking the other non-smoking, both serving excellent drinks. I did not have time to enjoy the restaurants. While Marunouchi changed quite a bit in the recent years - a very posh shopping street is just a stroll away, so is Tokyo Station -, it remains a business area and you need to travel for any nightlife. Taxi is the most convenient way, as it is quite a walk to the next subway station via the directly accessible underground passage. I will be back to the Palace for sure.

We stayed in the deluxe room with balcony and club access. The best part of this hotel room is the balcony. The other characteristics of the room and hotel are not much different from other similarly priced five star high end hotels in Tokyo, such as the spacious room, the exemplary service, quality amenities in room, spacious bathroom (a small television embedded in the bathroom mirror is unique), comfortable bed and linens, etc. There is some distance from the street to the balcony because of the moat that borders part of the hotel. It is quite nice to sit (the chairs and table are discreetly stationed to the concrete floor via wire) and look at the view (the palace grounds, the skyline on the other side of the palace moat and grounds) while sipping morning or afternoon tea/coffee. However, probably a better experience on the upper floors where the traffic noise and fume level is lower. The location is convenient to subways (Otemachi is the closest) and walking distance to Tokyo Station. The hotel is walking distance to the restaurants and shops within and surrounding the station. There are also restaurants and shops underneath the hotel plus access to subway. The club access was worthwhile. The view from the outside terrace of the club is awesome (although you need to compete with the hedges for the view). The club offers buffet breakfast (food is delicious), afternoon and evening snacks and drinks. If have club access, checkout and check-in are done there instead of the lobby. This hotel is beautifully renovated, designed, and decorated.

Impeccable is all ways from the high tech but welcoming and warm room to the relaxing breakfast restaurant.The service is reflects the Japanese culture of hospitality, politeness and then some moreThe tempura restaurant is a must experience. Just divine.Having stayed at some of the very best hotels in the world including George V Paris, Mandarin Oriental LV and Peninsula LA, the Palace sits proudly with them.It's suits the travellers who would like some tranquility from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo.A most wonderful experience but next trip for me is back to the Cerulean in Shibuya to be in the thick of the excitement and convenience

This modern, well located, well designed and well equipped hotel exceeded all my expectations (and they were pretty high). We stayed a total of two times over the course of two weeks for about 7 days total. On both visits we booked the standard room with club lounge access. I'll start by saying that the club lounge provided excellent value and service for what I felt was a very reasonable premium. Access includes a lovely breakfast, afternoon tea service and evening cocktails with heavy canapes. The food services were just lovely and the evening cocktail service was a perfect way to end the day and start the evening. Additionally, the lounge staff (led by the incomparable Ms. Matsunaga) was exceptional in helping to book train and restaurant reservations and in general ensuring that our stay was comfortable. The rooms themselves are truly a study in contemporary design yet able to retain that certain Japanese character which makes them so special. The beds had the most amazing linens and pillows dressing them. You would have thought you were in Italy but I checked and in fact the bed linens are made in Japan. So soft and smooth and cool! The bathrooms were a highlight with the best shower pressure I've experienced, great design, Toto washlets (of course) and really nice bath products from France or England depending on your type of room.The entertainment and electronic controls in the room were second to none. Numerous English channels as well as the option to connect your own device or listen to internet radio through the system. The electronically controlled curtains worked beautifully and were able to completely blacken the room (important when jet lagging!).Probably my favorite part of the room was the tea service provided and refreshed daily. The iron pots are made in an area of Japan that is well known for this and the teas themselves were awesome. There was no better start to a day than to brew a cup of strong green tea and sit on the balcony overlooking the palace (and Mt. Fuji on a clear day). Of course there was also coffee provided if green tea isn't your thing.Housekeeping was done at least twice per day and had to be the most thorough I've seen in my years of travel. Not one thing was overlooked or not replenished.The gym and swimming pool area were both well kitted out and very nice for a hotel gym and pool.Food in the Grand Dining room and in room dining were excellent quality and a good value for the yen. In particular the food in the Grand Dining Room was absolutely excellent for both breakfast, afternoon tea and dinner. The menu is of more of a Western nature but the quality was excellent.Bell services were on time and perfect. Front desk was very helpful. Wifi was fast and free (about 15 mgbs up and about the same down). On a nice day it's about a 10 minute walk to Tokyo Station but there's also the Otemachi metro station in the basement which connects to 5 subway lines making it extremely convenient to get around. The basement of the building contains a 7-11 (important for Americans as this was the only ATM that worked for me) but also included a number of well priced boutiques for buying clothing, textiles and other items along with a wonderful deli style sweet shop with awesome fresh breads, pastries and savory bites.In summary, absolutely every person we encountered (really the standard in all of Japan) was helpful, pleasant and was just nice. Based on location and quality of the facility as well as the superior service this is the place to stay in Tokyo.

This hotel was chosen for us by the travel agent at the train station during the typhoon when we needed a hotel near the Tokyo train station. The hotel is superb. Just a couple years old, very well designed inside and outside a very beautiful modern building near the Royal Palace. Staff hospitatily really exceptional, and plenty of employees to check you have got what you are looking for. Nice spacious well designed room and bathroom. Several great bars, from dark to outdoor, we drank in each one of course, but no HH. Some inexpensive restaurants and an Irish pub in the underground shopping center. Some great walking retail streets nearby. Very pleased with this hotel and we will recommend and return.

The Excellent- decor- service great all around- rooms are big and very nice - plenty of restaurant choices- location and connectivity- (might sound trivial) the smell The less good- some service is borderline snobbish. - breakfast is very good, and not excellent

Spent four nights in a deluxe room, booked thru Visa signature luxury collection.I got a great price match , free breakfast and room upgrade. Stayed last year at the Capitol Hotel Tokyu, and I thought that was the best. This hotel does cost more, but you get so much extra. The room is about the same size, but I prefer the design of the Palace. The Capitol has the sink located in the entry way to the room. I love the three TV's in the Palace and the breakfast buffet had more variety. The location is great, with five subway lines connected thru underground passages. Service was great at both hotels, but I felt a little more personal service was given at the Palace.When the female bell hop brought my bags up she introduced herself and asked if I needed a tour of the room. Excellent service continued when I called for help in bringing my bags down, I was called by name and the wait was very short. I earlier bought a box for packing from the bell desk and was surprised to see a nice strap was around my box when i got my bags back waiting for the airport bus. I plan to visit Tokyo again in January and wanted to book the Palace, but it was sold out. I will now try the Conrad and will see if this hotel can exceed my experience at the Palace.

The redesign of both the rooms and public areas is exceptional - very few places manage to combine style with practicality but the Palace Hotel does that in every way. This is exquisitely detailed design. The bathrooms are a sheer delight after a long flight. And the drawer holding almost every cable you'd ever need is inspired. I was here for business but wouldn't hesitate to stay for fun even though it is in a business area. The restaurants in the hotel,the basement and buildings close by offer something for everyone.

The Palace Hotel is a very nice hotel, they recently rebuilt the hotel about 2 years ago. It has the latest gadgets and beautiful views. My room had a view of the imperial palace grounds, though the view was limited, what I was able to see was very nice. My friend had a balcony and he said this view was great. The service was over the top good. An example of this is the day I left Tokyo, I decide to hand carry my suitcase, because I did not want to wait for it to come off the plane. I asked the concierge if there was some place I could buy a plastic bag for my liquids and gels, but she was unable to find one close. I was fine with buying something at the airport and went shopping for a bit. When I got back to the hotel, I had a message from the concierge saying they had some bags for me and that I could come down stairs and get them anytime. They gave me two ziplock bags at no charge.My stay was full of surprises from the concierge and other staff members at the Palace Hotel. Even if the hotel was not as nice as this one, I would recommend it to anyone just for the service. However, you get the added bonus with the Palace Hotel, because it is a very beautiful hotel in a very convenient location, very close to Tokyo station and to the Imperial Palace. If you are a runner or walker, the path around the Imperial Palace is a great place to workout.This Palace Hotel treated me better than any hotel I have ever stayed in and I stayed at many very nice hotels. This one is the best.

I spent four nights here recently with family. There is much to like at this recent rebuild of a Tokyo classic. The rooms are relatively spacious by Japanese standards with decent ceiling height, well equipped and good bathrooms. It is worth paying extra for the rooms with balconies that look out towards Hibiya rather than the standard rooms which have strangely angled windows designed to prevent you from seeing too much of the Imperial Palace. The location is good if you have business in the area or you need access to Tokyo Station but the district is somewhat lifeless in the evenings and at weekends.Although in many respects the hotel has most of the attributes of an international 5 star, I was disappointed by the service. Two of us arrived early but after a twelve hour flight from London I was hoping that they would show flexibility on giving us our room. We were told that we could have our room at noon and the check-in staff then kept to that schedule. When we asked if a room was available before that time they said the "inspection" was not complete. Restaurant recommendations by the concierge desk were disappointing. I was particularly annoyed by the attitude of the maître d' of the main all day dining restaurant, Grand Kitchen. I was trying to explain to the lady at the front that I wanted a table outside for lunch rather than join the waiting list for tables inside for coffee and cakes when he came over in an aggressive fashion and told me basically to wait my turn. When I explained what I was actually asking for and that there were at least four empty tables outside he did apologise but why had he behaved in this fashion in the first place. The next day he showed complete disrespect because I had invited to drinks two Philippinas who had worked for my family many years before.I always think the acid test of any review is would one stay again and in this case I believe the answer is probably no.

Having often stayed in the old Palace Hotel it was nice to try out the new.The owners have done a fantastic job and this is a perfect big city hotel with everything you need.The service is of highest Tokyo standard. ( of course)Had a delux room with balcony and a wonderful view. Fast Wifi, large bathroom, good minibar. Nice shops in basement and ATM in the Seven Eleven.We tried the Italian and the Japanese restaurant and both nice. The French was bit over done and waste of money in our opinion. The downside of this hotel is the surroundings if and when you have some free time to take a walk.Only big office buildings and nothing more. Next time I think I will come back to the Imperial not so far away. Park in the front and lots of action, small restaurants and also Ginza behind. But there is of course always a taxi.

We stayed here three nights after arriving from the states. It's close proximity to Tokyo station made it super accessible and the view of the palace grounds and the rest of Tokyo are lovely from the room. The hotel amenities and service are everything you could hope to expect. Friendly staff and lovely details in the room make it worth the price. The 24 hour fitness room is a great asset for when you have jet lag.We also enjoyed the brunch twice while we stayed there as it was a great way to start the day with a large assortment of items to choose from.I've already been recommending this hotel to family and friends for their stays in Tokyo.

This is our second stay at this hotel this year, and we truly loved it. It was our anniversary and we decided to stay here at the last minute when arriving in Tokyo in the afternoon. Everything was just as we remembered when we first stayed there in march this year. Our room view was of the imperial palace. location wise it's close to tokyo station and only 5 mins walk to imperial palace. There are also a lot of shopping malls nearby manourouchi. 20 mins walk to Ginza. There is an underground link below the hotel to go to other nearby malls, and some shops. Do try their patisserie shop at the lower ground floor. We tried their seasonal Sakura patisserie and it was a delight. The main reason why we kept coming back here is the Evian Spa! Prior to the treatment, you can use the sauna and hot spa. You can drink as much evian water as you want while at the spa. Good detox. The swimming pool is also lovely for lap swimming.The only ate food from the room service and the lounge area. Both were good.I would highly recommend this place when visiting tokyo. It is worth every yen!

I find the rooms in this hotel very similar to Conrad Tokyo. In fact, they are nearly identical!Yet, they are different in other areas.Palace Hotel offers rooms with balconies, I enjoyed the clean morning air mixed with cold fog and the view from the 23rd floor.Location wise, it is ideal for travelers who wish to use Shinkansen (Bullet Train). The hotel is around 7 min walk from Tokyo Station.In fact, you are surrounded by train and subway stations for easy access to JR Chuo, JR Yamanote, JR Keiyou, JR Keihin, Narita Express, Mita, Chiyoda, Hibiya, Marunouchi, Tozai and other lines. Tokyo, Otemachi, Marunouchi, Hibiya and Yurakucho stations are all within 15 min walk.It is also 5 min walk from the imperial palace parks and 20 min walk from Ginza Area.Breakfast is okay and Hotel Staff are friendly. Free WiFi access.Not sure if that was due to the corporate plan I have.Room is spacious and the view is nice.Bathrooms are better than the Conrad's, but I've seen better in Japan.Some amenities are high quality, while others feel cheep.A bit pricey, Conrad was better for the value.Access to Ginza Area was convenient, but The Peninsula Hotel is is much closer and also offers good Imperial Palace Park View rooms.Upon checkout, I found my breakfast bill missing, so I highlighted that to the front desk. Eventually, I was told that since it has slipped already, I won't be charged for it! Will I be back? Maybe, probably after trying some other hotels around.

This is a fantastic place in a beautiful location with top service. Traveling for business you want to be in a place where the more you return the more you feel like home away from home. Spacious rooms with all the amenities and a great workout room to sweat off the the jet leg.

Magnificent location, beautifully appointed decor, impeccable service, knowledgeable, helpful, attentive staff. I asked for a quiet room in the highest floor possible and that is exactly what I got, an amazing view of Tokyo and the Imperial Palace. I cannot commend the staff enough, from the porter, to the concierge, to the front desk, to housekeeping. Superb, luxury accommodation! Highly recommendable for business or pleasure.

This is a quality but cool business hotel.Just stayed four nights. Rooms well appointed and spacious with great bathrooms. Could not get any TV channels in bedroom that were not in Japanese. But it didn't really matter with a great WIFI connection. Good breakfast and friendly staff. As you might expect breakfast is pricey but there are restaurants etc in the mall under the hotel including an Italian. Hotel was full because of a conference and a colleague of mine booking later could not get in for one night but despite the full occupancy the staff were still very courteous and there was never a long wait for a lift etc. Definitely my first choice for future Tokyo trips.

Location : 4.5/5 - At your door step is the beautiful Outer gardens of the Imperial palace grounds- a very nice and pleasant walk. A 6 min walk to the start of shopping street Marunochi with lots of malls ( 2 blocks/ streets way) ,Tokyo station is about 10-12min walk (4 blocks). Otemachi Station on the Toei Mita Line- 2 mins walk, Otemachi Station on the Chiyoda Line is 7min walk.It like being close enough to walk to the malls but away form the noise. However, after all the shopping, a taxi ride is likely a welcome relief.The is a free shuttle service to the neighbouring facilities that operates daily from the hotel.Ambience : 5/5Front desk : 5/5 Speak good englishConcierge : 5/5 Speak good englishDining : 4.5/5 Fairly good variety of restaurants and small eating outlets within the premises of the hotel but make sure to book ahead for the more popular upmarket Tempura rest.Breakfast at the hotel's outlet is a good spread. They have a wonderful range of breakfast juices. The most popular is a green coloured juice of mix.Rooms : 5/5 Service : 5/5Housekeeping : 5/5Pricing : 3/5 - Nice to have experience but at a price.

We really enjoyed this hotel. After a stay in Kyoto and Matsumoto we finished a trip to Japan at the Palace Hotel. 4 seasons quality service but much more Japanese. Hotel over looks the Imperial Palace Gardens. Recommend waking the gardens in early morning and trying to catch a few glimpses of the royal palace grounds and their morning kendo practice. Very cool.

Love Tokyo- this hotel is very centrally located, with good subway and underground walking connections. Huge complex recently renovated, walking distance to Tokyo station for Narita Express. Consistent with what one can come to expect in Japan, great aesthetic and service. Many restaurants and huge complex gives it a bit of a Vegas feel, but I'll take that any way when overlayed with a Japanese touch.

Back Again to the PALACE HOTEL Came here last October and returned .I had an extraordinary stay,probably better than the previous one. ( which was really god).Now in my personal preferences PALACE HOTEL is number ONE,followed byPeninsula ,Four Seasons and Park Hyatt. And save 200/300 bucks a day , comparing with the others..not bad at all .Perfect location .10 minutes walking distance to Tokio Station even Ginza. I got an UPGRADE in the córner side with an amazing views of the Imperial Palace and their Gardens! , It was quite spacious and one of the most well designed I've seen. Almost everything is automated , allowing you to set lighting moods, open and close shutters and shades and a host of other features..,refilling amenities two/three times per day . Anne Semonin toiletries . water,tea, towels,etc..The Customer Service more than excellent ( and I speak for JAPAN per se ) , but I think that PALACE HOTEL go for the extra mile .I communicate three days in advance my particularly needs and the Chief Concierge and the head of Reservations rooms responded inmediately . all my needs and reservations we're accomplish .Excellent Network connectivity: WIFI is free with very good download speed.The Gym and the EVIAN SPA top notch.!I left for the end my comments about the Restaurants.If you come to Japan youHave to look for the best Japanese Food and if you can have in the Hotel this is a plus PALACE HOTEL has FOUR Japanese restaurants as they said.."A culinary concerto to satisfy the Soul" WADAKURA is for japanese kaiseki ( which was were I dine) ,also TATSUMI ( tempura) GO ( teppanyaki) And KANESAKA ( sushi)Of course they are other four restaurants ( French,Chinese,etc)After this stay I will be sure that every time I return to Tokyo PALACE HOTEL will be my place to stay.

I just can say that everything was perfect.I was there as part of a business trip and it is a high quality hotel. Very good service, wonderful rooms amd beds,lovely bathroom and amenities, great fitness centre with views over the city.Breakfast was also good.

I've stayed at the Palace twice over the past year so can vouch I liked it enough to come back, and will do so again. Pros (with some caveats):- Location (although in Tokyo I chose my hotels based on where I need to be, so this can vary)- Views from rooms- Impeccable modern rooms but these are not the largest vs other high end hotels- Nice modern bathroom and shower- Outside terrace for dining- Food is good but again, not the best hotel dining in Tokyo. The ground floor restaurant indoors, however, is also a bit sterile and lacks the views that can be found in some other hotels.No real negatives.

I stayed at The Palace Hotel for 8 nights on a recent business trip to Tokyo. The location is great--only 10 minutes to walk to Tokyo Station and just a few minutes away from the Marunouchi shopping and business district. Rooms are very large by Japanese standards. My room was very clean, comfortable, and had top notch amenities. I also was lucky enough to get an upgraded room with a view of the Imperial Palace grounds. There is a small shopping area in the basement of the hotel and a walkway that connects you to the subway. There are several restaurants in this area (udon, pizza, Irish pub, Tully's Coffee, etc.) and a 7-11 convenience store, which is open until 11pm each night. They also have a handful of gift shops that sell high quality Japanese merchandise. If you decide to purchase any gifts here, be sure to let them know that you are a guest of the hotel and they may offer a discount. . In addition to the subterranean dining options, there are several higher end restaurants on the 6th floor of the hotel. We ate at Go (teppanyaki) and it was fantastic. The only negative experience I had there was shortly after I checked out. I had a little time to kill before I needed to leave for the airport and decided to grab a quick lunch. I picked up a sandwich at one of the underground restaurants and was in the back of the hotel lobby on a bench by myself. It was extremely hot outside, so I decided to eat my sandwich on the lobby bench. Within a few minutes, a female hotel employee approached me and told me that I was not permitted to eat my sandwich there. She said that she knew that I was a guest of the hotel and was wondering why I was not eating in my room. I explained to her that I had just checked out and was leaving for the airport soon. She very rudely told me that I needed to take my sandwich elsewhere. I certainly did, but I was really upset at how rude she was, especially in light of the high level of service that I otherwise had received at this hotel. I felt like she should have been a little more tolerant of my sandwich eating or at least more polite with her request in light of the fact that my company had spent more than $10K at their hotel that week. Oh well. There are lots of other great places to stay in Tokyo that will tolerate my American-sandwich-in-the-lobby-eating ways.

Wonderful experience at the Palace Hotel. Came here last year and returned to a great reception. Restaurants - sushi and main Japanese are very very good. The Evian Spa was a wonderful experience.Hotel rooms are large and luxurious. Had a high floor and had wonderful views over the Imperial Palace. Can recommend for business and pleasure. Simples.

Having not been to Tokyo for a number of years, this hotel was quite new to us. After reading the reviews and seeing the pictures, we decided to book here. First off, the location is great. A very convenient train ride or walk to Tokyo station and even Ginza if you are up for it. It is also right across the palace gardens, great for a morning stroll.The lobby and entrance are superb, the pics do not lie, sweet spot. Not often will you find travelers pics that look good. The rooms are pretty spacious with great amenities. Gym was nice, although they do charge extra for use of the pool which is a bit of a turn off.We tried the tempura bar Tatsumi on the 6th floor which one of the best meals we had the entire trip, sublime actually. We did not have a chance to try the rest of the japanese restos on the 6th floor but I am sure they are also fantastic. The set up of the restos are amazing, really well done.This seems to be a lesser know property, but it can stand proudly among the giants, Penn, Park Hyatt, Conrad, etc. Go for it!

I stayed at this hotel for 4 nights in July. The design of the hotel is exceptional and tastefully understated with amazing artwork and furniture. I was constantly surprised at the small details that enhanced the overall experience and made my stay that much more enjoyable.
