What polished off this wonderful stay was the staff who were, without exception, excellent.I would definately book the Palace above any other deluxe 5* when I return to Tokyo.

Really luxurious hotel with spacious modern rooms (unusual for Tokyo). The staff was unbelievably responsive and attentive. I was obsessed with the lovely showers and all the many amenities the hotel offers. The toiletry freebies in the bathroom were impressive on their own! They really predicted every need. The restaurant on the hotel grounds was also delicious and had a wonderful outdoor area with torches at night which really made the meal relaxing. The concierge was very knowledgeable and the guy at the door always directed the cabs to where you want to go. Everyone at this hotel speaks English. Wonderful experience. Convenient location near the subways stations. The free wifi was a necessity.
user_name:
rachelia18
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is a 5 min walk from Tokyo station, where both the Narita airport and bullet trains come into, so it's super convenient. It's also opposite the royal palace so nice and green for Central Tokyo.The hotel is beautiful. Everything is wonderfully laid out. The rooms are spacious and full of hi-tech gadgetry.I thoroughly recommend this hotel.

I should caveat the review by pointing out that I had just stayed at the Park Hyatt in Tokyo before returning to the Palace and its hard to compete with the Park Hyatt.AT any rate, we chose the Palace Hotel for its location which is excellent - convenient access to Tokyo station, Ginza, the Imperial Palace etc. You can walk to the Otemachi station from the basement of the hotel (via the shopping arcade).We had a lovely (rather interestingly configured) room with a balcony overlooking the park.The bathrooms are well appointed (but a notch below the Park Hyatt's) as are the rooms.The pool is nicely located on an upper floor (but again, after you have bee at the pool and gym at the Park you get a little spoiled).The one thing I did not like about this hotel is the way they nickel and dime you . . . it strikes the wrong chord. Examples - the hollandaise sauce at breakfast is extra (although you pay $37 for a buffet breakfast), spa access is extra (unless pre-negotiated as part of the room rate), roll away beds are $100+ (we had 3 rooms and needed one rollaway but did without as it was a ridiculous price). Service is also not up to snuff for a hotel at this price point. The night we arrived they told us they could not commit to room service as they were very busy. Someone rethought this ridiculous position and called us back to say they could actually 'accommodate' us and provide room service. BTW, this was only at 9:30 pm. The staff at breakfast is not at all attentive.

I recently stayed twice at the Palace Hotel Tokyo, the first time for 5 nights and then again for 2 nights at the end of our Japanese holiday - I travelled with my 3 adult children. The hotel was renovated 2 years ago, and the rooms and decor are modern, and well quipped.For our first stay we had a twin Grand Deluxe room (there were only 3 of us at that stage), which didn't face the Palace - the room was spotlessly clean, extremely comfortable, well thought out - with international chargers on the desk - the highlight of the room for me was the bathroom, and wet area where the shower and bath are located - with beautiful views of Tokyo greenery and the city beyond. The amenities were luxurious and supplied plentifully. The air conditioning was quiet and very efficient. A freshly laundered sleep gown for night time was just one of the thoughtful touches this hotel supplied. Beds were very comfortable, so after a busy day out, we always felt at peace and rested inside the hotel.For our second stay we had two Deluxe Balcony rooms - these were also very comfortable, however my preference would be for the Grand Deluxe room because of the added space, and unique bathroom.Breakfast was also a highlight - the buffet was a wonderful combination of English/ American breakfast favourites, however there were some Japanese touches - Seaweed salad, a dark green freshly squeezed juice with spinach, omelettes made to order, and good espresso coffee etc etc. The breakfast set us up well for the day.The service (and I speak for all of Japan) here is superb, the concierge desk was always polite, and helpful - and went out of their way to help. Some restaurant recommendations may be on the pricey end, so check prior to going if that is a factor. Cleaning staff were discrete, and punctual - to be asked what time we would like turn down service, and for that to be adhered to for our entire stay was quite exceptional for a busy hotel. Check in and check out were swift - and the many porter staff, always there to greet you, or to help with transport.Another bonus for the hotel, is that it is situated on top of a subway station (not that you'd know it), and we travelled by subway most places, as you avoided traffic that way. Very easy to get around Tokyo.I would highly recommend this hotel, and look forward to returning one day.

Ever since I was introduced to the Palace Hotel two years ago, it has been impossible to stay anywhere else in Tokyo. Every details of the designs, the service/staff, and the food is simply memorable. As soon as you walk in, you would be welcomed by a distinct aroma. You feel like you have walked into a "homely version" of your own palace. There is staff around every corner of the hotel, anticipating your needs. The room, with the view of the palace is simply stunning. Absolutely clean, with every design details to make you enjoy the room in every corner. A beautiful spacious room with a view. The location cannot be better. Right above the Otemachi station. You are just two stops away from Ginza and even Roppongi. You must try the paper chocolate from the hotel pastry store. Bar none.

From the moment you step into the hotel you are fully aware of the tireless attention to detail that has gone into every aspect of your stay. The colour schemes and style are exquisite, the reception staff delightful and the check in service efficient. The rooms are truly stunning and the breakfast buffet area on the banks of the palace moat is inspired. The gym and pool area give stunning views over the palace and I challenge anyone not to be impressed by this iconic hotel. I will try to ensure that I stay there every time I return to Tokyo. Thank you all.

Stayed 6 nights under Unifrance sponsorship . Wonderful hotel. Polite staff. There's a 7 11 at the basement and a dozen restaurants. 12 minute walk to the Tokyo Station where the Daimaru department store is located. A lot of restaurants in that area. 25 minute walk to Ginza or 1500 yen by taxi. Shinjuku is around 2000 yen by taxi. Possible by subway but too confusing .During breakfast you can order the japanese breakfast.My room was facing the Imperial Palace and the gardens.At the airport there is a shuttle going to the hotel for 5000 yen. At the hotel don't forget to make a reservation for the shuttle as sometimes it's full .

This was my first business trip to Japan and my stay at the Palace Hotel made it very nice. It had all the amenities a western business traveler would expect and the the cultural overtones of the beautiful Japanese culture. The breakfast was amazing, the staff were kind, thoughtful and helpful. The room was spacious. I called for an iron and it was delivered within 5 minutes. The location was very nice given it was next to the Imperial Palace which gives you some peace and quiet in a tranquil setting before you go out with the brokers. Overall an excellent experience.

Large (about 500 sq.ft.), modern, comfortable room with view of the Imperial Palace gardens; courteous, helpful service and staff; outstanding breakfast buffet; most convenient location (attached to concourse to subway station with 5 lines); convenient walking distance to Imperial Palace and main railway station; moderate (by Tokyo standards) price - what could be better? Perhaps the restaurants, which were quite good, at least by hotel standards, although we ate better in carefully chosen restaurants elsewhere. All in all highly recommended.

This was the second hotel we stayed in during our visit to Tokyo in May 2014. I checked out at 12 PM from the Peninsula, and requested palace via Email (at 11AM) that i will be checking in early (at 12.30PM). Whilst they replied that they will try to keep the room ready early (but said that it was already overfull), i had made up my mind to drop my luggage and come back at 3, but on arriving at the hotel, i was pleasantly surprised that the room was indeed ready for check in! 5 Stars to the reservations team to accept my request (and it was a complimentary early check-in)The room was breathtaking with amazing views of the Imperial Palace Gardens! The bed was super comfortable and the room was super spacious! Only one grouse that the storage space for luggage was limited (but my bad as I was in Tokyo for 10 days with family, so was overloaded to the gills!).The buffet breakfast at the GRAND KITCHEN was F.A.N.T.A.S.T.I.C, No words can describe the awesome spread laid out every single day!One word for the in-room dining agents! My wife wanted to make Indian style porridge for my baby, and requested them to cook it our style (and proper instructions were given), they did it with a SMILE and made it to perfection! Further, at any point in the day, they were obliged to heat up baby milk for us as well. It saved us so much hassle!Location wise, this hotel is situated in a fantastic location (walk able distance via underground Link with the Otemachi Station (almost all lines converge at the Otemachi) just a stones throw away from Tokyo Central Station. I would definitely recommend one and all to stay in this fantastic hotel!See you then!
user_name:
Bharatravels
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: The hotel is located right in the heart of Tokyo just beside the imperial palace. There is a direct limousine bus from Narita airport to the hotel. It just a 10min taxi ride to the famous Tsjuki fish market. Another 10 minutes walk to Tokyo station. From Tokyo station to Akihabara it only 2 station away. Room is excellent and I got an excellent view.

Palace Hotel, Tokyo 10-12 June 2014 On Monday, June 4th 2014, Garuda GA-884 Boeing 777 landed on time in Narita Airport, Japan. I was in that plane. From Narita I directly went to Palace Hotel. My great experience in staying in this hotel on January 5-8th, 2014 is the main reason I came back to this hotel. The checked in process was so efficient. I arrived at the hotel check in counter around 11.45 am. Once I pronounced my family name, the reception immediately said welcome back Mr. Kadiman. Your room is ready and she handed to me the access card to the room. Before leaving my Jakarta office, my private assistance said that I can only check in around 2pm. The room was nice. It is located on 9th floor, it has a balcony with two chairs and a coffee table and from the balcony I enjoyed the beautiful view of neat gardens, ponds, pedestrians, birds and ducks of the Imperial (The Emperor) Palace. In fact, the name of the hotel I believe is determined by its location that is being a "neighbour" of The Palace. The wi-fi signal in the room and coffee shop is strong. Personally, I was feeling like working in the office. As well as a coffee shop and a western restaurant called The Grand Kitchen, in 6th floor there are Japanese and French Restaurants with many private rooms. Its very convenience venue for family and business dining. I invited my ex Indonesians students, Japanese apprentices and business partners to have lunch and dinner in the Grand Kitchens and Japanese Resto. The variety and quality of the food and beverages are excellent. The service is very effective and yet friendly. I wanted to jog and enjoy the pedestrians around the Palace unfortunately Tokyo was mostly raining during my stay. So, I enjoyed the fitness center in the Evian SPA located in 5th floor. I forgot to bring with me my sport shoes but it did not stop me from doing some physical exercises, sport shoes are availalble for rent. The concierges are very helpful. All information and helps I asked for were delivered satisfactorily.The check out process was also very efficient. It was completed within minutes. It is really a nice hotel: great scenery of the Palace, nice outdoor, neat and clean and a very effective and yet friendly services.

It was our last hotel in japan's vacationAfter some graet rooms with exelent service this one was one step further to all...the room was the best in any standart..clean ,large, cofortable,great view to the palace and the gardens..Very comfortble location on the green line of the subway..and above all the lady concearge that made evry wish to reality..maya and mey.No question Next time in tokyo im with you..

We admittedly was going to book the Peninsula first since its proximity to Ginza was second to none. But of course, it was full so we decided to stay at the Palace Hotel since they said they underwent a new renovation. Everything I would have to say was perfect. From the arrival, which I did not even touch my luggage or a door knob once, to my departure; everything was handled professionally and cordially.Some highlights1.) My mother forgot her scarf on the plane so we talked with the concierge and he said "no problem." The next day, it was neatly folded on top of my mother's bed when she got back to her room. Service like no other I would say.2.) When we asked them to store the luggage, I accidentally forgot my hat in one of the luggages. Before I was able to tell them which luggage it was, BAM all 4 luggages was in front of me. My mouth was opened wide at all this attention to service.3.) When you leave the hotel in a car/taxi, they have attendants standing all along the driveway, as you drive pass, each one bows (like you are someone important or something) though it may not seem much, it shows how much respect they show for you.The roomThe rooms have automated almost everything. From the blinds, to the curtains, to the blinds in the bathroom. The rooms have an excellent view of the imperial palace too since the other side of the hotel, facing away from the palace, is usually used as an office building so all the guests should have palace view rooms. The hotelThe hotel itself is very grand, with high ceiling entrances and a breakfast buffet every morning and it should be included in the price. They "say" that the Otemachi station is located right beneath the hotel and they would be right but… the place where you actually get on the train is like a mile away, but they did dig a tunnel from the hotel all the way to the "real" station and called it the Otemachi station. I love Japanese sweets so good thing there was a 7 eleven downstairs in the basement, cause I stocked up on my sweets for months to come!! Too bad it closes at like 10:00pm though… not like the 24 hour 7 elevens.OverallThis hotel is usually for business men, as I see them roaming around the lobby in great numbers. The service is what really astonished me here, and I would come back just for the service itself! The rooms are also great and no complaints about the room. But the service is what outshines everything, even the Lamborghini that's parked outside.

What a great base for a visit to Tokyo ! Across the street from the Imperial Palace, and a 10 minute walk from the shopping and restaurants of Ginza. A 5 minute walk from the main railway station. Friendly and attentive staff. Great Chinese and Sushi restaurants in the hotel. And a pool. I don't know how you could make this hotel any better.

Stayed in the Palace Hotel Tokyo for 6 nights in Apr. A good and comfortable hotel, though a bit pricey.The hotel is conveniently located next to the Otemachi station. You can walk to the hotel from the station through connected underground tunnels, so no problem even in rainy days. The hotel is also located about 10 to 15 mins walk to the Tokyo station, which is one of the major subway / train station in Tokyo. If you need to go to the International Forum, it's about 15 mins walk from the hotel.The area around the hotel is nice, quiet and safe. My room overlooked the Imperial Palace Park with a nice green view (please see photo). You can also find nice restaurants nearby while walking toward the Tokyo station. We also tried a few of the local food stalls near Tokyo station (under the bridge). The rooms are surprisingly spacious give the hotel is located in the heart of Tokyo. The bed was comfortable. Most of the things are automated including the curtain and were controlled by a central panel next to the bed. Free WiFi was available in the room.Staff were generally helpful and polite. Breakfast was good with a reasonable selection of choices. Personally I liked the fried beacon which was crispy and tasty. I also suggest to try their "exotic" greenish juice (which I forgot the name). Sweet and slightly sour, help my appetite at the start of the day.The hotel rate was slightly pricey, maybe we stayed there over a conference period.All in all, Palace Hotel Tokyo is a nice and comfortable hotel if you don't mind the price. If you would like a conveniently located hotel but away from the crowd, this may be one of your choices.

The Palace Hotel overlooks the Imperial Palace, and is a recently renovated, beautiful luxury hotel with phenomenal service and all the amenities. The views overlooking the Imperial Palace are especially beautiful and the breakfast and happy hour appetizers on the concierge floor are the best we've ever had.

The Palace Hotel has some of the most well designed guest rooms I've seen. Almost everything is automated from central panels, allowing you to set lighting moods, open and close shutters and shades and a host of other features. The glass walled bath in the middle of the space (with shutters for privacy as needed) is stunning. The hotels restaurants are incredible, the lobby area expansive and the staff first class. If there were a higher ranking than first, I would be glad to use it.

Staff couldn't be more obliging. All very helpful. Lovely room with lots of electrical gadgets: switches to control curtains and blinds;TV in bathroom, etc. comfy bed and great bed linen. No waiting around for a lift to our floor and lift only functions to go up if you swipe room card. Only gripe was breakfast service. Always seemed to be lots of staff rushing about but getting a refill coffee was far from easy. Apart from that very good breakfast buffet with lots of choice and always kept topped up. Eggs cooked to order so my morning omelette was lovely. Concierge was very helpful at booking restaurants outside hotel and getting a taxi organised. Disappointed when we checked out to find the hotel had charged for our room. Fortunately we had an emergency number for our tour operator and it was sorted quickly, but not what you want very early in the morning when you have a train to catch.

I stayed at the Palace Hotel Tokyo for 8 nights, they were by far the best stays!! The hotel itself is amazing, very grand and fresh. The check in took not more than 2 minutes and the pick up from the airport (arranged by the hotel) was very easy and quick. The rooms are outstanding, very much like a modern hotel in Europe, the size here was not a problem at a all. A king size bed, both a shower and tub in the bathroom, the electrical high tech Japanese toilet, oh and not to forget a small built in tv in the mirror over the sink! There is enough space to hang your clothes (8 nights don't forget) and a table to work on and eat (amazing in room food!). Free WIFI all over the hotel as a nice touch as well. The SPA and Gym were amazing, the gym was 24 hours, very clean and with a good combination of weights and cardio machines. A great selection of places to eat, both at the hotel or underneath it at the plaza centre. The location of the hotel is great, very near to the metro and walking distance to main Tokyo train station and just opposite the emperor palace and gardens. I cant wait to go back and enjoy this amazing hotel.

To say that the Palace Hotel Tokyo is a nice place to stay would be like saying that the Beatles were a pretty good band. Everything about it is grand. The interior, service and quality are all first class. The view from the balcony of our deluxe room was very impressive and the room itself was everything we had hoped for: a big, comfortable bed, excellent shower with strong water pressure, very quiet both day and night. Our room had every conceivable amenity and then some. Want to open the drapes but not get out of bed? There's a button for that. My wife and I were both were very impressed with our stay here. In fact, it gets our highest recommendation. As you may have noticed, though, there is nothing thrifty about the Palace Hotel. Our dinner at one of the hotel restaurants has the dubious honor of being the most expensive meal I've ever purchased. Although this hotel is close to the train station and subway, don't think that you won't be needing to walk much- often the train platform is quite a long way away from the station (sometimes by a half mile or so). If you're thinking of staying here then you probably won't be disappointed (unless, perhaps, you're the Queen of England).

This recently opened hotel faces the Imperial palace, right at the edge of the Marounichi district. It's five star facilities, many good restaurants and central location to the subway, Ginza and Roppongi hills works well in it favor.We arrived as a delegation at this hotel, and were greeted by the hotel manager. Check in was pre-arranged, and was thus fairly quick. Most of us checked in later in the day, but some, who had requested for early check in, received their rooms early to freshen up.The hotel lobby is grand, full of marble, and carpet and soft leather sofas. Lifts are card controlled, adding to the security for hotel guests. Cards will only take you to your floor. Rooms are very spacious and generous. My room had a king sized bed in the middle, with all the blinds, curtains and lighting control in modern control console on the bedside table. A sofa takes precedence next to the balcony window, and a round dining table sits beside it. A nice swivel chair is on the opposite side of the table. This would be a perfect place for in-room dining, if one should opt for that. There is a long table ledge stretching from the window to the red drinks cupboard. A large flat screen TV is hung on the wall. Lots of local TV channels as well as cable TV and news. The red drink cabinet houses all manner of small bottled alcoholic beverages, snacks and the usual assortment of fizzy drinks and beer. Near the door of the room is a large cupboard with an in built ledge for your roll-on luggage. However, if you are using a large check-in luggage, you'll have to find another place to store that.Carpet in the room is soft and new. The bed is semi-hard, and the sheets are relatively soft and nice. The turn down service leaves a bucket of ice in the room. The bathroom is open concept with two entry ways. There's inverted L-shaped toilet "corridor" with a large bath tub on one side, and the large single sink on the other. Lots of toiletries, including bath salt bottles, hair brushes, cotton buds and facial squares are available. On the shorter part of the L shaped corridor are the toilet, and the rain shower.The balcony is also accessible via a large sliding door. Outside, I enjoyed the fresh air and the view of canals running perpendicular to the hotel. The Imperial Palace is further to the right of my room.The room was very comfortable and more than adequate for the fussiest customer. Downstairs in the basement, I found more shops and food outlets. I enjoyed dinner in an Izakaya-themed soba restaurant. Very noisy with salary-men having a drink and dinner before heading home.In the morning or evenings, one can also head out for a run along the road that circles the Imperial palace. Kanekaze sushi has an outlet in this hotel, great for sushi lovers.A good hotel by all accounts and in a great location too. Rooms are very classy, comfortable, well thought out. Hotel staff are warm and will willingly assist you in any way possible.

Aside from the stellar location, I actually thought the room even at the lowest category was very well-planned. From the bedroom space to the cupboard that housed the minibar and snacks, everything was grand and well designed. Comfort was a given throughout. Even the newspapers clipped outside our room each morning I thought was genius in its simplicity. We stayed for 5 nights and although the rooms were great, we felt the service from the reception desk lacklustre. It was manned by an off mix of individuals, at times a little nervous and other times cold and stern. Also, the lounge chairs had so many stains on them and i was a little surprised that a hotel that did so many other things right did not see to them and expected guests to take cocktails and dine in these conditions. On the other hand,the bellhops were probably the most welcoming than any other hotel we've been to and we travel plenty. They were very well informed and much more of a delight to interact with. So in summary, the rooms are really awesome but service, a little hit and miss.

Was here on a family holiday and stayed 3 nights. The location being near Tokyo station and opposite the imperial palace grounds could not be beaten. Room was reasonably sized and comfortable enough even with an extra person in the room.Breakfast with a view of the palace was also a good way to start the morning. In fact the few days we were there, entry fees for the imperial palace was waived. Not sure why... but it a joy to wander around the palace gardens and tokyo and return to this hotel at the end of the day. Only gripe is that is a little pricey -- but u get what u pay for in this case.

I had stayed at this hotel towards the end of 2013 and was impressed. I went to Tokyo again a few weeks ago. For this second trip, I made reservations at the Park Hyatt figuring that I should check out the competition. However, as the trip approached, I realized I really wanted to go back to the Palace Hotel based on my prior experience, so I decided to go for the Palace Hotel again. I'm glad I did as I had another great experience at the Palace Hotel. Location is great being right next to Tokyo station, walking distance to Ginza and sitting on top of the Otemachi subway station that provides access to four subway lines that gets me to everywhere I need to go. It is also the only hotel literally right on the Imperial Palace grounds. It was just an amazing experience to have breakfast every morning on the hotel restaurant terrace overlooking the Imperial Palace moat where one can enjoy the imperial palace grounds with the occasional fish, ducks and even swans leisurely swimming by in the moat. It is hard to believe that the hotel is literally at the center of a 30+ million metropolitan area. As for service, I can not imagine better service, especially the service provided by the ladies at the club level lounge, including Ms. Suzuki (I hope you enjoy Manhattan this summer with our restaurant recommendations). When checking in at the club level, I was first greeted with a warm "Welcome Back", and then I was handed a bag with a bottle of contact lens solution and a nice cloths hanger that I left behind in my room six months ago. They kept my things for six months without me even asking. I was flabbergasted and totally sold on the hotel at thatcpoint as I have not had any similar experience anywhere else. It didn't hurt that I was upgraded both times, but I think I would have enjoyed my stays even without the upgrades as most rooms have good sized balcony overlooking the Imperial Palace grounds framed by Tokyo skyline. Design of rooms and common area are top notch as they were modern but also very thoroughly uniquely Japanese at the same time with no details overlooked as far as I can tell. The result is that the hotel has substantially more personality than other five star chain hotels, which is something that few modern hotels can pull off. It's difficult to convey in words, but one gets the feeling that this is a special place. I'm sure other hotels in Tokyo are nice, but all I know is that I can not say enough good things about this one.

This hotel is high-end, and it is worth every penny (or yen). We had an extremely spacious room overlooking the Imperial Palace Garden. The staff and service were exemplary. This is a beautiful hotel in a fantastic location. Definitely one of the best hotels we have ever stayed in. I would not hesitate to stay here again. We absolutely loved this hotel.

We stayed 3 nights at the Palace Hotel last week on the last lag of our 2 weeks holiday. True to its name - Palace - we were treated like royalty the minute we arrived at the hotel in a taxi to the time the airport limousine bus pulled out of its driveway 3 days later.Our club room was on the top floor, Level 23. It was very spacious with balcony complete with 2 sun chairs & table, directly overlooking the moat of the Imperial Palace. The bathroom was beautifully designed and well-stocked with luxurious amenities.The Club Lounge is located on Level 19 & it's one of the best lounges we have been to. It even has a sun terrace! There is a wide variety of drinks available during happy hours including draft beer on tap and canapés. It's a great place to relax & have pre-dinner drinks. We had dinner at Grand Kitchen on our first night & the food was so good that we went back the next night to have something different & it was as good as the previous night.Location of the hotel cannot be any better. 5 minutes walk to Tokyo Station & 20 minutes to Ginza and the Imperial Palace right at your doorstep. Would have no problem recommending the Palace Hotel to anyone travelling to Tokyo!TIPS: If you are travelling around Japan and Tokyo is the start & last city, stay at the Palace Hotel on your last lag as you will probably not stay at another hotel as luxury as the Palace.Request for the club room with balcony. It's worth it!

Writing this review brings me joy, because of the memories it brings back to me. Everything about this hotel is classic beauty, from the woods to the flowers to the sculptures to the elevators! We did reserve a club level room which undoubtedly enhanced our experience. As we went to check in, and the lobby level clerk brought up our reservation, he said, "Oh Sir, you have a separate check-in in the Club Lounge on the 19th floor. He then had someone escort us up there. From then on, we were in the hands of the delicate and beautiful Shoko and the rest of the staff, who could not be more helpful and wonderful. The club lounge was a wonderful place for both happy hour and breakfast. Happy hour included wonderful drinks and excellent draft beer, with appetizers and salad that would easily have substituted for dinner. The tomatoes in the salad were farmer's market tasty and will make it very hard for me to tolerate what passes for a tomato in the USA. Breakfast, which we were told would not be particularly sumptuous, had everything we wanted - great coffee, fresh-squeezed orange and grapefruit juice, wonderful croissants and pastries with flaky crust like the best Parisian cafe, perfect scrambled eggs and breakfast. The lounge also has a balcony with a panoramic view of the Imperial Palace and gardens, and we even got to see Mt. Fuji in the distance.Our room was spacious and elegant, our balcony was spacious with comfortable chairs and table for enjoying the outside. Amenities were abundant and opulent. I'd go back in a minute.
user_name:
Michael K
Salt Lake City, Utah

review_body: I last stayed at The Palace 20 odd years ago - it was the typical expat business hotel, long grey corridors and plenty of beige. It's changed: the hotel and indeed this area of the city, have had a makeover. The hotel tries - and succeeds - to capture an element of Japan, whether it be in the relatively minimal rooms, flowers (sensational) or just the general decor. This is not a Four Seasons or a Peninsula, and all the better for it. If you want an international hotel of 5 star standard (or more), but want a change from the usual suspects, then this is the hotel to stay at. Best rooms gave balconies and overlook the Imperial Palace. You won't be disappointed.

The Palace Hotel is undoubtedly one of the best hotels in Tokyo. The staff is friendly, courteous and very helpful. The rooms were large, clean, well stocked and very comfortable. The fitness center is also great - and one of the best hotel gyms i have seen - good for both a good cardio workout or weights.There is an underground link to Tokyo Station, which will just about bring you anywhere you wish to go! I stayed for business and eventually extended my stay with the hotel. Highly recommended.

It was my first time to the region, and I was particularly nervous about traveling alone to a non-English speaking country. I chose the Palace Hotel not only because of the great reviews, but the multiple comments about their English-speaking staff and amazing customer service. I can't say enough wonderful things about the hotel and the staff. The hospitality is unparalleled. Everyone from the valet to the receptionist to the restaurant staff was genuinely warm, courteous and wonderfully helpful. My double room was exquisite - luxuriously comfortable and spacious. The attention to detail was incredible. The bathroom was stunning and spacious (by American standards) with a jacuzzi-size bathtub, bidet (with warmed toilet seat), a small flat tv built into the bathroom mirror, high-end toiletry products, and baby-bottom soft bathrobes! I had a lovely view of the Imperial Palace grounds from my room, as the Imperial Palace was literally across the street from the hotel. Speaking of convenience, the hotel is only walking distance from the amazing Marunouchi restaurants and shops and Tokyo station, making all of Tokyo easily accessible.I can't recommend it strongly enough, other than to say I would give it more than 5 stars if I could. It was by far one of the best hotel experiences of my life! No question, it will be my first choice to stay the next time I visit Tokyo.

Undoubtedly one of the top hotels in Tokyo, if not the best! Excellent location with only a short walk to the Palace, Tokyo Station, Ginza etc. Rooms are very large by Japanese standards and furnishings are excellent. My room was on one of the club floors, offering access to the top floor club with patio--an excellent perk with a truly phenomenal staff and excellent amenities. I found the staff to be very helpful/polite and every aspect of my stay was excellent. I will absolutely be back next time I am in Tokyo.

Wow, I recently traveled to Japan with my two teenage children, childhood dream since watching Shogun with my mum when I was 12. We stayed for 4 nights at this amazing hotel, first class food and a room view to die for. we had a room on the 15th Floor which overlooked the imperial palace complex with the greenery of the park and the backdrop of the city.This hotel has its own metro stop, with a shopping centre as well and great views from the swimming pool and wellness centre on the 5th floor.Very polite staff and impeccably clean, this i s a very modern and ultra cool hotel.

This Hotel is very luxurious with views out over the Imperial Palace. It would appear that every room gets a view. The rooms are large and have the quietest air conditioners I have come across. There is a DVD player in all rooms and you can even play your iPhone through the TV speakers. International power sockets are built in. Bathrobes are provided as are nightshirts. There is nothing they haven't thought of!!My only criticism is there was no Japanese food offered in the buffet breakfast. It was a very Western affair.
After changing from the Cerulean in Shibuya to this hotel, we could really relax and enjoy Tokyo.Great rooms, amazing views, nice breakfast, complementary gym, excellent location.Highly recommended!

Excellant service, a 4min walk to Tokyo station, Stunning city view. The teppanyaki with waygu beef melts in the mouth. Everywhere from the room to service is top notch. The room size is huge for Japanese standard

We spent a total of 3 nights at the Palace going to and from Japan. The location across from the Imperial Palace is beautiful, particularly with blossoms in full swing. We found the rooms beautiful and spotlessly clean-- an upgrade on the third night to a higher class room was much appreciated. Staff were uniformly helpful and pleasant.One small quibble: on 2 separate occasions eating in the lobby bar (one lunch and one dinner) food delivery was delayed so that the first person had finished eating by the time the last person received their meal. Not sure why this would have happened especially on the second visit as they were not terribly busy. This does not detract from the overall impression of the hotel but I would be interested if others have had similar concerns.

Wonderful stay at Palace hotel in Tokyo. My wife and I never cease to be amazed of the quality of service you receive in Japan and still the Palace manages to exceed expectations. Location is hard to beat right in front of the imperial Palace. I enjoyed running around the palace almost every day and it is by itself a memory to be cherished (a perfect 5k trail for those athletically inclined). With tokyo station at walking distance it goes without saying that you can get anywhere in the city quite easily. Rooms are spacious and modern. Breakfast buffet is lavish and delicious. Gym and swimming pool are top notch. The concierge recommended great non-touristy restaurants which we loved. In general what you would expect from a 5 star hotel and more. You certainly have to pay for it but in this case we felt it was totally justified.
user_name:
fidelio2011
New York City, New York

review_body: Unbelievable hotel. I used to stay at the Imperial for years, but my colleagues started staying at the Palace and suggested I do the same. This place exceeded every expectation that I could have from the room, to the service, to the view, to the location, etc. Top notch and worth every penny that I spent. Also, love the fact that it is so close to Tokyo Station.
user_name:
VKShier
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The Palace Hotel is a large, modern, luxury hotel which is literally 1 traffic light across from one of the main gates of the Imperial Palace. It is centrally located in Tokyo and on top of the C13b exit of Otemachi station. Which itself is 1 stop away from Tokyo station. Pros: This hotel has all the normal top notch facilities of a luxury hotel. The rooms are large, modern, lovely, and well equipped. With cable and satellite TV in the bedrooms. And also in the bathroom. And free wifi everywhere. There is a bountiful and sumptuous morning brunch buffet which serves a yummy and wide selection of food which includes an egg station and very attentive, courteous and professional staff. However the over-whelming PLUS of this hotel is the staff. This place probably has the BEST CONCIERGE staff in the world. I was at the Palace Hotel for a business trip. And no matter what problems I had. The concierge staff sorted it out promptly, knowledgeably and with a smile. Need to confirm a reservation with an obscure local Japanese restaurant? No problem! Got a friend who is sick in hospital and needs cheering up? No problem! The concierge sent some wonderfully happy yellow and white cheerful flowers which brightened up an unhappy and sick woman in pain in a Tokyo hospital bed. Got a strange and delicate package that needs to be sent half-way around the world on a weekend? No problem! The staff magically knew the best and safest way to send delicate items by courier around the world. Even at the weekend when the post office was not open!But the most impressive thing I found, was the sheer dedication, competence and sense of pride and honour among the concierge staff. I asked for directions one Monday morning to go see the Currency Museum at the Bank of Japan. No problem! The concierge said it was a few stops away on the Hibiya line. Unfortunately he later found out that the museum shuts on Mondays. But he could not tell me as I had already set off to the museum. He tried his best to contact me, but alas, I was already on the train and could not be reached. When I returned from the "now known to be closed" Currency Museum, the concierge staff were incredible and had of their own volition and sense of honour and decency, bought me a lovely and tasty hotel Mango cream-cheese cake to say sorry for their tiny little oversight in missing the detail of the Currency Museum's opening hours. I was very impressed. There was no need for them to be so sorry, but I was deeply touched by their sense of duty and honour to their guests. Cons: None really. This hotel is not cheap. But then, what do you expect for a luxury hotel? In summary, the Palace Hotel has probably got the best hotel staff in the whole of Tokyo. I congratulate and salute the wonderful hotel staff of Assistant Chief Concierge Yuichi Hoshino and the exceptional team of Mai Hashitani, Kanako Honda and others at the hotel concierge and reception desks.To conclude, my stay in Tokyo was transformed by the wonderful staff at the Palace Hotel and I would happily stay at the Palace Hotel again. I cannot recommend or commend the exceptional staff of the Palace Hotel highly enough. The staff do great credit to their country and people by showing such superb hospitality and service to visiting travellers from afar. A job well done! Keep up the good work!

The hotel is perfect. Location, decor throughout, staff, room sizes, bed linen , bathroom towels, food.We had 2 nights here post cruise. We had selected the hotel for its location for central tokyo whilst in a good position for visiting via subway any of the other areas.It's adjacent to the Imperial Palace which is number one sight seeing spot. As a unexpected suprise but very kind consideration we were upgraded to one of the main suites. It was mesmerising and the wow factor was off the scale .The key point however from a general perspective is that the whole hotel is first class . We shall return irrespective of room grade!!

Beautifull settings and decors, too many employees for each task ( you're almost in their way) outrageous prices at bars and restaurants, poor 5-7 at the club floor but excellent breakfast, the only bed during our 3 weeks trip that was not confortable. Our room was a good size, ameneties complete, soundproof and good size wardrobe. Close to lots of restaurants, shops, train station and facing the imperial palace.  It was not our only experience in a LHW but it was surely one that left us with mixed feelings. Surely this hotel charges for its location and history...who wouldn't. But to our taste, it was just that bit too much and all their small attentions did not made up for it.

I stayed at a nearby hotel, but spent a lot of time here holding meetings and dining. It is a great location, with stunning views of the Imperial Palace. We ate in the restaurant (lobby) but can't remember the name. The food was excellent. Nicely appointed hotel, attentive staff. Highly recommended

I was supposed to stay in Shinjuku but all hotels were booked. I ended up here, but this was the best part of my trip - going back to the hotel room after a day's itinerary. Superb service and Ice cubes waiting beside my bed (can't drink without ice). Love!

Quite the last word in luxury in downtown Tokyo. If you're a traveller who likes to arrive in a fleet of shiny black limos with a flourish of trumpets, this is your hotel. However, if like me, you liked the friendly, welcoming atmosphere of the old Palace, you will be disappointed. Can't fault the hotel for luxurious comfort, but I felt that I had wandered by accident into a club of which I was not a member. Rather antiseptic and too cool.

I stayed at the Palace for a couple of days on business. Beautifully appointed and with great bars and restaurants, some overlooking the Imperial Palace Gardens, it is also well located. Just 3 mins walk for subway and connections down town. A bit more expensive than the usual hotels I stay in (the Tokyo hotels were full this week due to high school graduations and also Sakura season visitors), I would love to come back.

We made a last minute reservation here on our way to Palau. This was our 2nd visit and again we were quite happy with our choice.The location is perfect and the concierge was most helpful.We loved the tempura restaurant but were disappointed in the sushi restaurant. There were a number of sushi selections that were unavailable and the portions were tiny.

In the quiet area surrounding Tokyo Station there's no better place than this gorgeous property. Overlooking the stunning Imperial Gardens and a short walk to the train station, it is perfect for business or pleasure. Think the rooms are a better value than the Park Hyatt, and it's easier to get in and out of the hotel and to walk around the surrounding area. The rooms are also better appointed and more modern than the Park Hyatt, and there is a pleasant lounge on the main floor that gets pleasantly busy around cocktail hour. Highly recommend this as one of the nicest hotels anywhere in the world for a city hotel.

We arrived at tokyo palace and were astounded by how beautiful our standard room was. Pure luxury for 2 backpackers. The staff couldnt have done anything more for us. They even gave us a room for the wholeday as our train wasnt until late at night. Perfect stay in jaisalmer. Thank you!

Stayed first time in the Palace, Tokyo, for a three day business trip. Location is excellent in proxmity both to the business district as well as adding a bit of a 'holiday' feeling due to proximity and overlook of the Imperial Palace and Gardens. So make sure you get a room high enough up on the respective side of the hotel.Rooms were excellent. Very spacious, modern design, new, big bathroom. Staff is extremely polite and helpful. Great service. Tried the gym a couple of times, which is also very modern with very friendly staff. Concierge service great in organising a couple of things for me.So it was very worthwhile trying a new 5 star location and Tokyo, and definetly one I will come back to.

The location of the Palace Hotel is very convenient. A short walk from the train station, right next to the Imperial Palace and gardens. The rooms are very comfortable and classy ! The service in the hotel was extremely good and the staff was very helpful and polite. Definitely a place to come back to !!

This is a very impressive property, right up there with the best in terms of service, room design, common areas and choice of dining options. Tokyo struggles to provide the senior business traveller with good choice. The ageing 5 star options of the Imperial and Dai-Ichi are tired and even the non-smoking areas and floors reek. The Palace offers good value for a LHW and sits between the fading grandeur of those mentioned and the pricey Four Seasons, Shangri-La and Aman. Trust this hotel and it won't disappoint. New, sleek, spacious and super design sitting with spectacular views over the Palace and next to the wonderful district of Maranouchi.

Excellent service and location. Rooms are new, spacious, clean and comfortable. Concierge was helpful with suggestions, documents and reservations. Beds were comfortable as well. Breakfast buffet was good - not spectacular. Connection to subway system under hotel was very convenient - no need to step outside. Superb location for exploring Tokyo by metro.

The rooms have all been updated recently and some of them have spectacular views of the Palace grounds. From the moment you cab pulls up, the hospitality starts flowing. Super fast check and the on site dining options are very good. This place is a reasonable value and just a short walk from the big Tokyo train station.

My first visit to Tokyo I stayed at this wonderfull hotel. Great view from nice room. Top location next to imperial garden. Extremely friendly staff. Two days was too short to use evian Spa or gym. Only negative point is that you have to Pay separately for swimmingpool.

After trying every other form of Japanese accommodation (Love Hotel, Capsule, Business, Ryokan) I decided to go high end in Tokyo. There is no part of this experience that wasn't exquisite. I've never experienced the level of service offered at the Palace. The room, the linens, the view, the restaurants... Nothing was less than perfect. One example: I went to the lounge for afternoon tea and chose the chocolates and tea. 5 handmade chocolates and peppermint tea with the most perfect view. I nibbled those chocolates slowly, savouring every bite. It took almost 2 hours. However, every 15 minutes the staff would refresh my tea. No questions. No fuss. Just perfect, intuitive service.

This hotel is the ultimate in luxury! The staff is amazing and accomodating. The shops in the basement are five star for perfumes, soaps, flowsers even bridal gowns! I loved this hotel and its location. The view from my room was of the palace and it was amazing. The food at the restaurants is great but, the drinks at the bar weren't necessarily the best. It was my first trip to Tokyo on business and definitely made an amazing mark on my memory! The room was clean and well stocked with the great toletries and when I was getting ready to leave after a long day at work I cam home to find they had folded ALL my clothes and all I needed to do was put them in the suitcase! When they say 5 star! It's FIVE star. The other surprises was the piano lounge in the lobby where you could hear "oldies" and "classic Sinatra". The views, the service, the design of the hotel, the tv in the soak tub bathroom, I just LOVED it all! I was there for three weeks and have to say I didn't want leave. An unforgettable stay, in an unforgettable staff and an unforgettable country! Loved it!
user_name:
NY_ShoeGirl
New York City, New York

review_body: Superb indeed for 3 reasons - luxury, location and price. The interior is 5 star, as is the service. Fantastic rooms with views over the Palace and grounds. The rooms come with fabulous bathrooms, everything electronic, lots of little extra luxuries, and a quiet room with a comfy bed for the massively jet lagged. Location - next to Maranouchi (5 mins walk) and overlooking the Imperial Palace...could not have wanted for more. Price - with the Yen at 170 to the £, it's a bargain (as is much of Japan right now). Somehow we got rooms for £200 / night, which is the best I've ever managed in this country.

Great location. It is directly connected to Tokyo station with shops and malls just underground. Plus, it is just across the road of the palace park. If you are a 'keep fit' freak, a 5km jog around the scenic palace park would be a chosen activity.Services are outstanding. It is the sort of quiet courtesy that is most suited for business travelers. Hotel staff in other cities often confused this with the gregarious sorts. They should not assume that all hotel guests wish to be spoken to. You will have a large TV screen in your room and all channels are in HD. When compared to good hotels in other cities in the East Asian region, this is a bliss. The hot and cold water mixers in the shower works perfectly.The system pays real attention to the details. But for some reasons, power plug converters are not readily installed.

Saturday, January 4th 2014, I and my wife took off around 3am from Cengkareng International Airport, Indonesia by using Garuda GA 844. Initially, we were mad due to the 3.5 hours delay. Though it was annouced nicely but waiting for so long in the lounge was a tough test. The plane was the most modern and brand new Boeing 777. The seat on the business class is fantastic. In a single press of a button, the seat will smoothly transformed into a fully flat bed. The food and the service are among the top quality service like a 5-star hotel. Indonesian and Japanese food are available on the menu. The selection of musics and movies are plenty. Arrived in Narita Airport. We purposely selected the limousine bus service from the airport to The Palace Hotel, Tokyo. In our previous trips we tried train and taxis. The bus gave us a great travelling experience in the middle of Japan winter. We arrived and warmly welcomed by the doormen of Palace Hotel, Tokyo. The checked in process was so efficient. The room was on the 10th floor. We can enjoy the scenery of surrounding. We were amazed by the tidiness and the cleanliness. Perhaps, the top one from these two measurement. Choices of food are so wide from the coffee shop, lounge and some up scaled restaurants. We can also easily walk to the trains subway station. Plenty of selections of traditional Japanese cuisines around the stations. Bookshops and giftshops are also available. I and my wife stayed 4 days and 3 nights in Palace Hotel, Tokyo. A great experience. In short, Palace Hotel is so suitable both for business and holiday. The only not so positive point is that one shall be ready to dig his/her pocket deeper. Though it is not so much differ if compare to similar 5-star hotel that I experienced in big cities of Japan.

We stayed at the Palace Hotel during the first week of January, and we loved it! It is very hard to find a hotel in Tokyo that comes with a balcony, and with such great views. The room itself was top notch, and with morning and evening service. The complimentary gym and pool were well-equipped, although a bit smaller and without the classes that are offered at the Park Hyatt (not complimentary). The underground walkway connecting the hotel to the Otemachi station was convenient, although it is a good 7 to 10 minute walk before you actually get anywhere near a platform. The only complaint we had for this hotel was the lackluster breakfast. For 3500 yen, we expected a little more than what was essentially a continental breakfast. Staff were always available, and most spoke very good English. We will be staying here again!

Stayed here for 4 days on a business trip in November. Excellent rooms, facilities and particularly service. English fluently spoken. Truly a 5 star hotel. Perfect location on subway line and also close to a main JR station. 100 yards from Palace grounds which are well worth a visit.

Opened in less than two years, this hotel is well equipped with not only the best facilities but also the best service minded staffs, and everyone speaks English fluently.Bedroom was equipped with the latest sophisticated systems such as bathroom mirror tv, motorized curtain and blind, and the latest designed automatic flush toilet!You will also find many tasty restaurants in the hotel arcade and a 7-11 too.We stayed in many 5-star hotels in Tokyo, but from now on, Palace hotel will be our only choice of stay.

I stayed here for the first part of my trip to Japan and it was fantastic. The staff all speaks good English and as a result, you feel very comfortable immediately (trust me, that is not a given in Nippon). Rooms are very nice and they are very committed to cleanliness (whcih is a Japanese trait; we should take notes).IT is also in a perfect and very quiet location. It is basically in the middle of the 7 or 8 places you really need to see. It was very easy to head to Ginza or change gears and go to Shibuya. IT is in the business area (one of them) and thus very, very quiet. I would stay here again if/when I come back to Tokyo (btw, if you haven't been to Tokyo and are debating a trip.....quit thinking and GO! It's a Bucket List city).

In the past 10 years, there are several additions to the Tokyo top hotel list. Most of them belong to international hotel chains (Ritz Carlton, Peninsula, Mandarin Oriental, etc) but this one is a genuine Japanese hotel. Before the renovation, this hotel was a tired old establishment whose location was the only reason to stay. Now modern amenity, good size room and good service were added. Many subway lines stop within a short walk distance. It is a great choice especially if you are a business traveler to do something with mainstream Japanese companies in the area.

This is a fantastic hotel, though I guess Japan is a Number 1 country for a lot of travel experiences.Location: great for both business and pleasure. View of Imperial Park!Rooms: perfect size, pleasant, brand new, all the amenitiesService: very professional and thoroughCleanliness: just one anecdote - once walked in during the cleaning of my room. The whole bed was torn apart, no doubt in order to thoroughly inspect and cleanRestaurant: deliciousCriticisms? Ok, just to say something: was not thrilled with a round table for work and chairs on which it is hard to put clothes (really nitpicking here...). Japanese restaurant too pricey... Excellent stay!

The Palace Hotel was recommended by a good and knowledgable source, and boy did he get it right! Before booking, I compared it with other five-star properties in the key areas of Tokyo, but kept coming back to the Palace.It's hard to believe that many of the five/six star properties at 50% or 100% higher prices are going to be much better than this. The rooms are very large and immaculately presented, with a large balcony (we had a Deluxe King with Balcony). Reception, concierge, and restaurant service is all terrific, everything you would expect from a five-star hotel.For us the location was superb. We were there to visit areas such as Roppongi, Ginza, Harajuku, Shinjuku, etc, and most if not all of these were 15-20 minutes or less away on one of the five lines from Otemachi subway station just outside the hotel. And getting to/from Narita or other locations further afield is a breeze from Tokyo Station, a mere 10+ minutes walk or 700Yen taxi ride away.Highly recommended. I wouldn't hesitate to rebook here when I next visit Tokyo.

I have stayed at the Palace a couple of timess now and it has excellent amenities, staff/service and proximity to major business in Tokyo and Tokyo Station. It is a first class hotel and is newer than some of the other top hotels in the vicinity. Highly recommend for business travellers. Rooms overlook the expansive Imperial Palace which is always impressive in the middle of Tokyo.

The old Palace Hotel was somewhat "passé" and was a reminder of a time when there were very few international hotels in Tokyo and certainly not to the modern international standard .The new Palace Hotel has been competely reconstructed and it is now one of the best, if not the best, luxury hotel in Tokyo.The location is prime, facing the Imperial Palace, right in the center of the city.The service is immaculate, the rooms are tastefully decorated with a large balcony facing the large esplanade in front of the Imperial Palace.It is a great experience .

I have stayed in this hotel since 2007 for about 5 times now and the standard keeps the same, this hotel has a service which in my view no other hotel can beat. In every way, from front desk to concierge or restaurant staff or the bell boys/ladies they make you feel like the emperor itself. the variety of restaurants and bars are outstanding, about 5-10. It almost feels you are part of a small village. Breakfast is the best and similar to a US dining. In the weekends there is a waiting line because locals know how good this is for breakfast and lunch! The lounge area is huge and easy to have a quick drink or bite. Try to Imperial bar, but beware that smoking is still allowed in that area. The rooms are huge, the bathrooms wonderful and very easy to take a shower with a lot of space! Last but not least, the bus transfer from and to the airport is very convenient. I tried the gym this year for the first time and of course, quality all around. This is hard to match for other hotels!!

I was in Tokyo for business and had many visits to the old Palace Hotel prior to 'renovation'. If you liked what was there before, this is certainly a different hotel now, compatible with Tokyo's other top hotels. It lost it's Japanese touch, which I regret very much, but that aside, I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Location is (and remains!) great, and would suggest to pay a little more and get the room with a balcony facing the palace. Rooms were very functional, only missed a coffee maker which one would expect in a hotel of this standing. I arrived on an early flight and was able to check-in at 10am without an extra charge although the hotel was full. Breakfast was excellent, and there is an outstanding choice of restaurants. Do book in advance as they are all relatively busy, but that is Tokyo! Service was up to the level one would expect in a Leading Hotel and throughout my stay there is actually nothing that went wrong, absolutely nothing! Location next to Tokyo station is very convenient and excellent shopping in Marunouchi with unique boutiques, and Ginza is only a short stroll away.

The hotel services are excellent. It is near Tokyo station and can walk to many famous places. The room and hotel are very clean and modern. It is a worth hotel to go in Tokyo. And the staff are very helpful.

I stayed at the Palace Hotel in Tokyo about a month ago and must say this is a very nice hotel. But what made it stand out was the awesome service of the hotel staff. The ladies in the executive club were very helpful. In fact after checking out I forgot my reading glasses in the lounge and one of the staff chased me down and fought the taxi at a traffic light to return the glasses. Definitely above and beyond... Well done and very much appreciated.

The original Palace Hotel was established in 1961, it was a modern hotel for its time. The new rebuilt hotel carries on its un-mistakenly Japanese traditional hospitality of refinement and serenity within this modern architecture set on its original scenery. It retains the significant postal address being the very centre of the capital Tokyo facing the imperial palace.The drive in entrance is recessed by granite columns and low horizontal ‘Aji’ stonewalls arriving under a large mirror stainless steel ceiling sculpture with a greeting counter + a backlit onyx wall. Guests are led through a seating area with view to the bar, lobby lounge on the left, walk by a large display cabinet of gold leaved paper cut, face the floor to ceiling glass window looking at the waterscape + greenery view, turn right through the lift lobby before getting to the reception desk. If the guests wander off behind the concierge desk, there is this elongated lounge with the continuing waterscape + greenery view and stone sculpture pieces.The new interior design weaves this original scenery of water, greenery and natural light with the contemporary threads of stylized flowers + leaves pattern, green apple color, ebony veneer, warm grey stone, traditional white tile work depicting the blossoms, minimal bronzed pendants and the many artwork pieces through out guest areas as well as guestrooms.I have stayed twice in this hotel this year. I prefer the guestroom that has a more formal plan of fully enclosed bathroom and opens into a balcony with a floor lantern. The color palette of dark walnut veneer, gloss white + butter color fabric wall panels, taupe leaves pattern carpet, striking mirrored sun flower yellow gloss bar unit + accessories and cream stone in the bathroom is surprisingly comfortable to my eyes.I have enjoyed the Japanese breakfast room service looking at morning skyline, the first Spanish ‘fideua’ I had at all day dining terrace at dusk and the convenience of getting across the road for morning walk around the imperial palace moats as well as the greeting citrus scent of the guest lobby and its attentive front office staffs helping to book train tickets and tables at outside restaurants.

I have been here on business and later with my family (2 little kids). This place is pure excellence. Spacious lobby, smooth check-in, great breakfast buffet, very kind staff, large rooms, absolutely clean everywhere. The location is very convenient, just a short stroll away from Tokyo Station. Lovely to walk in the Imperial Palace gardens (entrance on the other side of the road). I was surprised by the quietness inside despite the location in a crowded noisy district like Marunouchi and the proximity to a very busy main street. We liked this hotel very much and would go back at once.

We stayed here three nights at the beginning of our two week trip to Japan, and this hotel really set the bar high. We stayed in a club level room and were very pleased with the size of the space and the high quality of all the finishings. The room is enormous and if that wasn't enough, there was a rather nice and spacious terrace to take in the amazing views of the palace (partial view but that's ok) below. The bed was extremely comfortable and was the only non-rock hard bed we had our entire time in Japan. Everyone who works here is extremely helpful and they rush to make sure you have everything you need at all times. The club level was great with breakfast and light afternoon drinks/food included. Having that there just made the whole day convenient and the food was also quite tasty. There is also a nice patio off the club and we had wine brought out to us while the sun went down, which was really nice. Originally, we weren't too sure about the location but we actually found it very convenient with the subway right around the corner. It was also nice to take a walk around the palace at night with the legions of joggers. I could have stayed another week at this hotel just to soak up the luxury and maybe try out the spa which looked really nice when I scoped it out.

Booked 2 nights at The Palace Hotel, Club Level room prior to our Silversea cruise from Tokyo to Hong Kong. All I can say is what a way to start our vacation! Initial impression upon walking in the door was "Wow! Modern, sleek, beautiful!"Upon arrival, we were greeted by staff at the door who took our hand luggage & escorted us to the check-in desk. The desk clerk noted our Club Level reservation & said we were to check in on the 19th floor. A bellman escorted us up the elevator where we were greeted by the Club's concierge. We were given a welcome drink & were asked to be seated in the lounge while they completed our registration. The bellman took our bags to the room while we registered.Afterward, we were escorted to our room by the concierge--wow! How beautiful--same as the lobby. This room has everything you could want! The bathroom is very spacious, the shower is amazing. We had a fabulous view of the Imperial Gardens from our window. Every amenity you can think of is here.We enjoyed the breakfast, afternoon tea, & cocktails & canapés in the club lounge. The staff there are very attentive & friendly. Last night, we enjoyed a cocktail in the lobby bar where they had piano/sax playing. It was a very busy spot (@ 10pm), but the staff were friendly & attentive.It was a very wonderful stay.

I can't say enough nice things about this hotel. The location, across from the Imperial Gardens is superb, and it's right next to a centrally located subway stop. The building itself is just gorgeous. The rooms were beautiful, serene and so comfortable. We had a lovely terrace that was a great spot to have a cup of coffee in the morning or just to sit and read. And the bathrooms! Wow! I felt so spoiled,, they were spacious and elegant. We were there for 5 days and I would have been content to stay for 2 weeks. The staff is terrific. They work really hard to make sure you are comfortable. The concierges spoke fluent English, although the google translate app was a lifesaver ! We had the buffet breakfast every morning. It is just delicious with a wide array of choices both western and Japanese. My only complaint is that although there is a ton of staff in the morning, they seem very disorganized, particularly for Japan, it took forever almost every morning to get coffee. I always complain about the kiting in rooms as it never seems to be what I want. For example, the lighting over the closets was really dim . But, these are minor annoyances for a true five star hotel. I hope I get to go back there soon!
user_name:
JacksonHoleSkiier
New York City, New York

review_body: As frequent visitors to Tokyo, we have stayed at various nice hotels in the city, Mandarin Oriental, Grand Hyatt, Ritz Carlton, Conrad. A friend recommended Palace Hotel for our anniversary and my travel agent got us a nice deal of air+ hotel package, so we gave it a try.Everything was better than perfect, even before we arrived. I emailed to inquire about airport transfer and it was answered promptly and precisely. Concierge team writes and speaks very good English and is extremely professional and helpful.Our room was at 17th floor with a balcony which is spacious, perfect for hanging out on an autumn night. The room, like everything else of the hotel, is tastefully appointed with a quiet luxurious ambience. Strong wifi available for free in the whole property. The hotel is attached directly to Otemachi Metro station which is conveniently the interchange station for various major lines. It's a 10-min walk to JR station. The Royal Palace is virtually right across street so you are not to expect many small alleys and local shops in the neighbourhood. The whole area is decent and very well maintained to a really high standard. We had very enjoyable night jogs along the jogging trail around the royal garden,joining by a lot of locals. We didnt try breakfast this time as the package didnt include it and there are so many choices when it comes to Tokyo. The gym is amazing!Would definitely come back for our next trip, IF, the price remains comparable to other 5-star hotels.....

Our stays in Tokyo have always been at very nice hotels, as standards in Japan are so high, but none quite as impressive as The Palace. The rooms are beautifully appointed, the location is great for exploring Marunouchi, Ginza and beyond and the view over the Imperial Gardens with Shinjuku twinkling in the distance is lovely. And I can't remember having such a restful night's sleep in such a long time...the room was utterly soundproof and the blackout blinds were just that. Very much looking forward to a return visit.

Perhaps one of the best hotels I've stayed in. Location was great. Tokyo metro station at the basement of hotel. Restaurants and seven eleven store also at the basement. Exceptional service by the hotel staff, always ready to help. I will definitely recommend and surely in the future go back to this hotel.

This is a review of the New Palace Hotel in Tokyo – it was reopened last year after being closed for reconstruction since 2009 – my goodness what a change there has been. I stayed frequently in the old Palace but this was my first visit to the new version and how impressed I was.The new Palace Hotel has gone very much upmarket, making it perhaps the best hotel in Tokyo, in my opinion. The treatment of guests from arrival at the front door to delivery to room is impeccable and laced with traditional Japanese good manners – what a pleasure after what one gets in Europe and the US in similar establishments.The room (mine was on the 11th floor with a side view of the Imperial Palace) was absolutely peerless, roomy and spotless. All that you could ask for is provided and I cannot see what anybody would need to pay extra for a Club Floor room (where I normally stay) other than, perhaps, the use of the 14th floor Club Room. It seems to me that the hotel offers so much that the Club Lounge is rendered pointless. Really – the room is probably one of the best I have ever stayed in and is at least as good as the Tokyo Shangri La, which is also of very high quality and which I reviewed previously. The problem with the Shangri La is that it does not have the Palace view and facilities.So many restaurants are available that they are too many to mention – the food is excellent and beautifully presented in those we did eat at. A word of warning – with the Yen at its current value, the hotel food outlets are very expensive – I suggest that you pay a visit to the franchised food outlets in the Basement, including an excellent Irish Pub, which offer much better value.I did not use the Spa with its exceptional pool but my colleague who did tells me it is excellent.Internet is free for unlimited kit and lightning fast – what a pleasure! The business centre is fine but you have to pay for everything which I did not like.All in all, it must be a contender for the best hotel in Tokyo – very, very impressive – you must give it a try.

I have been to many hotels around the world but there is simply nothing like this! From your arrival, to the smallest details, this hotel brings service and hospitality to a totally different level. The view of the Imperial Palace gardens on your spacious balcony is worth the steep price. And yet after realizing what the hotel is striving for, price becomes secondary. This is Japan as it should be experienced. I had a great morning run around the moat of the Imperial Palace and the hotel's proximity to it is a major plus. A subway stop is just an escalator down. Rooms are spacious, bathroom is great. The artwork is truly fine. The downside? The hotel breakfast buffet is hohum. While trying to be different, the same food each day can be tiresome. But the other dinig outlets? That's another spectacular story to tell. When in Tokyo, this is the hotel to be in!

I have very high expectations when I come to Japan. As such, I expect nothing but perfection, esp at the prices you can pay in this city for a decent room. Read a few reviews about this hotel and really have no complaints. Rooms were great, view uncompromising and the lighting system not at all difficult to master! Not quite sure what others were having difficulty with! The only complaint I had was breakfast - but the one thing I never have high expectations for in Japan is a western breakfast. They just cannot do it right. When in Rome! Hubby had a superb Japanese breakfast, but they couldn't even toast my toast today. I would recommend that u take the buffet, despite the price tag, as u can go and get what u want and not be baffled by what is given to you. The descriptions in the menu are very misleading for the a la carte items, so if u want a bowl of cereal, for example, just ask if u can choose it directly from the buffet. The 10grain cereal is actually puffed wheat (yes, as in the kids fave) and not at all what u would expect. Other than that, very very nice hotel.

Thank goodness the Palace Hotel opened! It is by far the best hotel I've stayed at in Tokyo. As other reviewers have said, it does a wonderful job of combining traditional Japanese style and service with a modern feel. As soon as you enter the hotel you are greeted by the most wonderful smell. It's actually a scent you can buy from the spa. The rooms I've stayed in are beautiful and much larger than in other Tokyo hotels I've stayed in. it's also in a great location next to the Imperial Palace which if you're interested in exercising is a good spot for a run, although the gym in the hotel is also fantastic.

Hotel entirely rebuild from the venerable Palace Hotel. Magnificent combination of style between traditional Japanese and modern styles. Just beautiful everywhere in the lobby, in the rooms, in the restaurants and bars.... very attentive, efficient and polite service. As a typhoon approached I ventured to the concierge to rebook my flight earlier. The concierge rearranged everything on a sunday morning in 5 minutes. The room is spacious well appointed with a delightful balcony and incredible view on the imperial palace ground. At night incredible silence despite beeing at the very heart of Tokyo. This place is just special. Of course other hotels in Tokyo are also excellent: The Ritz Carlton in Midtown, The Peninsula nearby in Yorakucho, The Mandarin Oriental in Nihonbashi, the Park Hyatt in Shinjuku, Capital Tokyo in Akasaka ( may be the clever quality vs. price choice!) but in my view the Palace Hotel will give you both incredible beauty and luxury and a a genuine Japanese experience. May be the best city hotel in the world.

Well, if you think you have stayed at the Best Hotel ever, and you have yet to bunk at the Palace Hotel in Tokyo, think again.No detail is overlooked with excellence being an everyday standard.The rooms are spacious and inviting, with views abounding. The Concierge floors are crazy good and the lounge,service and all the trimmings is excellent.Room baths are ample and full of ammenities. Let's face it, this is a real, and rare business or family treat.....four thumbs up for sure.

We stayed for two nights after arriving late from Lax and cannot say better things about this place. Rooms are big for Japan and bathrooms are huge and even the worst rooms have a fantastic view of the park and imperial palace. We loved how roomy and spacious the lobby area is and how tranquil and relaxing the setting is along the moat, yet sitting right above Otemachi station and a short walk to Tokyo station. Next time I visit Tokyo, this will be my one and only option.

If you're looking for an upmarket hotel around the Marunouchi / Chiyoda area then this hotel is perfect - only a short walk (5-6 mins) from Tokyo Station. It's a well maintained and formal hotel - rooms are large for Tokyo standard and the views over the palace grounds are fantastic.The gym is good and the spa / gym staff are helpful and willing to show you around. If you want to eat / drink somewhere a bit less formal than the hotels bars and lounges try the restaurants and pub in the basement complex; they're good value for money and a bit more relaxed.

This is *the* hotel to choose in Tokyo! It offers unique views of the Imperial Palace garden, and has sumptuous rooms with modern technology (like mirror built-in TV in the bathroom, 46 inch TV in the room). I had a great time there, either on the large balcony admiring the view, or in the Evian Spa and its 20m long pool. Service was irreproachable, and housekeeping of an elite level. After my stay here, I won't go anywhere else when back in Tokyo!

We stayed 5 nights in this hotel with my spouse during our first trip to Japan. The hotel is located close to the Imperial Palace and we had a beautiful view over a park with the Tokyo skyscrapers which was amazing especially at evening. The room is large, the bathroom is perfect, the beds are very comfortable and we had a large balcony as well. The staff is very polite and professional. Free wireless internet is available all over the hotel. The Ginza district is in a waking distance, other destinations can be reached by the subway which has a station under the hotel. The only negatives are that the breakfast is nothing special, the inroom lightening is tricky and we missed a proper desk (but we had a relatively huge table we could use for working). Altogether one of the best hotels I have ever been to.

It was recommended by an sub-contractor friend. I believe it is one of the best domestically operated hotel in Tokyo. The hotel has been totally refurbished, since Tokyo is an extremely competitive hospitality market. The hotel facilities are not only first class, but also the service.
