Not only was the club floor service was superb, but also the bell captain was extremely knowledgeable of the city. Two thumbs up!. If one would have time, I would highly recommend their French restaurant, Crown. I believe they are one there way towards earning michelin star!Two thumbs up!

Everythig in this hotel was perfect. The reception staff speak perfect and they go out of their way to make your stay memorable. The rooms are spacious and extremely well fitted out. The laundry service is quick and efficient.The facilities for entertainment were first class, one could start to believe you are across the road in the Imperial palace. his is one of the finest hotels I have ever stayed in.
user_name:
Ron E
Connah's Quay, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed five nights at the palace hotel in Tokyo last June 2013. We could enjoy the delicate Japanese perfectionism, an excellent hotel facing the quiet imperial gardens offering exquisite service at a much more reasonable than other hotels in Ginza. Although it is not in the Shibuya or Omotesando area, it has very good tube connections and is very close to Ueno, Ginza and other interesting sights. If you want to try a daytrip to Kamakura or Fuji mountain out of the city, Tokyo station is ten minutes walking from the hotel. Breakfast, however, is quite expensive and with so many good lunches and dinners awaiting for you, it makes no sense to start the day so full, why not try some deli on the way to Ginza? Dean and Delucca, in the nearby, is fine!But surely the best of the hotel was the amiable and efficient lady who attends every morning in the Concierge desk to any guest seeking suggestions for sightseeing or just a good restaurant. The best guide to Tokyo without leaving the hotel! In addition, there was a misunderstanding one night when we tried to go to dinner at Sushi Kanesaka (two Michelin stars), and the next day we were invited to dinner or eat there for free! Truly, one of the best hotels we have been treated ever, just as if we were at an Aman. Thank you!

I had been 2 times before in the Palace Hotel in Tokyo. When we arrived at the hotel surprisingly there is a completely new hotel in the same place.The rooms now have a better view of the Imperial Palace gardens and are extremely well decorated.The services continue excellent, with the people always willing to help you. The Concierge services exceeded our expéctations. They are quite immportant to provide directions, reservations, etc, mainly if one does not speak Japanese.The breakfast service is first grade in terms of food variety and services.I will return there if possible, but I would choose a room with balcony to better feel the city.

This is a great hotel. The standard rooms are big by any city's standards. The bathrooms are great with a very nice shower and bath. I had a imperial palace view which was very nice. The staff is all very professional and courteous and all speak great english. The hotel also has a great location being very close to Tokyo station.
user_name:
Scott F
New York City, New York

review_body: I'll start with the pros. The rooms are spacious, with comfortable beds, well-laid-out and well-appointed bathrooms, nice views of the palace grounds if you get a room facing that direction, and great sound insulation. The service is generally as good as you'd expect for a hotel at this price level. It's the sort of place that tempts you to lounge around in your comfortable room all day instead of going out into the city.But it gets knocked down from 5 stars for a few reasons. The breakfast is pretty lackluster for a hotel of this class, not much selection and nothing especially delicious. Breakfast was also the one time we experienced poor service during our stay; the staff asked if we wanted coffee and we said yes, but after ten minutes no coffee had arrived and we had to flag down another waiter to ask for it again. Nitpicky but at these prices you get to nitpick.The location is convenient if you're visiting the Imperial Palace or you have meetings in the surrounding office buildings. But for general sightseeing, it's a bit of a hike to several of the subway lines that in theory are right nearby, and I found myself thinking it would have been better to choose a hotel a couple blocks closer to the train station just for better subway access. If you take taxis everywhere it won't matter as much, but the subway is usually much faster than getting caught in Tokyo traffic.There are restaurants and shops in the arcade under the hotel. We ate at two of them and weren't impressed; the same quality food is available at much lower prices within easy walking distance, as is much better food at similar prices, e.g., at the "Iyo!" shopping arcade a couple blocks away. Those restaurants aren't part of the hotel per se, but given their location they factor into my impression of the place.The #1 thing that irritated us on an ongoing basis, though, was the lighting controls in the room. The overhead lights in the dressing area are on a dimmer, and we wanted to leave those lights dimly lit and turn off all the rest of the room lights at night. This turned out to be a nontrivial undertaking that required a fair amount of trial and error -- the bedside lighting controls, for example, will turn the floor lamp on, but won't turn it off again, so you have to flip the physical switch on the lamp if you want to turn it off while any other lights are on. Again, this is something I wouldn't bother complaining about in a budget hotel, but for the amount of money they charge, I expect them to have thought through common scenarios like wanting a non-pitch-black room at night.That's a bunch of complaints but really none of them were deal-breakers and we enjoyed our stay a lot. This hotel isn't perfect but it's pretty darned good, even at the price.

The Palace is a truly great hotel. It is brand new, luxurious and the rooms are huge compared to others I have stayed in in Japan. The hotel is located opposite the gate to the Imperial Palace and overlooks the gardens and Palace with the tokyo skyline as a backdrop. It was like an oasis within this metropolis. The room we stayed in had a large and private balcony. The service throughout the hotel was terrific, we were travelling with 2 young children and the staff made them feel very welcome. The pool and the fitness centre was great and the hotel waived the $20 pool fee for us after a request from our travel agent in Japan. The hotel was an easy walk to the subway and also to Tokyo station for the bullet train. There was a number of restaurants and cafes in the arcade below the hotel including a fantastic Italian restaurant and the obligatory Irish pub if you need a bit of western food and tv. We had planned to stay at the Peninsula which was unavailable but will definitely stay at the Palace next time we are in tokyo.

I was there for a short stay in between 2 cities. I booked the special rate online and to my surprise it was value to money paid stay. Room was clean and crisp, not simply because of the renovation, but it was maintained very well. Front Line staff at the driveway was nice and friendly. Reception staff was polite and professional, but must say that they do not exude friendliness and warmth, which is probably very typical tendency in Japan as being polite, is focused more than being friendly. The room was small but the space was utilized very efficiently so you do not feel that it is small. Bathroom and amenity is gorgeous, I wish I could have stayed a bit longer. Used bar and Sushi place. Again, bar server was polite and professional but did not feel the sense of warm welcome. Then we moved on to the Sushi Restaurant. We were very lucky to be able to get ourselves in that night. It is small 10 counter seats place but the head chef there was probably the most engaging and friendly personnel that we met in the hotel. Quality of the foods were immaculate, as well as the service. It was not a cheap dinner but it was worth it, and it was truly entertaining! Overall, I had great time, and I may have just find another hotel on my list of top hotels in Tokyo.

A lovely hotel to stay in when in Tokyo. It overlooks the Palace, so one can take a walk or run around the palace's outer premises. It is a 5-7 minutes walk to the Tokyo Station. The rooms are beautifully put together; very nice bathroom. The lobby cafe has an outdoor seating which was lovely in the morning (for breakfast) and in the early evening for drinks/snacks. The only down side to the choice of restaurant was that the cafe didn't serve simple japanese food. There was a very fancy and expensive Japanese restaurant though.All in all, it was a lovely hotel!

I attended a wedding at this hotel and is was just beautiful. The Chapel looks like something from heaven. The meal was fantastic and each dish was like view a beautiful painting. Everything about this hotel is 20 out 10. Next time I come to Japan I am going to stay a few nights here.

A room balcony and lounge chair to look over downtown Tokyo and the water of the Imperial Palace! One year old, rebuilt and luxurious/modern. Middle of central business district where all major corporations are. Nothing like it. Peninsula, Ritz and Hyatt are great but the Palace location and views are second to none. A new high standard of luxury in Tokyo. Lovely sitting area.
user_name:
Megazord
New York City, New York

review_body: One of the best hotels I've ever stayed in! Everything about it was what a 5-star hotel should be....Pricey, but if you like to splurge or are accustomed to travelling at this level, this hotel is well worth it!

As per all the other reviews, this hotel was excellent at every level of hospitality.The view over Tokyo and the Palace was stunning.Our last 2 nights here in Tokyo were a true joy, the people here gave us an incredible experience, the balcony room perfect with all amenities fit for royalty.The club lounge was superb and I would highly recommend a package with the club lounge included. We tried to get into the hotel restaurants but they were fully booked during our stay.The hotel is well positioned especially with the subway in the basement, a good assortment of small restaurants, cafes and for something different an Irish bar!! catering for all budgets,all down stairs Here or the conrad both different and amazing - we can't wait to get back!!

There was a special aromatherapy once you step into the hotel. It was a mixture of perhaps citrus and a wood. The hotel is fitted with art pieces in every corner. Being next to the Palace, yo have the luxury of just walking over and running around the Palace - and inhaling the fresh air that envelops the palace and the hotel.The staff were ultra attentive. And last but not least, you must try the special chocolate from the bakery in the basement. They are sheets of chocolate with traditional pattern "engraved" into each sheet of chocolate. The whole packaging is just another experience in an of itself. The only place that is worth staying in Tokyo.

Fantastic location, literally next to the moat of the imperial gardens. Can walk from Tokyo station (marunouchi exit, walk away from station towards palace, 10-15 minutes). Spacious rooms, many with view of the gardens. Very well- designed bathrooms (tub and shower), many rooms have balcony. Nice gym (24hr), pool costs 20$. Service is impeccable - hotel connects to one of the main subway stops (otemachi) underground. Service is impeccable with most staff speaking fluent English. Inside tip : for people looking for western food there is a French pastry place in the arcade (sweets & deli) which is quite good.One caution : beds might be a little short for basketball players (I'm 6"1' and it was ok)
user_name:
Oliver J
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is very conveniently situated close to the Tokyo station. It is a step up from other nice hotels in Tokyo, such as the New Otani, probably because it was rebuilt in 2012. The style chosen is similar to other hotels, so do not expect some out of the box design or unforgettable expereince. Just, a very nice and very modernly conceived hotel. Location is quite ideal for Tokyo: five minutes away from Tokyo station, the hotel is connected to Otemachi metro station, which is the biggest in Tokyo, and it's beside the Imperial Garden. Hard to find a more connected place ... Rooms are big, very nicely conceived, and with probably the best mattress I ever slept on. TV channels are, as usual, rather scarce in Japan. Courtesy of staff is very good. As a side note, if bars could be open a bit longer, that would be great for us jet-lagged people, but I understood it was Tokyo regulations that did not allow this ... By the way, all the fanciness comes for a price - so, if you are prepared to pick up a hefty price tag, then this hotel is the best you can find.

We stayed at the Palace at the end of April for our first trip to Japan. The hotel is absolutely beautiful and the service was fantastic. I can echo all the other reviewers great comments about the standard of rooms, amenities, etc. We were on holiday, not on a business trip, and we loved the location. Unlike some other major hotels, you can easily walk to great shops and restaurants. Marunouchi is a vibrant up-market area which is really smart. The access to the subway under the hotel was a bonus.We stayed in a club room and must mention the service from the girls in the club lounge. They were really friendly and helpful - and they made a special fuss of me on my birthday which was much appreciated! They really were delightful.I can't wait to visit Japan again and would stay at this hotel in a heartbeat!

I stayed at this hotel during a recent business trip to Tokyo. The location could not be better. The property is directly adjacent to the royal palace grounds in the heart of Tokyo.The hotel apparently was recently remodeled and re-opened. The rooms are great particularly if you get one with a city view. I ate in a couple of the restaurants and the food was outstanding both times.The gym is surprisingly small for such a nice hotel but the equipment is decent.The service was top notch.I am planning another stay during my next trip to Tokyo.

This is what a hotel should be. They do not miss a beat.It is not just that they do it right, they anticipate things.The staff are so friendly it is refreshing, and can be aremedy for all the pain one would have had traveling in France and subjected to their arrogance. The hotel is veryquiet and elegant. Food is very good, and the service the best. And of course the location is very good for business.

When my fiance and I arrived at the Palace Hotel, I was surprised on how great it was. The staff is very courteous and friendly. We were greeted by at least 10 people by the time we got to our room. Check-in was a breeze. They had a bellboy take our luggage up to our room and gave us a tour. We were on the 18th floor facing the Imperial Palace. It was such a nice view. Our room was very clean. It looks like it just went through a remodel. The rain shower head was a great. The bidet was a nice touch. The location of the hotel is on the Otemachi Station. You can get to any part of Tokyo easily. We used the concierge every day to plan our day or schedule a reservation at a restaurant. The only negative is the breakfast buffet. I was highly disappointed with the selection of food. I expected a lot more.

Very impressed by this hotel for my second stay in Tokyo. Good location and a lovely setting near the palace. Nice rooms well serviced and walking distance to Tokyo station for NEX. Recommend this for business travellers. Good, fast in room wifi, good quality speaker phones in room and desk space. Bar downstairs is good, but service was a little slow, especially when sitting outside. Breakfast was pretty good, nothing extraordinary but good

Very happy with this hotel, esp for the price compared to others. The area is very nice, and has a nice park with the Imperial Palace across the street. I would get a balcony room facing the park! Only thing that was disappointing was that after travelling for a very long time - my room was not ready until 5pm! This has never happened to me before, but they were kind enough to let me go to the executive lounge and feed me espressos. Otherwise a great experience and if the Conrad is not a lower price when I return, this is where I will stay.
user_name:
Dan H
New York City, New York

review_body: We were in Tokyo for 5 nights of our 3 week self-planned Japanese holiday and were absolutely delighted, in every respect, by our choice of the Palace Hotel. The hotel is located in one of the most prestigious Tokyo areas, Chiyoda, right opposite the Imperial Palace and close to the gate to the Palace's East Gardens. It is a mere 10 minute walk or a 5 minute ($7 cab ride) from Tokyo Station where the Narita Express from the airport arrives. The service in the majority of hotels in Japan is first class and the Palace was no exception - caring, courteous and very helpful. Our room was a good size, beautifully furnished, fabulous bed, nice bathroom with separate shower and exquisite toiletries, with towels that put the fluff in fluffy. Tokyo is a very easy city to get around and the Otemachi subway station, just minutes away, can be reached without going outside the building! The tourist open top bus service that runs 3 routes around the city is just a 5-10 minute walk away close to the station so for us tourists the Palace Hotel was extremely conveniently located. There are plenty of good shops in the Maranouchi area close-by and a Dean and Deluca if you are missing your coffee. We only ate in the hotel restaurant one evening and that was the more casual ground floor eaterie. We had some delicious tapas and 4 glasses of very nice red for a total of $75 so definitely weren't blown out of the water by the expense. The Palace is not a cheap hotel but it delivers value and luxury in spades.

We had to wait for quite some time for room key and to find out the receptionist forgot to do it.Breakfast selection is poor and there is no Japanese option which we would've expected. Location is good for business travellers but not for tourists.Takes about 10min taxi ride to Ginza

A great place to stay in Tokyo - while you tend to get first class service everywhere in Japan, the quality of the hotel and rooms as well as its location near to Tokyo station, the Imperial Palace and Maranouchi sets this apart from the rest.

I have just returned from Tokyo where I had the absolute pleasure of staying four nights at the Palace Hotel. We chose the Palace after looking at the top 20 hotels in Tokyo, then refining them by the standard of rooms, design and levels of service. We wanted to avoid staying at a Hyatt, Mandarin or Four Seasons, so the Palace Hotel was a great option. It's also brand new and very modern. Being a Japanese owned hotel, it's standard is of the absolute highest level. Much like the Halekulani in Waikiki is of a superior level to the other multinational chain luxury hotels, we found the same at the Palace compared to the other bigger multinational hotels.The hotel is close to the JR station (Y1,000 taxi ride) or 5 - 10 minute walk if you have carry-on luggage. If you're arriving from the Narita airport JR train, follow the yellow Yaesu Central Exit signs for the taxi rank to get to the hotel. Upon arriving at The Palace after a 14 hour + flight from Melbourne, Australia, we were weary yet excited to explore Tokyo. We requested an early check-in but knew our chances were slim arriving at the hotel at 10am on a busy Saturday morning. To our delight, the check in staff apologised for the 1/2 hour wait - our room would be ready at 10.30am! The best apology I've ever had from check-in staff. This was the beginning of a faultless smorgasbord of world class, friendly, attentive service from the moment we arrived until well after we left (more on that later).We booked a Grand Deluxe Room which all come with a very large balcony, and the room is absolutely huge. There is a walk-in entrance, large walk-in dressing room (lots of hanging space, drawers, etc), very large area around the bed and then a day bed, armchair and table opposite the chicest mini-bar you'll ever lay your eyes on. The bathroom is absolutely divine, floor to ceiling marble (in muted tones), with clever mirrored walls throughout to make the bathroom appear huge and bright. The obligatory spaceship grade toilet is hidden behind a frosted door allowing the rest room to again be bright and welcoming. The bath and shower area is breathtaking, with the bath having a corner window to look out over the Tokyo skyline and palace gardens below. The Toto taps and shower heads are both excellent (sadly not available back home - I've already checked!), and tech heads will love the TV seamlessly built into the mirror (the funnest morning shave I've ever had). If you have a tendency to pilfer the amenities, you're in for a treat, provided you have a large luggage allowance for the flight home. The bath products are French Anne Semonin products used in the spa and I found them to be both luxurious and gentle on my sensitive skin. There were 8 individual bath products left in the shower and bathroom, and these were replaced twice daily where needed. There was also a long list of other amenities, wooden hair brush, razors, toothbrushes, hair bands and all the other usual items. The towels deserve their own award, they are Imabari towels made in Japan and the softest you'll find in any hotel in the world (albeit typically small in Japanese fashion). If you fall in love with them (guilty as charged) they are sold in the friendly towel shop in the world in the underground Palace shopping complex.The television in the bedroom is huge, the bed is incredibly comfortable and the block out curtains (all electric) and blinds mean the room is pitch black at night. All the room furniture is of the highest standard and beautifully designed. The carpets feature a cherry blossom pattern which lifts the slightly masculine feel of the room. This is by far the best quality furnished room I have stayed in globally, and the design is classic yet modern chic. Everything is brand new from the floor up - a distinct advantage over the Mandarin Oriental, Peninsula and Imperial Hotels.The room service was of a high standard, and although I'm not sure it was intentional (probably was knowing this hotel), we had the same incredibly friendly staff member each time we ordered a meal. The other meals we had were also of a high standard in the hotel restaurants. We had dinner at the Grand Kitchen (my least favourite meal purely because I wasn't crazy about the table design and chairs and it was on the cold side seated right next to the windows - the food however was excellent) and coffees in the main lobby.Another highlight was Privé, the restaurant bar on level 6. The room is intimate and beautifully designed with a jaw dropping view of Tokyo and the gardens below. The service here was absolutely faultless, the female front of house who seated us each time was so lovely and elegant, we couldn't wait to go back each time, and we did go back, 3 times. At lunch they offer a 3 course meal of soup, main and dessert for only Y3,000 excluding drinks. At that rate, and with a great meal and dessert included (my favourite from my whole trip - a cherry blossom themed light vanilla dessert with raspberry) we splurged and ordered Cristal (2008) by the glass at Y3,300 (the Louis Roederer NV is a relative bargain at Y2,000 a glass), which compared to what that would cost in Australia, was an absolute steal. The bar was quiet most of the time, however for dinner on the Tuesday night, as we were leaving it was filling up with salary men who were ordering martinis by the table - so might have been fun to stick around. Indeed we found the lounge and lobby very busy on weekends but virtually empty on weekdays, whilst the on-site restaurants downstairs and upstairs were very busy on weeknights and quiet on weekends.In terms of other services, we utilised the laundry service with excellent results. I would recommend calling housekeeping to have an iron in your room for your stay if you want to save on the cost of having your clothes pressed. There is also a very well stocked (and super friendly) 7-11 downstairs (with a foreign ATM) which sells juice and soft drinks for well below the cost a few floors above. If you can bring yourself to drink Y1,200 bottles of wine, you'll find that too!When it came to check out, we were travelling to Tokyo for two days and couldn't bare to take all our luggage with us. The bell desk didn't blink an eye at our request to hold onto 8 bags for a further 48 hours. And that's the way it was at the Palace Hotel. No matter what the request, there was always a 'yes'. Nothing was too much trouble. There are too many small examples to mention of this however I would say that all the staff we met took absolute pride in the service they provide. There were some previous reviews that (fairly) described the service as overwhelming or over-the-top, but once you realise the staff are passionate about service, and are the best at what they do, you can really get used to it without the guilt. A returned bow and thank you in Japanese will always be appreciated by the staff also.In terms of location, you need to decide what's important to you where you stay. We were willing to trade being in the thick of it (Shinjuku / Shibuya / Ginza) with the more relaxed, elegant atmosphere of the Imperial Palace views and corporate buildings near by. You will feel 'out of the action' at this hotel, but it's only a train stop away (2 minutes). We found this the absolute best compromise - walking and jumping on trains all around Tokyo each day till our feet were literally bleeding, and then coming back to the Palace Hotel, pouring a champagne and lying in the bath watching the Tokyo skyline from afar. We met friends staying in Shinjuku and frankly the sheer amount of people everywhere meant you were dodging people the moment you left their hotel. I would also recommend booking a tour of the Imperial Palace grounds with the imperial household agency, there are a limited amount and you need to book up to 2 months in advance. We also got PASMO universal train cards that you can use on any tokyo metropolitan train line (subways and JR lines) from Concierge.The train network is something else, as you can expect, and we mastered it in a day or two thanks to a couple of fantastic iPhone apps. The best thing to do is order a b-mobile data SIM before you arrive (they will post it to your hotel the day before) so you can use google maps on your iPhone, it will plot out which trains to catch and where to change stations.The downstairs shopping precinct was dead on weekends but busier on weekdays. The shops downstairs include the exquisite Imabari towel shop, a spectacular (but minimalist) pottery/crockery store with very reasonable prices along with the amazing sweets & deli shop and a number of all small gift stores.As we returned from Kyoto and then picked up our baggage and moved onto another Tokyo Hotel (Capitol Hotel Tokyu - great hotel but not even close to the Palace in any respect, although the Capitol is much more affordable), I could not forget the fantastic experience we enjoyed at the Palace Hotel. In fact, on our last day in Tokyo, five days after checking out of the Palace, we went back and had lunch Privé one last time before our flight home (complete with Cristal!), bought towels and crockery from the shops below and then sadly jumped on the subway headed to the airport - we just didn't want to leave! Finally on my way home, I recalled the Palace sell the unique essential oil scent that features in the hotel lobby spaces, and I had forgot to pick some up from the Concierge. I emailed the hotel the day I returned to Melbourne and asked if they would post some out to me (for the cost of the oil and postage of course) and sure enough I received the essential oil a few days later in the post.We will definitely be back to The Palace Hotel. Until then, we'll have to make do with the essential oil scent, the towels, the crockery...and a few cheeky amenities!

In a city with many excellent, newly designed 5-star hotels with flawless service, the Palace Hotel still manages to stand out for its stunning design, grand views and stellar location. As befits a great 5-star hotel, the design, atmosphere, rooms, service, location and dining were all top-of-the line. The Palace was completely rebuilt and re-opened just in 2012, so everything still feels new and fresh. There is an element of classic yet ultra-modern design and art infused in every area of the hotel from the restaurants to the lobby and rooms. The architect clearly took advantage of the natural setting of the Palace right beside the Imperial Palace grounds and moat. While Tokyo in general is a fairly tranquil city, the tall glass facade that overloos the palace moat in the lobby, the use of green and off-white hues and the separation of the more active restaurant areas from the check-in lends the Palace a remarkable air of luxurious tranquility right in the middle of the world's largest city. Service was always prompt, fluent in English and on hand whenever needed. I've stayed at other 5-star hotels in Japan and it has not always been this easy to communicate in English. What separates 5-star hotels from 4-stars tends to be the level of service and number of staff. In this regard, the palace never disappointed. I never had to wait in line for anything and there were always several staff members on hand who I could turn to for service.The room was of generous size and the beds were of top quality. Possibly the greatest asset of the rooms are the balconies with stunning views overlooking the imperial palace and Marunouchi skyline. Even the lower floor rooms will benefit from this view. It was a very welcome introduction to the city and great to wake up to every morning. As the hotel is new, the technology in the room is all up to date. Of course, all the usual amenities are provided, but there are also a few extras too. For example, there is a built in flatscreen into the bathroom mirror which was quite nifty. Also, the bathroom is designed open plan so you can open it up to the main room. It includes a separate walk-in shower and large soaking bathtub. I was in Tokyo on business and the Palace hotel's location adjacent to the Marunouchi financial district was a huge benefit. We were able to walk to many of our meetings while also enjoying the scenery in the parks on the way back. This will suit travellers on leisure as well! While the hotel benefits from many restaurants, I mainly dined at the main all-day facility for breakfast. The Breakfast buffet was not huge in variety and quantity but more than made up for that in quality. As in many Japanese things, the focus was on providing a smaller selection of great quality items instead of more of everything. The roasted potatoes and sausages were some of the best I've had! In short, the Palace is what 5-star city hotels should all aim to live up to. Service, design, atmosphere, tranquility, luxury, large rooms with up to date technology... everything was flawless.

This hotel is a standout in the Tokyo business area. Posh, pretty and prime, guests will be accorded 5-star treatment with true Japanese hospitality in a contemporary space. Positives:1. The rooms are huge, and by Tokyo standards that already has a lot going for it. 2. If i am not wrong, all rooms have balconies that open up to awesome views of either the Wadakura park and skyscrapers of Ginza, Minato and Ropponggi or the Imperial Palace. Lovely vistas night or day. 3. The room is decked out impeccably. Comfortable beds, a settee, lots of mood lighting. Very clean.4. My room had a open-concept bathroom, with doors and screens or could deploy for privacy. There was a standing shower and a bathtub. And my God the shower! There's a rain shower option that shoots wonderful jets of spray from the ceiling. Alternatively, the massage options on the shower head plus the super water pressure should be sufficiently pleasing. 5. There's a TV screen built into the bathroom mirror so that one can be entertained while lounging in the tub or brushing teeth. 6. The turn-down service crew comes around in the evening to refluff your pillows, lay out a set of pyjamas, and restock water and other disposables. They also leave bedtime candies and the breakfast menu. 7. Location - some would argue it's off the main fun areas of Tokyo. I figure it's a respite from the hubbub, noise and lights. Otemachi and Tokyo stations are pretty close by. It's great for business trips into Marounochi and Chiyoda areas. Tokyo has the convenient Airport Express to Narita. 8. The hotel can arrange a shared bus to Narita or Haneda airports. The bus picks up travellers from other hotels so it takes a whole but it's way cheaper than getting a taxi. Negatives1. The selection of TV programs is sort of boring. Not enough family/popular entertainment options. No HBO. (Well it is a business hotel really.)2. I couldn't figure out how to control the main corridor light from the door. It seemed I could only do so from beside the bed. 3. Inevitably, such an awesome stay at a fabulous hotel is pricey. Regular rates are something like US$380 a night at the least. Hotel breakfast is about US$40. We opted for muffins and coffee at the nearby Dean & Deluca.

This hotel was so good on our arrival in Tokyo that we cancelled a booking at another hotel for our second stay after Kyoto and booked the Palace againThe location is excellent, walking distance to the station and Ginza and you basically fall over the Imperial Palace when you walk out the front door. And it's an oasis of calm in a big, busy cityWe were lucky enough to afford the Club Lounge (which probably saves money when staying in Asia) and while all the staff are friendly, professional and helpful, it was there that the experience was most exceptional. So good in fact that we emailed the hotel with a commendation for one individual staffer in the Club when we got homeI think it speaks well for the Hotel that we received a personal letter of thanks from the General Manager in replyif you can afford to stay at the Palace Hotel do so, you won't be disappointed!

This is a beautiful hotel. Everything is new and top quality, and even the lowest price category rooms are large by Tokyo standards. Our 18th-floor room had plenty of natural light and overlooked the moat and garden area across the street. Lots of toiletries are provided, along with nightshirts and the usual robes and slippers. The mattress was very comfortable and the hand-held shower head was the best ever - I want one for our home!We paid for access to the club level, and it was well worth it, at least for the one night we stayed. The club room is nicely decorated with a view overlooking the Imperial Palace grounds as well as the park area south of the hotel. Service was excellent. We arrived in time for the afternoon tea option, so had a quick coffee and scones. Later we enjoyed the cocktails and canapes, which served as a light dinner. The lounge wasn't crowded, and it was pleasant relaxing over a glass of wine and looking at the city lights. Breakfast the next morning was more than sufficient, if not the huge buffet we'd had elsewhere. At checkout, they presented us with a souvenir photo they'd taken of us on the little terrace the afternoon before.As others have noted, the location is quiet but only about 3 blocks from the main train station. If you want nightlife, it's very easy to take a train to Shinjuku or subway to Roppongi. It was even convenient to walk to the station with our luggage (wheeled) to catch the express train to Narita when we left. Though the hotel is not cheap, we felt it warranted the price and would love to stay there again if we return to Tokyo. A few minor quibbles:1. Why are so many hotels going to using all-in-one duvets as bedding? I applaud the replacement of gross bedspreads with duvets which are laundered every stay, but they are too hot and heavy for me. Please also provide a separate top sheet.2. When we checked in, the clerk asked if the normal noon check-out time was all right for us. We responded that our train was at 2:30 and if we could stay until 1:30 or 2 it'd be greatly appreciated. She left to check, and came back with 12:30 as the latest they could allow. This was fine, as we hadn't counted on a late check-out, but I'd suggest not raising the possibility of an extension if it isn't available.

For twenty years I have been staying at the Imperial hotel on my twice-yearly visits to Tokyo. This time the Imperial was full so I stayed at the recently opened Palace hotel. Which is better?1) Price. For a nine night stay the Imperial is quite a bit cheaper and in my view represents better value for money.2) Location. Overlooking water and the Imperial Palace yet within walking distance of Tokyo station I can't think of a better location for a Tokyo business hotel. Palace wins. (Having said that the Imperial is also in a superb location).3) Food. I don't dine at either hotel's fine dining restaurants but just have simple light meals in the evening at either hotel's ground floor cafeteria-style restaurants. The Imperial wins hands down. (I didn't think The Palace's food was anything special at all).4) Service. I have never stayed anywhere in the world with service as good as the Imperial's. The service at the Palace is excellent but not on a par with the Imperial's.5) Rooms. Refurbished rooms in the main tower of the Imperial are excellent as are the Palace's. Score draw.6) Sauna etc. Imperial club members receive free use of the Imperial's sauna and pool whereas you pay Y3,000 for a sauna and Y2,500 for a swim at the Palace. The Imperial's sauna and relaxation room has a wonderful clubby ambiance whereas the Palace's seems 'dead'.7) Telephone. Phoning home from the Palace is a rip-off while phoning home from the Imperial is reasonably priced.Next time I'll try to check into the Imperial before trying the Palace.....having said all of the above if you're with a colleague, and if you've got a healthy expense account, you could have a great time at the Palace. The interior decoration on the ground floor is delightful, the outdoor patio area is lovely, the hotel is brand new and the reception areas smell great.

we try a different hotel in tokyo each trip and palace hotel is one we'd consider staying at again. it almost feels like walking in clouds in here. it's very cavernous and even if there's people around in the lobby lounge, it doesn't seem busy. it definitely empties out early at night. i was impressed that concierge knew who we were when we first approached them--that's service. prior to checking in, concierge was very responsive and helpful via email for reservation requests. i was a little unhappy with the room at first since it didn't have a powder room. but when we were able to open up both balcony doors during the day bathed in sunlight and feel a gentle breeze, i was ok without the powder room (tho the balcony could fit 10 powder rooms). there's a little too many illuminating lights at night for my taste--from the a/c and lighting control panel, tho i was pleased to see an old school phone bedside instead of one of the fancy hi-tech ones with touchscreens that glow lights. the gym (open 24hr) has a lot of cardio equipment plus fancy cable contraptions and dumbbells. there's a small section with medicine balls and weighted bats. the pool is 20m long and they lend swimcap and kickboards (goggle for purchase). the club lounge breakfast is adequate with mostly western selection. they have a juicer which was a fun way to start the day. it's a nice place to relax for afternoon tea or cocktails after walking around the city all day. staff is very friendly and helpful.wifi is included in room rate while business center (24hr) has fee for computer usage (15min blocks), copies, fax, print. scan is free. i think you have to log onto the computer to print as there is no email address to send a print job. good location for tourists with access to many subway lines underground and tokyo station less than 10min away. tons of dining options nearby in all the marunouchi buildings, on top of the hotel restaurants. nice open views from guestrooms since no tall buildings on the palace grounds.

Simply Amazing! The Palace Hotel has you captivated from the moment you arrive. The brilance of the modern decor is enough to take your breath away. We stayed in a club room and were still checked in at the club lounge with welcome drinks, even though we arrived very late in the night. Friendly doesn't even begin to describe the staff, who would bend over backwards to ensure your needs are met. The room was one of the larger we have stayed in Japan. Around the same as Tokyo Disneyland Hotel, and larger than the Imperial Hotel for those wanting a comparison.The modem decor in the rooms made us feel not only comfortable but relaxed the moment we entered the room. The view of the Imperial gardens from our Room added another dimension that was even visible from the bath if you so wished.You must visit the bar for a stunning view, and amazing range of whisky.Not a large range for the club breakfast as always, but the view is worth it.Highly recommend. We can not wait till our next stay in Tokyo, as we no longer need to decide where to stay. We have found our Tokyo home.

While the Palace Hotel has a long history, I think it fair to call it a "new" hotel because of the recent extensive renovations. The work was worth it. The rooms are good size and of the highest quality, with great layouts for business travelers (lots of plugs, and complimentary wired and wireless internet). The bathrooms are very luxurious, with great water pressure in showers. The staff is superbly attentive, as you would expect from a 5 star Japanese hotel. I have been a frequent guest at, and a huge fan of, the Four Seasons Marunouchi, but I tried this hotel on a recommendation from a friend. Despite my high regard for the Four Seasons, I find this hotel even better, primarily because of the wider selections of restaurants, the great breakfast (which can be included with room), and the more convenient walk to the office buildings. (The hotel is a short 5 minute walk from Tokyo Station and even closer to the Maruouchi and Marunouchi-shin office buildings.)

Stay here 4 nights for meetings/conferences. First rate facilities, great location (next to Imperial Palace grounds, also <10 minute walking distance to Tokyo Station for trains & subways lines everywhere). Ultra modern gadgets in bathroom and bedrooms. Very spacious rooms for a western style hotel in Tokyo. Only drawback is it's very expensive, avoid eating breakfast in hotel if you can, even a simple continental breakfast easily costs closed to $30. Stay here if your company's traveling budget allows you the leadway. Many helpful & friendly hotel staff members with good command of English (except some dining room wait staff) made the stay very pleansant and trouble free.

We enjoyed our business trip to Tokyo for many reasons, but the Palace Hotel made it special. Best service, beautiful rooms, great location - they have thought of everything.Breakfast in the morning was amazing. It was an easy walk to the train station. We will be back to the Palace Hotel!

The hotel reopened in may 2012 following a complete rebuild. The rooms are a good size and simply top quality. Everything has been thought of. There is a tv in the mirror so you don't miss the news while shaving. It gets my best hotel shower award. It has the best lighting in the room. Low level lighting. Mood lighting. All controlled electronically. Push button blinds and make sure you are up high. My room is on 14 th floor. View over the park is brilliant. The location is great too. It is not however the cheapest hotel .......! Breakfast was the only slight criticism as although very good was not also in the very best category. I would also research eating here as opposed to some of the high end restaurants elsewhere.

The all new Palace hotel is a great venue to stay if you need a convenient location in Tokyo but are happy to avoid the livelier parts of town. It is very easy to reach from the airport by catching the Narita express to Tokyo train station from where it is a 5 minute walk. Its location in the Maranouchi financial district next to the Imperial Palace is a relatively quiet part of the city although its central location means it is easy to get to most other areas. The atmosphere in the hotel itself is one of serenity and calm, almost too quiet if you like a bit of hustle and bustle.The rooms are of a high standard and mine even had a bath. It also had a great view over the Palace park. All in all a good choice for a quiet base to visit Tokyo.

This was my first time staying at the Palace Hotel since it was closed and entirely rebuilt. If you ever stayed at the old Palace, there is simply no comparison to the new hotel. The rooms are spacious, everything is new and guests are treated like Royalty.It isn't cheap but it's worth it.If your looking for some comfort food, in the lower level (1 below) there is a noodle shop, English Pub and sundries available at the 7-11.

It's by no means a low-budget choice, but the "new" Palace Hotel delivers more than many other hotels of the same category. A good location and very friendly staff coupled with a very smart and stylish interior makes this a suitable place for business travellers and couples alike. Rooms are relatively spacious and most of them with good views as there are limited surrounding buildings. The lobby bar and resturant attracts outside guests so making reservation for meals is a good idea.

Extremely attentive staff, even for Japan. Always friendly, helpful and they do it with an earnest smile.Rooms are spacious, beautifully decorated and always with a fantastic view (although the balcony rooms more so than the ones without). In terms of service, this hotel seems to me to have the most modern and internationally oriented service while still maintaining that Japanese grace and elegance.The breakfast restaurant is airy, also beautifully decorated and both the a la cart menu and buffet leaves nothing to be desired in terms of selection and quality.The gym is well equipped, has a fantastic view and so spacious that you don't feel crowded when working out.Last thing, most staff speaks excellent English, which after numerous years of travelling to Japan with frustrating language barriers, is a huge relief.Cannot recommend this hotel enough.

This was my first visit to Tokyo and I expected that the hotel rooms would be tiny, as they are in Manhattan. Our (standard) room turned out be spacious, with beautiful views of the Emperor's Palace. The free, 24-hour gym had the same lovely views. (Warning-they kicked my husband out, saying his shoes--regular New Balance running shoes--were inappropriate--and we never could figure out why except that maybe they had black soles?) I had a wonderful massage at the spa and enjoyed sipping tea with a friend in the large and elegant lobby. The location is excellent in that it seems that wherever you go in Tokyo, you have to pass through the palace area. It's within walking distance of Tokyo station (though not if you have much luggage), where you get the train to the airport. You can also walk to Ginza, although it's a bit of a hike. A pedestrian mall behind the hotel has numerous restaurants and shops. The concierge is wonderful, especially if you do not speak Japanese. They booked numerous dinners for us and, Japanese style, refused tips. The room and restaurant foods were decent but very expensive. In general, this is an expense account type of place with impeccable service.

They have done a fantastic job with the new hotel. Modern clean, rooms are great with lovely balconies. Really well worth staying and even had a Japanese girl on the front desk who spoke impeccable english with a perfect accent.

Best hotel ever!~Large and modern room love the design of bathroom the bestfacing emperor palace, free and large gyma bit far from subway stationbut it's a journey of art, worth the pricebreakfast downstairs is also great (extra charges)very beautifully touchedbest hotel i've found in Tokyo

The hotel is excellent in every respect - service, rooms, facilities. It is also close to the subway. And my room had a perfect view of Mount Fuji in the morning. Truly a great experience.The only downside I can think for a tourist is that the area is the business district, so it can be quiet at night and there aren't as many shops or restaurants around as in Shinjuku or Ginza for instance.

This is perhaps one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in. We arrived around midday and the reception staff arranged an early check in for us with no fuss. We stayed in a Deluxe room with balcony on the 11th floor of the hotel. From our room we could see part of the Imperial Palace grounds, greenery in the parks in front of the hotel and the Tokyo skyline. The view from the room basically summarized the essence of Tokyo for us. History and tradition through the Imperial Palace grounds, the skyline of the business districts symbolizing the business and shopping metropolis Tokyo is, and the nature that sprouts between buildings exemplifying the attention Japanese culture places on parks and gardens. A truly beautiful city view both during daytime and at night.The room was functional and very spacious. We found the decoration tasteful with nice colors and with attention to detail everywhere. The balcony was on the small side but it overall added a feeling of more spaciousness to the room. The bed in the room was big and comfortable.Hotel breakfast was very good and the terrace outside overlooking nature and the moat next to the hotel provides for a nice relaxed meal or tea/coffee. There are many restaurants in the hotel and even a small arcade for shopping and food at the basement of the hotel.Service wise the hotel was great. The staff were discreet, courteous and polite and there seemed to be enough staff ready to help at all times in the lobby. During our stay we visited the Imperial Palace gardens which are just across the road from the hotel. We also walked to Ginza, past the famous Tokyo station, a nice walk to the heart of Tokyo shopping. Overall an excellent stay at Palace Hotel Tokyo. I recommend the hotel for a business stay or for a couples luxury sightseeing, shopping and eating Tokyo visit.

We stayed at the Palace Hotel on a business trip where my wife joined for a couple days. As many reviewers have indicated the hardware at the new Palace is impeccable - very modern with a touch of warmth that gives it an incredibly comfortable feeling. What was incredible about this past stay was the service of the assistant chief concierge Yuichi Hoshino who not only helped us with bookings but helped us find different restaurants over the phone while we were lost in Tokyo. Every day he greeted us, helped us and then walked us to our taxi to make sure that everything was okay - and with no expectation of a tip. I stay in hotels at least 3-4 times per month, and the Palace is one of the best.

My husband and I had stayed at the Palace 7 years ago and loved it, for comfort, service and location (close to Tokyo Station and the Otemachi metro station, and overlooking the Imperial Palace grounds). The hotel has since undergone a major expansion and renovation and recently reopened. It is now much bigger and grander. We were told that 80% of the rooms have views of the Palace grounds; our view was superb and our room included an outside balcony. The room was very spacious and well appointed, with every imaginable amenity. Overall the hotel is a beautiful property, but staying there was a bit overwhelming. Staffing levels and service standards are so high that, for us do-it-yourself Americans, walking through the lobby felt like running a gauntlet. After we used the gym (excellently equipped, by the way), staff members received our sweaty towels like a gift and ran ahead of us to open the exit door and press the elevator button for us. Generally, of course, Japanese service standards are much higher than American and all those "arrigato gozaimasu"s can really make you feel appreciated. Yet, our conclusion was that next time we go to Tokyo, we will stay in a smaller, less grand hotel. Having said that, the Palace is a great indulgence if you love to be treated like royalty!

Convenient location- just a short walk to the tokyo station. Room is well designed with tasteful touch. The bathroom is well equipped and stylish. And this is only a standard room.I should also add that the room offers a great view of the surrounding area. Breakfast had a good spread and was well prepared. I have no complaints.

Stayed three nights at this new hotel on a business trip. The location is across the street from an entrance to the Imperial Palace grounds. It is also only a couple of minutes walk from a metro station and about ten minutes walk from the famous Tokyo Station, where you can catch the Narita Express (departs about every thirty minutes and takes an hour to reach Narita Terminal 1 and 2. The hotel has very nice rooms with a sleek modern look and understated decor. Lots of modern features, including push-button controls for nearly everything and plenty of plug-ins for charging your electronic devices. Most of the rooms have views. Service from the staff is awesome and friendly. I did not try the restaurants or executive lounge on this trip, but The hotel has both. Another nice feature is that there are restaurants, fast food, and convenience stores a few minutes walk from the hotel in an underground shopping area that connects to Tokyo Station. One minor quibble is that simple printing tasks in the business center were more complex than you find at most hotels and they charge for even a self-printed boarding pass. Still, this is a very good hotel in my opinion. I would stay there again.

This newly renovated hotel was nothing but stunning. Located right in front of the Imperial Palace and in the middle of the most prestigious area of Tokyo, the view from the room was unbeatable both day and night. If you want to, you can jog or walk in the track surrounding the Palace's garden. I saw people doing it even until late at night and very early in the morning. You don't have to worry about getting harassed or robbed and the air was almost free of pollution. The hotel is also within walking distance to the Tokyo Station (also newly and beautifully renovated), subway stations and Ginza - a great walk even during the night. The room is classy, cozy and completed with everything even beyond one's expectation including a pajama and flat TV above the bathtub. TV channels are either Japanese or dubbed in Japanese but by turning the sound off you can still listen to the original version of the CNN, BBC, Discovery and Nat Geo channels in English. The service I would say was the best I had ever experienced, starting from the check in till check out time and all occasions in between. The staff seemed to do it wholeheartedly without expecting tips (it is not customary in Japan to accept tips from guests). One suggestion to the management, a welcome basket of fruits or Japanese delicacies in the room would add a little touch to the already excellent experience.

I cannot fault this hotel. I visited here on a business trip thus can't vouch for it as a family destination, nor can comment on value for money. But if someone else is picking up the tab, go for it. I was incredibly busy during my stay so saw nothing of Tokyo and far too little of the hotel. But if we focus simply on the room - which is what most business travellers need most of all - then it's fantastic. Exceptionally comfortable bed, glorious shower and bath, sumptuous towels and nightgowns, plenty of space, and brilliantly peaceful. I had time to dine only once in the restaurant and the food was first class. The bar is comfortable and spacious and one never has the sense of being hurried. The Japanese reputation for politeness and service is well deserved and this hotel has impeccable staff from top to bottom. As a deeply reluctant voyager, this hotel reduces the pain of business travel and pointless conferences and fixed-smile introductions to a zero. Thanks so much, staff of the Palace, if I ever come back to Tokyo and can afford it, I won't stay anywhere else.

Beautiful renovation and amazing location overlooking the palace gardens! This grand dame of Tokyo is brilliant! Rooms with views and balconies the best. Gym is a little small for a newly renovated hotel though - food is ok but it is IMF World Bank week in Tokyo - they seem to be coping well with the influx of mega- egos!

This hotel was a treat from my Japanese friend, as it was my first visit to the country. She wanted me to be comfortable my first night.... and was I ever comfortable! This hotel is AMAZING! Gorgeous rooms with views of the Imperial Palace area. The staff is wonderful and treats you like royalty from the moment you walk in. The only downside was that I only had one night here.

The Palace Hotel in Tokyo is simply lovely.The decor, the staff, the food, the impeccable turn down service, the proactivity to all of our requests.I have been to Park Hyatt but the Palace has a more intimate and boutique feel. True, it s 5 mins taxi from Ginza and it is not really close to the Roppongi and Omotesando scene but it is within reach by the impeccable Tokyo underground system.I loved it,  I will be back.

I have pretty much stayed in every 5* hotel in Tokyo but this one is the best one for the following reasons: 1) I arrived on a Japanese public holiday and i was travelling light. My trousers ripped at the airport and they were my only pair. I had a pretty important meeting the next day at 9am. I called the hotel and pretty calmly they arranged for a tailor to pick up the trousers when I arrived which was around 10:30pm. The trousers were then mended (the rip had been total and very embarassing) and dry cleaned for the morning at a cost of around double the price for dry cleaning - so pretty good value at the same time. This maybe says more about Tokyo than the hotel but i think there are some other 5* hotels in Tokyo that would not have been quite as acommodating. 2) the rooms are ecellent. I would say marginally smaller than the rooms of the Mandarin and in a similar style but feel more homely. Also they have balconies in addition and my one was large enough for a full outside table and soft chair. Everything in the rooms is electric as you expect in tokyo and the TV in the bathroom (built into the way at one end of the full length bath) is the largest I have seen in Tokyo. The room also had a big tv and a dvd player as standard. The selection of TV stations was also better than most Tokyo hotels including some movie channels such as wowwow and discovery so overall entertainment was great. Room service was delicious although the after 10pm menu was a little limited.  3) the view is right over the imperial palace grounds and because of the expanse you can see all the way to roppongi with Mori tower very evident as well as Tokyo tower. Of course somerooms dont look in that direction but pretty much all of them have some sort of view over the palace grounds. the location was also to die for - yes as someone said its not right in roppongi or ginza but compared to the shang or mandarin its just as good and its so close to tokyo station you can basically go anywhere. 4) the staff even by tokyo standards are insanely perfectionist.  5) the pool , the Evian spa (yes it sounds pretentious but its amazingly good ) and the chapel are all lovely as is the gym. The lobby is expansive and beautiful. 6) there are three high end restaurants - french, japanese, and chinese as well as an italian themed casual restaurant on the ground floor with a terrace overlooking the moat of the palace.I stayed in the old Palace Hotel often when it was still a 6 story building built in 1961 (indicentally there is a book detailing the history of the hotel for your perusal in each room which you can take home) and it was a good hotel if flawed. Its successor is , however, a true palace.Overall i cannot find fault here... maybe next time&_&

The rebuilt Palace is a great stay in Tokyo. It is convenient to the Palace grounds, train station and Ginza shopping area. The hotel is spa like and prefect in every way. The gym is very well designed and has full equipment. The hotel service was good. Breakfast is not included so plan accordingly.

Its a new hotel and thats why i picked it.Location is prime right across the Imperial Palace Tokyo, near to Ginza, but not walking distance.First i stepped into this beautiful hotel, i saw that every guest coming will be assisted directly with one staff. Really one staff to each guest. And it was busy at the lobby.The check in was fast, and they kept our luggage in the room already (we delivered our luggage from Kyoto with a the luggage delivery service).The room was beautifully appointed. The staffs are really professional, they greeted you with your name. Some staffs look really new but they tried their best to be as professional as they can.They have Evian Spa. But the bad thing is: you have to pay to use the swimming pool even though you are staying there.The swimming pool is very nice, it has a beautiful view. Too bad we didnt try the spa treatment.I found this hotel really good in every aspect, a serious competitor in the market.

Brand new hotel, with all 5-star amenities. My room was huge, with an elegant design, a mix of traditional japanese and modern. Bathroom was amazing, surrounded by crystal walls.As for the negative sides, location is great for business, but it lacks the atmosphere that other areas, like Roppongi, have. So, for dinner you will have to take a taxi or the metro to explore the areas where nice restaurants are located.Also, I found very annoying that they made us pay 50% of the room rate for an early checkin (at 11.00 a.m.). I understand paying for the early checkin when you ask for it in advance (since thay have to guarantee that your room is free), but when you arrive and the room happens to be free, this means that there is no extra-cost for the hotel... so why making you pay?In this kind of property, I would have expected a higher attention to the client!

Newly reopened and extremely well done. A beautiful property and wonderful staff. Located across the street from the Imperial Palace with great views. The room was large and well appointed with a "spa like" bathroom complete with amazing shower and great water pressure! The only downside - and very minor- was breakfast buffet lacked variety of more "western" style fare. Overall - a true 5 star experience.

Great location being separated to the Imperial Palace only by the water. Marunochi area is a bonus being great for shopping and eating. JR train station and the main Tokyo station isn't far away. Great renovation. Nice and modern feel but definitely not cold. Homey is the perfect description. Reasonably priced in my opinion. I love to eat, relax and read a book by the outdoor seating area overlooking the Palace. The lounge is perfect for sipping tea or drinking beer. I also enjoyed eating breakfast at their lobby outlet. Ate there for two straight days trying both the traditional Japanese breakfast and the usual continental buffet. Rooms are big and new. Great view i must say. Staff are very polite. I like this hotel better than the other five star hotels in the area.

The Palace Hotel is a wonderful hotel; newly reopened after extensive renovation. Adjacent to the Imperial Palace grounds and East Garden, it is somewhat removed from the crowded action of Tokyo and more geared to business clientele rather than tourism. However, the Otemachi subway is a block away and the Tokyo station is an easy walk (or 710 yen for a taxi). A line of taxis is always waiting. The Marunouchi Building is a short walk offering dining and shopping, and the Ginza is just minutes away. Citibank is down the street for banking needs. The hotel interior is bright with a contemporary edge and designed very well with a large lobby- front desk, concierge, and bellman on one side and a spacious lounge and restaurant with terrace dining overlooking a moat on the other. The atmosphere is relaxed and not stuffy. The lobby restaurant and lounge menus offer a nice selection and the cocktails are very well made. A restaurant in the park is also open for lunch, but we did not eat there so i can not speak for the menu.An escalator from the lobby leads down to an small arcade with small specialized shops, a 7/11, a few Japanese restaurants, and a Irish pub which offers a relaxed small pub atmosphere with Quiness and English pub fare (although not smoke free). The hotel's formal restaurants I feel need improvement. They were rather pricey as expected but I was just not that impressed with my dinner. Other close dining options (of all prices) were a good alternative. The hotel breakfast, however, was very good either ala carte or buffet with a Western selection for a full English breakfast of sausage, bacon, grilled tomato, sauteed mushrooms, potatoes, and eggs made to order; stations for bread, danish and fresh toast; fresh juices, milk, and cereals; another for a charcuterie of cheese, meats, and pickles.The rooms have very comfortable beds, and a nice design with the standard large TV on the wall, a room bar, and large closets. The windows are large and designed to have good views with automatic room darkening drapes. The bathrooms are very large and luxurious with an open glass bath, separate shower, sink with a mirror TV, and separate toilet with heated bidet features. Blinds provide privacy for the bath. Perhaps the Palace's best feature, however, is the service provided by the staff. Room service is just minutes away. Everyone treats you like royalty, and a walk through the lobby will never go without someone asking at least once if you need anything. Doormen always take care to explain to the taxi driver exactly were you are going. The concierge is extremely knowledgable and helpful, came to say goodby with bottles of water as we checked out and accompanied us to our taxi. There is no question we would return.
Best room ever . Daily changes. Nice services from the staff

Excellent Location and luxurious rooms. Very helpful staff. You can also do Gym here. Gym is equipped with latest machines. You can use swimming pool here. But you have to pay some charges for that. Ginza is not so far from here. You can do a limited breakfast because of its menu. I strongly recommend it.

Excellent hotel - beautiful facilities, comfortable rooms with nice bathrooms (great shower!) and flawless service - particularly impressive less than a month after opening. Very convenient location for business in Chiyoda and also not too far from good shopping in Ginza. However, not a very lively location at night or over the weekend. The views of the imperial palace are obviously great and make this a very unique place - my favorite spot was the terrace of the lobby restaurant - just so relaxing and great atmosphere any time of the day.Hard to find faults - if anything, pricing of some of the services seems a bit off; unless staying in a club level room, guests have to pay for both using the pool (JPY 2,000) and the spa (JPY 2,500), which seems unusual for a hotel of this class / pricing; also a simple coffee at JPY 900 and a continental breakfast at JPY 2,500 is quite steep. Selection at breakfast buffet (JPY 3,500) is good quality but limited. Very happy to have found a new favorite hotel in Tokyo and look forward to being back!

Four nights stay in ideal location with attentive and helpful staff. Rooms are spacious with excellent amenities. Had wonderful view onto the Imperial Palace. Gym is well equipped but you do have to pay to use the swimming pool. Breakfast choice a little bit limited relative to some other hotels of a similar standard and class but still ate well. Found a good soba noddle house in the basement. Would definitely recommend the hotel and will use it again.

Excelent location. Re-design of the hotel is superb. Loved the views from our room of the palace grounds. Liked the location and service of the old Palace, but the new Palace has it all.Worth the cost and can't wait to go back. Don't read old reviews pre renovation - it is a different place.Gym and swimming pool excellent as is internet service. Great location for work.
